Event: GE born as Mary Anne Evans at South Farm, Arbury, near Nuneaton, Warwickshire, daughter of Robert Evans, 'the one deep strong love I have ever known' (Cross 1: 284) and his second wife Christiana, neé Pearson (1816-59). GE, the 29 youngest of his five surviving children: Robert (half-brother to GE, b. 1802), Frances (or Fanny, half-sister, b. 1805), Christiana (or Chrissey, b. 1814), and Isaac (b. 1816).
Baptised at Chilvers Coton church.
Birth of GE's twin brothers William and Thomas Evans (lived only 10 days).
Begins first journey away from home, visiting Derbyshire and Staffordshire in the company of her father and mother.
Two days of rioting, witnessed by GE, and subsequently influential on the composition of Felix Holt, begin at Nuneaton during the election for the North Warwickshire constituency.
Begins School Notebook (Beinecke), dated and signed Marianne Evans containing essay on 'Affectation and Conceit', poem On Being Called a Saint, and story 'Edward Neville' (Haight, pp. 553–60).

Fifteenth birthday. About this time has Evangelical conversion experience: 'One feels certain that it struck Mary Anne suddenly and hard' (Haight, p. 19). Begins to neglect her personal appearance in order to demonstrate her anxiety for the state of her soul.
Robert Evans suffers acute attack of kidney stone, an illness from which he never completely recovers.
Apologises for failing to send Maria Lewis details of her mother's health, the reason being her father's sudden illness.
Death of her mother, Christiana Evans. GE’s duties and emotional support help to compensate for the loss in her father's life.
Receives Holy Communion for the first time.

Acts as bridesmaid for Chrissey at her wedding to Edward Clarke, a medical practitioner at Meriden, near Coventry. GE takes over household management duties for her father after Chrissey's marriage and subsequent departure.
Invites Maria Lewis to stay with her in the coming holidays.
Sends Maria Lewis details of a recent week-long visit to London with Isaac, with whom she went to services at St Bride's and St Paul's, but refused to attend the theatre.

Writes to Martha Jackson, declaring that it is the duty of Christians 'to aim as perseveringly at perfection as if they believed it to be soon attainable' and condemning a recently heard oratorio concert in Coventry (Cross 1: 9).

Tells Maria Lewis, 'I am generally in the same predicament with books as a glutton with his feast' (Letters 1: 11), current reading including Robert Leighton' s A Practical Commentary upon the First Two Chapters of the First Epistle of St Peter and The Life of William Wilberforce by R. I. and S. Wilberforce. Repeated condemnation of the Coventry oratorio symptomatic of her religious zeal at this period: 'It would not cost me any regrets if the only music heard in our land were that of strict worship' (Letters 1: 44).
Solicits her aunt Elizabeth to send news of herself.
Writes to Maria Lewis, copying out in the letter Ryland's hymn 'Sovereign Ruler of the Skies’.
Tells her aunt Elizabeth, 'I feel that my besetting sin is . . . ambition, a desire insatiable for the esteem of my fellow creatures' (Letters 1: 19).

Sends a lengthy and earnest letter to Maria Lewis questioning the expedience of reading fiction: 'As to the discipline our minds receive from the perusal of fictions, I can conceive none that is beneficial but may be attained by that of history' (Cross 1: 52-3).
Disapproves of the Tractarian movement in letter to Maria Lewis.
Sends Maria Lewis a poem, As o'er the Fields: the crude fruit of a lonely walk last evening, when the words of one of our martyrs occurred to me (Letters 1: 27-28).
Sends Maria Lewis another early poem she calls Sonnet, beginning, 'Oft, when a child...' (Letters 1: 30).
Twentieth birthday.
Tells Martha Jackson that she has been reflecting on 'the duty of perfect contentment with such things as we have' (Cross 1: 37).

Writes to her uncle Samuel, 'I have been much exposed to temptation from contact with worldly persons . . . I have great need of your prayers, and I fear not that I shall be denied them' (Cross 1: 40).
Tells Maria Lewis of progress with the chart of ecclesiastical history, and asks advice on the formation of a clothing club. Mentions attack of hysteria at a party.

Sends Maria Lewis an outline of the historical chart, and refers enigmatically to the recent breaking-off of a romance (probably with a young man not of her own religious suasion). She repressed her feelings by a 'prayer to be free from rebelling against Him whose I am by right' (Cross 1: 46). Some High Church reading at this time, including the Tracts for the Times and the Lyra Apostolica.
Proposes that Martha Jackson always suggest in her letters a subject for intellectual debate: 'You will polish and sharpen me, will you not? Alas: I need melting and remoulding ' (Cross 1: 48).
Writes a lengthy letter of sympathy to Edith Kittermaster, following the death of her sister Jane.

Discovers that a rival chart of ecclesiastical history has just been published – plans for her own chart subsequently abandoned. Tells Maria Lewis, 'I am a negation of all that finds love and esteem' (Cross 1: 51).
Asks Maria Lewis to obtain Italian books for her in London.

Arrives with her father at Wirksworth, Derbyshire, where they stay with her uncle Samuel and aunt Elizabeth at the beginning of a week's tour. Comparative lack of enjoyment of this visit indicative of the growth of her religious doubts: 'I think I was simply less devoted to religious ideas' she subsequently recalled (Cross 3: 176)
Move on to stay with William Evans.
Return to Griff.
Writes to Maria Lewis about her recent journey.
Tells Maria Lewis that she and her father intend to move to Coventry.
Under the nom de plume of Clematis asks Martha Jackson (or 'Ivy') to visit her.
Tells her uncle Samuel, 'I cannot for her own sake regret that my dear Aunt is so near the very brink of Jordan' (Letters 1: 61).
Begins four-day visit with Isaac to his fiancée Sarah Rawlins at Edgbaston, near Birmingham.

Writes to Martha Jackson, 'Every day's experience seems to deepen the voice of foreboding that has long been telling me, the bliss of reciprocated affection is not alloted to you under any form' (Letters 1: 70).
Tells Maria Lewis that she has adopted Certum pete finem ('Seek a sure end') as her motto.
Inspects possible new house (Bird Grove, at Foleshill) with her father, who agrees to purchase it.
Visits the Nicholas Chamberlaine Hospital, an almshouse near Griff.
With her father, buys furniture for their new home.
Regrets that preparations for the move to Foleshill have prevented her writing sooner to her uncle Samuel.
Isaac drives GE to Foleshill to prepare for her father's arrival.
Robert Evans arrives at Foleshill.
Receives Easter Day communion with her father at Trinity Church, Coventry, where they become regular attenders.
Suggests that Maria Lewis might become governess to the Whittem family.
Robert Evans takes GE and Chrissey to see their half-sister, Fanny Houghton, at Baginton, near Coventry.
Travels to Edgbaston with Isaac.
Acts as bridesmaid at Isaac's wedding to Sarah Rawlins. The couple honeymoon in the Lakes and Scotland before returning to live at Griff.
Visits Chrissey at Meriden.
Drives to Kenilworth with her father to hear Henry Montagu Villiers (later Bishop of Durham) preach his final missionary sermon in the parish.
Agrees with Maria Lewis's determination to advertise for a position.

Tells Maria Lewis 'I am beginning to be interlaced with multiplying ties of duty and affection that, while they render my new home happier, forbid me to leave it on a pleasure-seeking expedition' (Letters 1: 101).
Tells Maria Lewis of the force of her realisation that she is 'alone in the world' (Letters 1: 102).
Thanks Maria Lewis for obtaining books for her (including Chalmers' Sermons) in London.

In a letter to Maria Lewis analyses the parable of the sower, and recommends Henry Hallam's Introduction to the Literature of Europe, remarking, 'I love words; they are the quoits, the bows, the staves that furnish the gymnasium of the mind' (Letters 1: 107-108).
Sends her uncle Samuel favourable news of her father and brother.

Asks Maria Lewis if she would object to becoming governess to a Nonconformist family, and bewails her own lack of social involvement: 'I am supine and stupid . . . while the haggard looks and piercing glance of want and conscious hopelessness are to be seen in the streets' (Letters 1: 116).

Taken to visit Charles and Caroline Bray at their house, Rosehill, overlooking Coventry, by Charles Bray's sister, Elizabeth Pears, a neighbour of the Evanses at Foleshill. Immediately becomes attracted to them. 'It is impossible to overestimate the importance of Mary Ann's introduction to the Brays . . . She was quickly brought from provincial isolation into touch with the world of ideas' (Haight, pp. 44, 46).  Reads Charles Hennell' s An Inquiry Concerning the Origin of Christianity (1838) as a result of this introduction.

Writes to Maria Lewis, 'My whole soul has been engrossed in the most interesting of all inquiries for the last few days, and to what results my thoughts may lead, I know not – possibly to one that will startle you' (Letters 1: 120).
Recommends Carlyle's Sartor Resartus to Martha Jackson.
Maria Lewis (who had stayed over Christmas) and Robert Evans temporarily leave Foleshill.
Urges Maria Lewis to return to Foleshill and to stay for as long as she wishes. Maria Lewis arrives in the evening.

Refuses to accompany her father and Maria Lewis to church, her first familial display of her religious change of heart, causing several subsequent pleas to change her mind, from both family and friends.
Maria Lewis leaves Foleshill for her new school at Nuneaton.
Again refuses to accompany her father to church.
Robert Evans pays his son-in-law Edward Clarke £250 to purchase a house, the commencement of the Clarkes' money troubles.

First written acknowledgement of change in personal theology in letter to Elizabeth Pears: 'I wish to be among the ranks of that glorious crusade that is seeking to set Truth's Holy Sepulchre free from a usurped domination.' Of the scriptures, she writes, 'I regard these writings as histories consisting of mingled truth and fiction.' (Letters 1: 106).

Tells Maria Lewis, 'having had my propensities, sentiments, and intellect gauged a second time, I am pronounced to possess a large organ of adhesiveness, a still larger one of firmness, and as large of conscientiousness' (Letters 1: 107-8).
Has her conduct reproved by her brother Isaac.

Writes to her father, announcing her determination not 'visibly to unite myself with any Christian community.'  Of the scriptures, she writes, 'I regard these writings as histories consisting of mingled truth and fiction.' Offers to leave Foleshill should he wish (Letters 1: 128).
Robert Evans plans to leave Foleshill, chiefly as a result of his daughter's conduct.
Writes to Cara Bray, regretting condemnation of the Evans family in an interview of that morning.
Advises Cara Bray that it would be unwise for Elizabeth Pears to seek an interview with Robert Evans. Considering leaving her father and supporting herself by teaching in Leamington.

Robert Evans, succumbing to the pleas of Rebecca Franklin and Elizabeth Pears, sends GE to live with Isaac at Griff. GE recalls, 'I came hither . . . in compliance with my Father's wish that I should retire for a time from a neighbourhood in which I had been placed on the very comfortable pedestal of the town gazing-stock' (Letters I, 133, 138).
Robert Evans postpones the sale of his house.
GE tells Elizabeth Pears that 'on a retrospection of the past month, I regret nothing so much as my own impetuosity' (Letters 1: 134; Cross 1: 112).

Writes to Francis Watts, professor of theology at Spring Hill College, Birmingham, discussing her doubts, and expressing her desire to translate R. A. Vinet' s Mémoire en Javeur de la liberté des cultes.
Tells Cara Bray that Robert Evans has agreed to GE's return to him after a time.

Following an agreement to attend church with her father (whilst tacitly withholding assent from the worship), GE returns to Foleshill. Cross records, 'In the last year of her life [GE] told me that, although she did not think she had been to blame, few things had occasioned her more regret than this temporary collision with her father, which might, she thought, have been avoided by a little management' (Letters 1: 113).
Visits Cara Bray at Rosehill, and is shown letters from her brother, Charles Hennell.
Attends church with her father.
Again attends church with her father.
Invites Maria Lewis to visit Foleshill in the coming holiday.

Sara Hennell arrives for a six-week stay at Rosehill. GE introduced to her during this month, and visits Rosehill when able to leave her father. Cross remarks, 'The two ladies- Cara and Sara . . . - now became like sisters to Miss Evans, and Mr Bray her most intimate male friend' (Cross 1: 114).
Edward Clarke and his family, still in financial difficulties, arrive for a three-day visit to Foleshill.
Tells Francis Watts, 'It seems to me that the awful anticipations entailed by a reception of all the dogmas in the New Testament operate unfavourably on moral beauty' (Letters 1: 144).
Sara Hennell leaves Rosehill.
Thanks Sara Hennell for writing to her.
Tells Sara Hennell that she has again met W. B. Ullathorne at Rosehill.

Resumes correspondence with Martha Jackson, left off because GE feared that her new opinions might give offence. Reports that her life is now 'peaceful and happy to a degree that I little anticipated some months ago' (Letters 1: 152).
Sends birthday greetings to Sara Hennell, the first of many exchanges of birthday letters between them.
The assembled Evans family discuss the desirability of GE's further association with the Bray circle.
Cara Bray records Robert Evans's refusal to carry out Isaac Evans' s plan of moving from Foleshill to Meriden, so that GE may be removed from the Brays' influence.
Death of Mary Hennell.
Sets out with the Brays, the Hennells and Rufa Brabant for three-week holiday, visiting Bristol, Tenby, Pembroke and Swansea. Rufa Brabant and Charles Hennell renew their engagement during this trip.
Returns to Foleshill.
Dines with Robert Owen at Rosehill: 'I think if his system prosper it will be in spite of its founder' she reports to Sara Hennell (Letters 1: 161; Cross 1: 119).
Thanks Sara Hennell for procuring her a copy of Hymns and Anthems, edited by W. J. Fox.
Sends Sara Hennell a lengthy letter about loss of faith, stressing 'the truth of feeling, as the only universal bond of union' (Letters 1: 162; Cross 1: 122).
Arrives in London, where she enjoys some sightseeing both before and after the Brabant-Hennell wedding.
Acts as bridesmaid at the wedding of Rufa Brabant to Charles Hennell at Finsbury.
Goes to stay at Devizes, Wiltshire, with Dr Robert Brabant.
Sends Cara Bray a favorable account of her reception by the Brabants.

Again enthuses about the Brabants in a letter to Cara Bray: 'I am in a little heaven here, Dr Brabant being its archangel . . . I am never weary of his company' (Letters 1: 165). Her relationship with Brabant, 'an intellectual friendship drawn by over-ready expansiveness into feelings misunderstood' (Haight, p. 52), begins to assume a proleptic character.
Tells Cara Bray that her return to Coventry is imminent, though concealing the problems caused by Dr Brabant' s affection for her.
Returns to Coventry from Devizes, indignant at Dr Brabant' s ungenerous behaviour after his wife's insistence that GE should leave the house.
Cornelius Donovan gives GE and Charles Bray a lesson in phrenology.
Asks Sara Hennell to clarify who is providing the funding for the Strauss translation, and whether the manuscript is to be sent directly to the publisher.
Hears Daniel O'Connell speak in Coventry.
Thanks Cara Bray for sending an account of her visit to Clapton, East London.

Leaves with the Brays for seventeen-day holiday at the Cumberland lakes, visiting James Martineau and his family in Manchester on the journey home. For Cara Bray's account of the trip see Letters 1: 178-80.
Begins three-day trip with Bray to London, where they visit a phrenologist, James Deville.
Writes to Sara Hennell regretting the long gap since they last saw each other.
Tells Sara Hennell that she hopes to have finished vol. I of Life of Jesus by the end of November. Apologises to Martha Jackson for the long gap in their correspondence.
Visited by the young artist, but her interest in him subsides.
Writes to break off their relationship.

Writes to Sara Hennell: 'My unfortunate affaire . . . I have now dismissed . . . from my mind, and only keep it recorded in my book of reference, article Precipitancy, ill effects of' (Letters 1: 185). Also oppressed by her translation work.
First meeting with Harriet Martineau: 'She is a charming person - quite one of those people whom one does not venerate the less for having seen' (Letters 1: 189).
Writes to Martha Jackson, giving details of her translation work and mentioning her ended involvement with the young artist.
Thanks Sarah Hennell for her painstaking assistance with the copy-editing of Life of Jesus.
Writes to Cara Bray, giving her comments on Disraeli's Sybil.
Begins three-day trip to London with Bray.
Delighted with first section of proof of Life of Jesus.
Forced to withdraw from the Brays' projected trip to Scotland because of the bankruptcy of her brother-in-law Edward Clarke.

At the last minute, intervention by Bray enables GE to accompany the Brays on their holiday, visiting Liverpool (where they renew contact with the Martineaus), Glasgow, Loch Lomond, Loch Katrine, Stirling, Edinburgh and Abbotsford. Cara Bray remarks, 'We were all in ecstasies, but Mary Anne's were beyond everything' (Letters 1: 201).
Learns of her father's broken leg.
Arrives home.
Complains to Sara Hennell about quality of printing of Greek in Life of Jesus proof.
Explains to Sarah Hennell that the illness of herself and her father has impeded translation work.

Cara Bray reports that GE has not enjoyed 'dissecting the beautiful story of the crucifixion' and is nervous about public reception of her translation. Her father's illness has also been a cause of anxiety (Letters 1: 206; Cross 1: 139).
Tells Sara Hennell that she has not enjoyed translating Strauss's accounts of the crucifixion and resurrection of Jesus, or the bursting asunder of Judas.
Delighted by Strauss' s preface to her translation.
Begins eleven-day visit to Sara Hennell in Clapton.
translation of D. F. Strauss's The Life of Jesus, begun in 1844, appears anonymously, published by John Chapman in 3 volumes.
Visits Dover with her father for a fortnight, and becomes considerably distressed by the deterioration in his health.
Sara Hennell remarks that GE 'must be writing her novel', an engimatic speculation (Letters 1: 233).
Reports herself in high spirits to Sara Hennell, asking her to write more frequently.
Writes a burlesquely humorous letter to Charles Bray, imagining herself proposed to by Professor Biicherworm of Moderig University.
Review of Christianity in its Various Aspects, by Quinet, of The Jesuits, by Quinet and Michelet, and of Priests, Women and Families, by Michelet alone, appears in the Coventry Herald.
Review of Gilbert à Beckett's The Comic History of England appears in the Herald.

Tells Sara Hennell that she would like to complete her collection of Xenophon's works, and reassures her about the extent of her regard for Brabant: 'If ever I offered incense to him it was because there was no other deity at hand' (Letters 1: 225).

Expresses her qualified satisfaction with the review of Life of Jesus in the Prospective Review: 'The praise it gives to the translation is just what I should have wished' (Letters 1: 227; Cross 1: 150).
Discusses St Luke's account of the Emmaus Road in letter to Sara Hennell.
GE publishes 'Introductory', the first of five instalments of her 'Poetry and Prose from the Notebook of an Eccentric' appears in the Coventry Herald, owned by Charles Bray.
Thanks Sara Hennell for the opportunity of seeing her manuscript Heliados.
Over Christmas GE makes her final break with Maria Lewis, who is staying for a fortnight.
'How to Avoid Disappointment', the second instalment of 'Poetry and Prose from the Notebook of an Eccentric', appears in the Herald.
Third instalment of 'Poetry and Prose from the Notebook of an Eccentric', 'The Wisdom of a Child', appears in the Herald.
The Herald publishes the fourth instalment, 'A Little Fable with a Great Moral'.
The Herald publishes the final instalment, 'Hints on Snubbing'.
'Vice and Sausages', a satirical piece on the Coventry police inspector John Vice, appears in the Herald.

Tells Sara Hennell, 'Mr Chapman . . . was always too much of the interesting gentleman to please me. Men must not attempt to be interesting on any lower terms than a high poetical genius' (Letters 1: 231).
Begins five-day visit to London with Charles Bray.
Attends performance of Mendelssohn's Elijah at the Exeter Hall.
Sees Bellini's I Puritani at Her Majesty's Theatre.
Gives Mary Sibree an account of her London trip.

After rereading Charles Hennell's Inquiry, sends Sara Hennell a lengthy appreciation of the work: 'I think the Inquiry furnishes the utmost that can be done towards obtaining a real view of the life and character of Jesus by rejecting as little as possible from the Gospels'' (Letters 1: 237; Cross 1: 165).
Takes her father to the Isle of Wight to improve his health.
Sends the Brays a cheerful account of her Isle of Wight visit.
Takes her father to Brighton.
Returns from the Isle of Wight.
Describes Alum Bay and Brighton in letter to Sara Hennell. Reading Richardson's Sir Charles Grandison with enthusiasm.

Tells Sara Hennell of two new readers of Strauss – a Leamington lady (probably Caroline Congreve) and John Sibree, remarking, 'I confess to a fit of destructiveness just now which might have been more easily gratified if I had lived in the days of iconoclasm' (Letters 1: 241).
Sends lengthy letter, including discussion of Tancred and Judaism, to John Sibree, with whom she had begun to correspond late in 1847.
Death of Leonard Clarke, nephew (Chrissey's son), aged nine months.

Pleased to note John Sibree's agreement with her enthusiasm for the French revolution, also giving her own opinions on British reform: 'there is nothing in our Constitution to obstruct the slow progress of political reform. This is all we are fit for at present . . . we English are slow crawlers' (Letters 1: 252; Cross 1: 181).
Has tooth withdrawn after chloroform.
Delighted to hear of Sara Hennell's encounter with Emerson.
Worried by deterioration in her father's health.
Reports to Sara Hennell a decided improvement in her father's health.
Tells Fanny Houghton that their father's health is now sufficiently recovered for him to be able to contemplate a recuperative visit to the coast.
Takes her father to St Leonards, Sussex.
Tells the Brays that her father's health fared better on the journey down than her own did.

Writes to congratulate John Sibree on abandoning his training for the ministry: 'It was impossible to think of your career with hope, while you tacitly subscribed to the miserable etiquette . . . of sectarianism' (Letters 1: 261; Cross 1: 183).
Writes to the Brays and Hennells deploring the impeachment of the French revolutionary Louis Blanc, and angry because 'society is training men and women for hell' (Letters 1: 267; Cross 1: 190).
Reports decline in her father's health to Bray, recording also her disapproval of Jane Eyre.

Tells Sara Hennell, 'I am entering on a new period of my life, which makes me look back on the past as something incredibly poor and contemptible.' Comments also on the fall of the French Socialist party: 'Paris, poor Paris - alas! alas!' (Letters 1: 269-70; Cross 1: 190-91).

Introduced by the Brays to Emerson: 'the first man I have ever seen' (Letters 1: 270; Cross 1: 191). The party visit Stratford, Emerson becoming much impressed by GE: 'That young lady has a calm, serious soul' (Haight, p. 66). Also Letters 1: 271, note 7, details the date of Eliot's introduction to Emerson as Thursday, the day after Emerson arrived.
Cara Bray tells Sara Hennell that Robert Evans' s death appears imminent.

Writes to Sara Hennell, admiring Macaulay and Sand, and reporting, 'My body is the defaulter - consciously so. I triumph over all things in the spirit, but the flesh is weak, and disgraces itself by headaches and backaches' (Letters 1: 275). Tells her sister Fanny, 'We may satirise characters and qualities in the abstract without injury to our moral nature, but persons hardly ever' (Letters 1:  276).
Sends lengthy appreciation of Rousseau and Sand to Sara Hennell.
Begins to translate Spinoza's Tractatus theologico-politicus (the translation has not been found).
Review of J. A. Froude' s Nemesis of Faith appears in the Herald.
Froude congratulates GE on her review, with some affection.
Tells Sara Hennell of her admiration for Nemesis of Faith and recommends Froude's Shadows of the Clouds.
Reports her father much deteriorated in health.
Tells Elizabeth Pears that Robert Evans has remembered her with gratitude and affection, adding that 'my chair by father's bedside is a very blessed seat to me' (Letters 1: 275; Cross 1: 203).
Death of Robert Evans: 'What shall I be without my father? It will seem as if a part of my moral nature were gone' (Letters 1: 284; Cross 1: 205).
Requests Bray's advice and help.
Robert Evans buried at Chilvers Coton.
Meets J. A. Froude.
Leaves with the Brays for continental tour, visiting France, Italy and Switzerland, in which she eventually decides to winter. Begins her Journal.
The Brays return home, leaving GE at Geneva.
Sends Bray an account of her life in a pension owned by a Madame de Vallière.
Sends the Brays and Sara Hennell further details of her new environment, also asking them, 'Pray that the motto of Geneva may become mine - Post tenebras lux' (Letters 1: 295; Cross  1: 213).
Tells the Brays and Sara Hennell that she has not yet decided whether or not to spend the winter in Switzerland.

Informs the same correspondents that she has now decided on staying: 'I am really good for nothing yet, and I feel that my future health and actions entirely depend on my recovering thoroughly my strength and spirit' (Letters 1: 301).
Implores Fanny Houghton to write to her.
Asks the Brays to give her address only to friends as close as themselves.

Informs the Brays that she will return to England in the spring, also including details of her friendship with Madame de Ludwigsdorff. Reports that Charles Bray has remarked 'there is much that is morbid in your character . . . with a dwelling on yourself, and a longing to think of yourself unhappy' (Letters 1: 307).
Tells Fanny Houghton and the Brays that she has decided to lodge with F. D' Albert-Durade, a Genevan painter.
Moves to lodge with D' Albert.
Gives the Brays a favourable description of her new surroundings. Reports that she has had a letter from Mary Sibree: 'a good sweet girl, but her ideas want testing' (Letters 1: 315).

Enthuses about D' Albert in a letter to the Brays: 'I have not heard a word or seen a gesture of his yet that was not perfectly in harmony with an exquisite moral refinement' (Letters 1: 317; Cross 1: 233-4).
Tells Sara Hennell, 'I have always had a hankering after this sort of life, and I find it was a true instinct of what would suit me' (Letters 1: 321, 323; Cross 1: 237).

Tells the Brays that lack of health has obliged her to suspend work on the Spinoza translation, and confesses to Sara Hennell that she is becoming 'passionately attached' to her life in Geneva (Letters 1: 241).
Sends seasonal greetings to the Brays and Sara Hennell.
Urges the Brays to write to her.
Requests a letter from Fanny Houghton, who has not written for five months.
Thanks Fanny Houghton for her letter, and announces intention of returning to England in late March or early April.

Tells the Brays that D' Albert is painting her portrait, and that she is sitting for my portrait - at M. D'Albert's request - not mine (Letters 1: 330). Also attending church regularly:  'I go to the Genevese churches every Sunday, and nourish my heterodoxy with orthodox sermons' (Letters 1: 330).
Informs Bray that she may now leave Geneva as early as mid-March.
Accompanied by D' Albert, leaves Geneva for England.
Moves in with the Brays at Rosehill in Coventry (rather than moving in with any of her siblings and their families.)
Tells Fanny Houghton, 'I am sad at the sight of my own country, and feel more of an outcast here than at Geneva' (Letters 1: 333).
Tells Martha Jackson that her homecoming has been painful and that she is uncertain whether she will remain in England or return to Geneva.
Asks Sara Hennell to send details of the accommodation offered by Chapman, also remarking, 'Oh the dismal weather, and the dismal country, and the dismal people' (Letters 1: 334; Cross 1: 252).
Tells Cara Bray that although Chrissey has been kind to her, she is delighted to feel of no importance to the rest of the Evans family, and has no motive for living amongst them.
Begins an eight-day stay at Rosehill.
Entertains D' Albert at Rosehill for four days.
Makes Rosehill her base for the next six months.
Death of Charles Hennell (brother of Sara and Cara, husband of Rufa).
Delivers review of Progress of the Intellect to Chapman, lodging with him for two weeks, and deciding to make writing her career.
Meets Eliza Lynn Linton at Chapman’s. Tells the Brays that she has enjoyed her stay at Chapman' s and plans to visit him again in January.
Returns from London.
Returns to lodge and work with John Chapman at 142 Strand, to co-edit the Westminster Review.
Attends lecture by Faraday.
Dines at Mackay's with the Chapmans, Amott and Leslie.
Tells the Brays of her visits to lectures by Faraday and F. W. Newman.
Publishes first review of Letters on the Laws of Man’s Nature in the Leader.
Publishes second review of Letters on the Laws of Man’s Nature in the Leader.
Leaves Chapman, apparently because of friction with the other women in the Chapman household,  but continues to correspond with him. Returns to Rosehill.

Returns to Chapman letters from his wife reproving his conduct with GE, enclosing comments of her own. Agrees to continue to provide a catalogue raisonné of Chapman' s more important publications, though insisting that he make clear to his wife that the work is undertaken at his request.
Chapman receives letter from GE consenting to abridge Strauss for £100 (a project Chapman never pursued), and revealing that she is beginning to get greater enjoyment from work on the catalogue.
Chapman forwards to his wife a letter from GE, and hopes that GE and Susanna Chapman will now become better disposed towards each other.

Agrees to write an article on W. R. Greg's The Creed of Christendom and Charles Hennell's Inquiry for the Westminster. Sends Chapman an account of James Martineau's The Rationale of Religious Inquiry for inclusion in his catalogue.
Chapman arrives for a fortnight at Rosehill, proposing that GE should assist him in editing the Westminster.
Meets Thornton Leigh Hunt at Rosehill, where he stays the weekend.
Writes the prospectus for the Westminster.
GE and Chapman make a 'solemn and holy vow' to bind them to 'the right' (Chapman's diary, qutd. Haight 91).
Suggests to Chapman that he should give out that he employs an editor whilst himself retaining editorial responsibility.
Advises Chapman on how the proofs of the prospectus might have been circulated more diplomatically.
Gives Chapman further advice on attracting supporters for the Westminster.

Sends Chapman her verdict on several Westminster contributions, and advises against inviting Charlotte Brontë to write an article on modern novelists: 'She would have to leave out Currer Bell, who is perhaps the best of them all' (Letters 1: 355).
Agrees with Chapman's suggestion that GHL be invited to contribute an article on modern novelists.
Chapman discusses the Westminster prospectus with GE, visiting London in company with the Brays. Her introduction to Spencer also dates from this visit.
Chapman takes GE and Sara Hennell to the Great Exhibition.
GE returns to Rosehill, though still advising Chapman from a distance on Westminster plans.
Tells Mary Sibree, 'there are but two words of very vital significance for you and me and all mortals - Resignation and labour' (Letters 1: 359).
Meets the phrenologist George Combe at Rosehill, Combe noting in his journal GE' s extraordinary ability.
Advises Chapman that a translation of Comte's Cours de philosophie positive by W. M. W. Call will probably be more successful than one by Harriet Martineau.
Article on W. R. Greg's The Creed of Christendom appears in the Leader. Chapman and his wife begin a three-day stay at Rosehill.

Returns to lodge with Chapman, gathering contributions for the first number of the Westminster's new series, and enormously broadening her intellectual and social acquaintances. Involvement with Herbert Spencer begins to develop.
Sends Cara Bray news of her employment: 'I am training myself up to say adieu to all delights, I care for nothing but doing my work and doing it well' (Letters 1: 363).
Tells Charles Bray of her meeting with Herbert Spencer, whose Social Statics she recommends.
First, unimpressed, encounter with GHL: 'a sort of miniature Mirabeau in appearance' (Cross 1: 261; Letters 1: 367). [See Haight's note 2 for details of the visit to Jeff's Bookstore.]
Tells Charles Bray that the Swedish novelist Frederika Bremer, currently staying with Chapman, is extremely unprepossessing.
Repents of her attitude to Frederika Bremer in a letter to Sara Hennell.
Brings the Brays and Sara Hennell up to date with subscriptions to, and articles for, the Westminster. Tells them of the pleasure given to her by Carlyle' s Life of Sterling.
Sees The Merry Wives of Windsor with Spencer and Chapman. GHL in the same box.
Tells Cara Bray of GHL's witticisms on the Merry Wives performance.
Combe urges Chapman to use GE's judgement as an aid to his own.
Tells the Brays that pressure of work will regrettably prevent her from joining them for Christmas: 'It is the first Christmas day I shall have passed without any Christmas feeling' (Cross 1: 267).
Visited by H. G. Atkinson and Harriet Martineau - repulsed by the vulgarity of the latter's looks and gestures.  Has lengthy conversation with Pierre Leroux at a soirée.
Advises Charles Bray to read article on physiognomy in the Quarterly Review.
Sends birthday greetings to Charles Bray.
Attends party at Mackay's.
Tells the Brays of her pleasure in the company of Bessie Parkes, with whom her friendship develops this year. W. J. Fox visits in the evening.
Sara Hennell begins a nine-day visit to GE and Chapman.
Dines with Peter Taylor and his wife Clementia at Sydenham, Kent (now South London). Bessie Parkes visits and 'is very pretty in her attentions' (Letters 2: 11). ·
Tells Cara Bray that 'The thick of the work is just beginning' on the Westminster (Cross 1: 272).
Attends meeting of Association for the Abolition of Taxes on Knowledge, hearing Cobden, 'in whom I was woefully disappointed' (Cross 1: 272).
Visits a Miss Lynn to discuss lodgings, but subsequently considers it undesirable to fix on a London residence immediately.
Tells Clementia Taylor, 'until the end of March I fear I shall be a prisoner from the necessity for constant work' (Cross 1: 273).
Visits Cara Bray at Rosehill. Reports that she has been made joint trustee of fund for publication of Harriet Martineau' s translation of Comte.
Returns to London. Attends GHL's The Chain of Events with Spencer, reporting to Bray, 'It is a very long chain and drags rather heavily' (Letters 2: 18).
Herbert Spencer alarmed by GE's affection for him. Assures Sara Hennell of her lasting friendship: 'I love you more than ever, not less' (Letters 2: 19; Cross 1: 275).

Attends Donizetti's I Martiri at Covent Garden with Spencer, telling the Brays, 'We have agreed that we are not in love with each other, and that there is no reason why we should not have as much of each other's society as we like' (Letters 2: 22).
Attends brilliant soirée at Chapman's, with F. W. Newman, W.R. Greg, and Louis Blanc among the guests.
Dickens chairs meeting of Booksellers' Association at 142 Strand: 'He is not distinguished looking in any way', GE reports to the Brays (Letters 2: 23; Cross 1: 279).
Visits Clementia Taylor at Sydenham.
Dines with Andrew Johnson.

Attends Bellini's Norma at Covent Garden, probably with Spencer. Tells Cara Bray, 'My brightest spot next to my love of old friends, is the deliciously calm new friendship that Herbert Spencer gives me. We see each other every day and have a delightful camaraderie in everything' (Letters 2: 23; Cross 1: 281). Also describes the great impression which Millais' s The Huguenots on St Bartholomew's Day made on her.
Attends Anniversary Meeting of the Charity Schools at St Paul's Cathedral.

Replies to joint invitation to herself and Spencer to visit Rosehill: 'We certainly could not go together, for all the world is setting us down as engaged' (Letters 2: 35). Congratulates Bessie Parkes on her twenty-third birthday.
Visits Joseph Parkes.
Spencer brings his father to visit GE.
Visits Kew Gardens with Spencer.
Mary Smith visits GE with Florence Nightingale, Hilary Bonham Carter and Mary Mohl.
Tells George Combe that she does not wish to employ the critic Ebenezer Syme again.
Travels to Chandos Cottage, Broadstairs, Kent.
Tells Cara Bray, 'I am thinking whether it would not be wise to retire from the world and live here for the rest of my days' (Letters 2: 42; Cross 1: 285).
Sends Spencer her opinion on Tennyson's In Memoriam (Letters 8: 53).
Tells Charles Bray that she is obliged to write hurriedly, since she is not alone, a possible indication that Spencer was visiting her (Letters 2: 42).
Urges Bessie Parkes to publish her poems. Receives note from Florence Nightingale, and remarks that 'There is a loftiness of mind about her' (Letters 2: 44-5; Cross 1: 285).

Reports herself to Charles Bray as 'Picking up shells (not in the Newtonian sense, but literally); reading Aristotle to find out what is the chief good; and eating mutton chops, that I may have strength to pursue it' (Letters 2: 46; Cross 1: 286).
Writes to Chapman discussing articles and editorial policy for the Westminster.
The Brays join GE at Broadstairs.
Charles Bray returns home.
Cara Bray leaves Broadstairs.
Returns to London from Broadstairs, Kent, with a violent headache and sickness (Letters 2: 53, n 6)
Tells Cara Bray that the articles for the October edition of the Westminster are 'on the whole unsatisfactory' (Letters 2: 55; Cross 1: 290).
Writes to Charles Bray recounting conversation with GHL on phrenology.
Reports herself to Sara Hennell better satisfied with the final appearance of the October Westminster.
Travels to Edinburgh to stay with George Combe.
Robert Cox, editor of the Phrenological Journal, visits GE.
Tells the Brays, 'The Combes are all kindness, and I am in clover - an elegant house, glorious fires, and a comfortable carriage' (Letters  2: 59; Cross 1: 292).
Visits Craigcrook, summer home of Francis Jeffrey.
Arrives to stay with Harriet Martineau at Ambleside in the Lake District.
Visits workmen's cottages with Harriet Martineau in connection with Martineau's Co-operative Building Society.
Visits Borrowdale.
Leaves Ambleside for Rosehill.
Harriet Martineau tells Chapman of her pleasure at GE' s visit.
Tells Bessie Parkes that she has had 'a delightful month --nothing but petting and admiration, beautiful scenery and agreeable talks' (Letters 2: 64).
Charles Bray writes to George Combe of GE: 'Her manners are much improved since she went into the world: they were tinged with a slight degree of affectation' (Haight, p. 124).
Returns to London from Rosehill. Visited by Spencer.

Describes her day's work to the Brays: 'My task was to read an article of Greg's in the North British on Taxation, a heap of newspaper articles, and all that J. S. Mill says on the same subject' (Letters 2: 68; Cross 1: 297). Visited by GHL.
Sends birthday greetings to Sara Hennell.
Attends annual meeting of the Association for the Repeal of the Taxes on Knowledge at Exeter Hall.
Travels to Coventry to spend two days with the Brays.
Sends autograph letter of Mazzini's to W. F. Watson for his collection.
Hears news of her brother-in-law Edward Clarke's serious illness. Clarke dies the same day.
Tells George Combe that she is painfully preoccupied by Clarke's death.
Travels to Rosehill, to stay with the Brays prior to travelling to Meriden.
Attends Edward Clarke's funeral.
Spend Christmas with her sister at Meriden, telling the Brays that 'Chrissey bears her trouble much better than I expected' (Letters 2: 74; Cross 1: 300).
Returns to London.
Tells Charles Bray that she is utterly dejected.
GE begs Sara Hennell not to 'lay the sins of the article on the Atomic Theory to poor Lewes's charge'. She herself disapproved of the article, which was by Samuel Brown (Letters 2: 80; Cross 1: 302).
Tells Charles Bray, 'You are a fine fellow to talk of supporting the Westminster - for my sake too . . . The only thing you can do for my sake is to prosper' (Letters 2: 81).
Writes to Charles Bray, 'Heaven help us! - said the old religion; the new one, from its very lack of that faith, will teach us all the more to help one another' (Letters 2: 82; Cross 1: 302).
Tells Bray that she has determined to leave Chapman's house.
Corrects Charles Bray's mistake of supposing that she dictates Chapman's Letters and praises Chapman's industry. Doctor summoned to treat her rheumatism.
Reports herself to the Brays in frightful pain.
Rheumatism improved.

Gives Clementia Taylor her opinion on Gaskell's Ruth: 'How women have the courage to write and publishers the spirit to buy at a high price the false and feeble representations of life and character that most feminine novels give, is a constant marvel to me. Ruth, with all its merits, will not be an enduring or classical fiction . . . [Gaskell] is not contented with the subdued colouring - the half tints of real life' (Letters 2: 86; Cross 1: 304- 5).
Charles Bray collects GE and takes her to Rosehill to convalesce.
Returns from Rosehill to London. Bessie Parkes tells Barbara Smith that GE has made up her mind to love her (i.e. Bessie Parkes).
Tells the Brays that she is dissatisfied with the Westminster: 'I should be glad to run away from it altogether' (Letters 2: 88; Cross 1: 301).
Spends the evening with Huxley and Masson.
Dines with Bessie Parkes.
Tells the Brays that the next issue of the Westminster will be a particularly good one.
Reports her disappointment with the next issue of the Westminster, not least with GHL's contribution, but has clearly postponed her resignation from the Westminster.
Spends all day correcting proofs, though satisfied that the issue will be better than she once feared.
Enjoys a pleasant soirée at Chapman's, telling Sara Hennell that GHL 'has quite won my liking, in spite of myself' (Letters 2: 94; Cross 1: 307).
Visits Clementia Taylor at Syndenham. Tells the Brays that GHL 'has been quite a pleasant friend to me lately' (Letters 2: 97).
Enjoys 'an agreeable soirée. . . I fell in love with Helen Faucit' (Letters 2: 98; Cross 1: 308).

Sees Rossini's William Tell. Tells Cara Bray that GHL 'has quite won my regard . . . Like a few other people in the world he is much better than he seems . . . A man of heart and conscience wearing a mask of flippancy' (Letters 2: 98; Cross 1: 308).
Visits the Brays at Rosehill.
Tells Chapman that he may add her 'Idea of a Future Life' (never completed) to his list.
Returns to London.
Forced to decline article by Foxton for the July Westminster.
Dines with the Combes at the house of Dr Abram Cox in Kingston, Surrey.
Sees Adrienne Lecouvreur by Scribe and Legouve with GHL.
Dines with Sir James Clark together with the Combes and Neil Arnott.
Meets Caroline Cornwallis, a prodigy of languages.
Advertisement appears in the Leader anticipating The Idea of a Future Life by ‘the Translator of Strauss' s Life of Jesus’.
Visits the Combes.
Invites Sara Hennell to visit her so that they may both call on Bessie Parkes in Ockley, Surrey.
Visits Bessie Parkes, the party including Chapman, Sara Hennell and Barbara Smith.
Declines an invitation from George and Cecilia Combe to spend the summer with them in Switzerland.
Writes to Bessie Parkes, expressing distaste at new edition of Mary Hume's The Bridesmaid, Count Stephen, and Other Poems, but pleasure at Bessie Parkes's own verse-letters.
Continues her holiday by travelling to Tunbridge Wells, Kent.
Considers moving on to Hastings or St Leonards.
Tells Cara Bray: 'I never felt the delight of the thorough change that the coast gives one so much as now' (Letters 2: 111; Cross 1: 309).
Tells Cara Bray that she is 'being regenerated by baptism and--beer drinking! This latter sacrament I . . . find . . . very efficacious' (Letters 2: 113).
Visits Hyde Park to look for new lodgings.
Fire destroys the presses and composing room of Savill and Edwards, printers of the Westminster.
Decides to take lodgings at 21 Cambridge Street. Her move here may mark the beginning of her formal relationship with GHL.
Begins a fortnight's stay with the Brays at Rosehill.
Herbert Spencer arrives at Rosehill.
Leaves Rosehill for London, where she commences residence at 21 Cambridge Street.
Reports to Cara Bray, 'I like my lodgings . . . and I have not one disagreeable to complain of at present' (Letters 2: 119).
Sends Combe her comments on his Relation of Religion to Science.
Visited by Harriet Martineau.
Again visited by Harriet Martineau.
Learns of the illness of her sister Fanny.
Visited by R. W. Mackay.
Meets Neil Arnott and John Elliotson at an evening party at Mackay's.
Harriet Martineau's translation of The Positive Philosophy of Auguste Comte appears in Chapman's Quarterly Review.
Tells Chapman that she wishes to give up any connection with the editorship of the Westminster.
Responds to Sara Hennell's birthday greetings: 'I begin this year more happily than I have done most years of my life' (Letters 2: 127; Cross 1: 317).
Compliments Bessie Parkes on her Summer Sketches and Other Poems. Gives Combe a two sided estimation of Huxley's reputation.
Reports 10 days of stomach complaints. Writes to Chapman requesting a guarantee of texts for, and the publication of, Feuerbach's Das Wesen der Christentums (The Essence of Christianity).
Begs Chapman to withhold Huxley's contemptuous article against GHL from the Westminster.
Unsuccessfully advises Chapman to drop Huxley's ‘Science’ article completely.
Tells Combe that her reason for withdrawing from the Westminster is Chapman's financial difficulties.
Spends Christmas Day alone at Cambridge Street.
Dines with Arthur Helps at Sir James Clark's: 'very snug--only he and myself' (Letters 2: 135; Cross I: 319).
Begins visit to Chrissey at Meriden.
Travels to Rosehill to stay with the Brays.
Returns to London.
Thanks Sara Hennell for agreeing to criticise the Essence.
Declines invitation to attend a dance organised by Bessie Parkes's mother, fearing 'to appear like a withered cabbage in a flower garden' Letters  2: 138).
Requests Charles Bray to send a copy of an article by Thomas Guthrie on the importance of the Bible in children's moral education.
Thanks Sara Hennell for correcting the manuscript of the Essence.
Thanks Bessie Parkes for bringing a number of Barbara Smith's paintings.
Combe tells Chapman that GE had told him that her connection with the Westminster had terminated on 1 January.
Discusses points of typography for the Essence with Sara Hennell, also telling her, 'I like my independent life in lodgings better and better' (Letters 2: 145).
Begins to send manuscript of the Essence to printers.
Declares herself out of 'a labyrinth of headaches and palpitations' but predicts herself 'deep in proof sheets till the end of May' (Letters 2: 148-49)
Considers writing the 'Belles Lettres' section in future editions of the Westminster to compensate for the poor financial return for the Essence translation.
GHL taken severely ill. GE takes over his work for the Leader.
Tells Sara Hennell, 'I have been almost constantly ill for the last ten days . . . I am too entirely without hope about the book' (Letters 2: 152).
Urgently begs Sara Hennell's criticism of the appendix of the Essence.
Views the French exhibition at the Pall Mall Gallery; is much impressed by Scheffer's painting of Francesca da Rimini.
Visits the Royal Academy exhibition.

Writes to Cara Bray expressing her admiration for Holman Hunt's The Light of the World and Ruskin's attendant correspondence in The Times. Writes of emotional troubles, stating 'When we are young we think our troubles a mighty business…But we begin at last to understand that these things are important only to our own consciousness, which is but as a globule of dew on a rose-leaf, that at mid-day there will be no trace of.'
Visited by Charles Bray.
'Finally decided not to live with the Chapmans . . . I may wish to go to the continent. At all events, I like to feel free' (Letters 2: 158).
Complains to Sara Hennell of slowness and inaccuracies with the Essence proofs.
Apologises to Cara Bray for being unable to visit Rosehill before Midsummer.
Refuses to visit the Combes.
Queen Victoria opens the Crystal Palace at Sydenham.
Visited by Charles Bray and William Smith. Discusses with Bray her relationship with GHL.
Finds further inaccuracies in the Essence proofs.
Goes to stay with the Brays at Rosehill, her last visit there.
Advertisements appear for the Essence translation to be ready 'in a few days.'
GHL refuses the Brays' invitation to Coventry.
Returns to London.
Visited by George Combe.
Spends evening at Chapman's.
Advises Cara Bray to 'consider the Strauss mss. waste paper' (Cross 1: 324).
Review in the Coventry Herald by Sara Hennell lavishly praises the Essence translation.
Visits the Crystal Palace at Sydenham.
Clears financial arrangements with Chapman prior to going abroad.
Writes to the Brays and Sara Hennell, 'I have only time to say good-bye, and God bless you. Poste restante, Weimar, for the next six weeks' (Cross 1: 325).

GE and GHL leave London together for Weimar, travelling via Antwerp, Brussels, Namur, Liège, Cologne, Mainz and Frankfurt. Records in Journal, 'The day was glorious and our passage perfect' (Journals 14; qutd. Cross 1: 332).
Leave Antwerp for Brussels, where they stay until July 27, leaving for Namur and Liège.
Wander round Liège in 'a state of rapture' (Journals 17; qutd. Haight 150).
Leave Liège for Cologne

Dr Brabant (a chance encounter en route to Cologne) brings Strauss ('a man for whom life has lost all charms') to visit GE and GHL for breakfast at the public rooms of the Hotel de Hollande in Cologne (Journals 18; cf. Haight 151).
Arrive via Coblenz and Mainz in Frankfurt.
Visit the Goethe house, Judengasse, and Staedelmuseum in Frankfurt.
Arrive in Weimar, where they take lodgings for 3 month, until November 3. For an extensive list of reading during subsequent months, and GE's comments on this reading, see Cross 1: 374-7.
Receives letter from Chapman proposing that she write an article on Victor Cousin's Madame de Sablé. The Spectator reviews the Essence translation favourably.
Describes her meeting with Strauss in letter to Chapman.

GE and GHL dine with Liszt at the Altenburg. The company includes Raff, Schade, Cornelius, the Princess Carolyne zu Sayn-Wittgenstein and several others. Liszt plays: 'For the first time in my life I beheld real inspiration' (Journals 21; qutd. by Cross 1: 347). Acquaintance with German opera partly stimulated by numerous meetings with Liszt at this time.
Tells Charles Bray, 'I have had a month of exquisite enjoyment, and seem to have begun life afresh' (Letters 2: 170). Dines with Liszt.
GE and GHL visit Schiller's house. 'Stupidity of people tricking out and altering such a place instead of letting one see it as he saw it and lived in it' (Journals 23).
GE and GHL visit Goethe's House for the first time.
Arthur Helps passes through Weimar, visiting GHL and GE.
Tells Chapman of her extreme happiness.
Sends Chapman her article on Cousin's Madame de Sablé.
GE and GHL go to see their first opera at the Weimar theater, Verdi's Ernani.
Liszt comes to dinner and introduces M. Rubinstein.
Sees Gustav Freytag's Journalisten at the Weimar theater.
Sees Wagner's Tannhäuser with a Mr. Marshall who has come to visit.
Asks Chapman to forward a copy of the article on Madame de Sable for Liszt to read.

Bray tells Chapman: 'Nothing that I have yet heard or know will make any difference in my conduct towards her' [i.e. GE] (Letters 8: 123). Malicious rumours about the GE-GHL relationship begin to circulate in London.
Records in diary that a “painful letter from London caused [GE and GHL] both a bad night.”
GHL writes to Carlyle and Helps defending his position with regard to GE and his family in London.  (Journals, 27, Haight 160)

Writes to Chapman, 'I have counted the cost of the step that I have taken . . . I am not mistaken in the person to whom I have attached myself. He is worthy of the sacrifice I have incurred, and my only anxiety is that he should be rightly judged' (Letters 8: 124-5). Sees Wagner's Flying Dutchman (Der Fliegende Holländer)
Chapman tells Robert Chambers that GHL is not alone to blame.
GHL receives a letter of generous sympathy from Carlyle in respect of his elopement with GE.
A letter from Bray 'occupied us [GE and GHL] painfully' in the morning (Journals 28). Sees Acts 1 and 2 of Wagner's Lohengrin.
Hears Clara Schumann play; meets her again on October 28: 'a melancholy, interesting looking creature. Her husband went mad a year ago, and she has to support 8 children!' (Journals 29).
Publication in the Leader of 'The Romantic School of Music,' an abridged translation by GE of an article by Liszt on Wagner and Meyerbeer.
GE writes to Sara Hennell to attempt to clear up misunderstandings caused by the Lewes affair. Relations with Rosehill, however, never completely restored.

Leave Weimar for Berlin, where they also encounter a large cross-section of the artistic intelligentsia. (For GE's recollections, see Recollections of Berlin,' Journals 243-258; Cross 1: 349--64, 367-73.)
Combe wonders if there has been insanity in GE's family, and tells Charles Bray that GE, GHL and Thornton Hunt have inflicted a great injury on the cause of religious freedom.
Begins to translate Spinoza's Ethics. Read Wilhelm Meister and The Merchant of Venice to each other in the evenings.
Tells Charles Bray that she cannot think two humans could be happier than GHL and herself.

Visit German philosopher and classicist Otto Friedrich Gruppe at his family home. Note: They were introduced Nov 13; at a dinner Dec 18 GE is 'amused' at Gruppe's wife's anti-Semitism when GHL performs Shylock's monologue [Journals 39]).
Completes draft of 'Three Months in Weimar', subsequently to appear in Fraser's Magazine.
Tells Chapman that Berlin life is eminently agreeable, and that they are both reading substantial amounts.

Meets Adolf Stahr (scholar of antiquity) and Fanny Lewald (German-Jewish novelist) (Journals 36). She has read her novel Wandlungen in prior weeks and begins reading his study Torso on December 31 (review appears in the Leader on March 6, 1855)
Christmas morning. Miserably wet (Journals 40). Note GE and GHL are in their Berlin lodge, no mention of outings or celebration.
Visit the sculptor Christian Daniel Rauch in his studio. First-ever visito to a sculptor's studio, with the 70-something artist 'superintending the modeling of a statue' (Journals 41).
Hear Gluck's Orpheus and Eurydice (later appears in Armgart)
Writes to Chapman with an idea for an article on 'Woman in Germany’. Hear Beethoven's Fidelio.
Agrees to write on Vehse's multi-volume Memoirs of the Court of Austria, which she starts reading Jan 23, finishing around Feb 2.
First visit to the Neue Museum, including the sculptures from the Altar of Zeus at Pergamon. The museum is 'on a grand scale, worthy of a great nation and shames the British Museum' (Journals 45).
Sees Richard III.
Completes 'Memoirs of the Court of Austria', a review of Vehse, for the Westminster.

GE and GHL leave Berlin for England, breaking the journey at Cologne and Brussels, and enjoying in the latter a chance encounter with Berlioz (Monday, Mar 12). Arrive in Dover's Lord Warden Hotel on Tuesday, Mar 13.

Takes lodgings at 1 Sydney Place, Dover, while GHL continues to London to procure a separation agreement with Agnes. Resumes work on Spinoza's Ethics and begins to reread much of Shakespeare, including Two Gentlemen of Verona, Venus and Adonis, Romeo and Juliet, The Tempest, and the sonnets, throughout March.
GE's article 'The Art of the Ancients' appears in the Leader.
Writes to Chapman to offer her sympathy over his serious lung disease.
Invited by Chapman to undertake the 'Belles Lettres' section of the Westminster. Celebrates with a walk over the hills.
Writes to Charles Bray to discuss her financial affairs.
'Painful letter [presumed to be about Lewes's separation agreement with his wife, Agnes] which upset me for work' (Journals 56).
'Walked feeling much depression against which I struggled hard' (Journals 56).
Arrives in London to live with GHL. Move into temporary lodgings at 8 Victoria Grove Terrace, Bayswater.
Decide on 7 Clarence Row, East Sheen, Surrey, as a permanent residence.
Visits the British Museum.
Chapman visits GE to invite GHL to write on teetotalism for the Westminster. GE accepts on his behalf.
Completes article 'Three Months in Weimar' for Fraser's Magazine. Visited by Rufa Hennell.
Writes to Chapman discussing future articles on Kingsley and Dr Cumming.
Visited by Bessie Parkes.
Move to 7 Clarence Row, East Sheen. GE arranges to have correspondence forwarded in GHL's name. They at first attract few visitors.
Requests Charles Bray to lend his volumes of Scott for an article for Fraser's Magazine. (The article never appeared.)
Completes article on Kingsley's Westward Ho!
Describes her article 'Three Months in Weimar' to Charles Bray.
Article on Westward Ho! appears in the Leader.

'Sent article on Liszt, Wagner and Weimar to Fraser'; Tuesday, June 12, 'Sent article on Menander for the Leader' (Journals 56) (Three Months in Weimar published both in Fraser's and in the Leader, June 1855).
Mention of book II of the Iliad is representative of a course of reading in Greek undertaken in this and the following two years. For details of other reading this month see Cross 1: 382.
Supplement to the Leader includes GE's 'Menander and the Greek Comedy' and GHL's 'The Memoirs of Sydney Smith'.
Writes to Charles Bray, 'we like East Sheen better and better and are happier every day, walking hard, reading Homer and science and rearing tadpoles' (Letters 2: 202).
Chapman comes to dinner, bringing his article 'The Position of Woman' (Journals 57).
Writes to Chapman offering a detailed critique of his article.
Reassures Chapman of the article's worth.
'Lord Brougham's Literature' appears in the Leader.
Finished Articles on Wilhelm Meister and on Gruppe for the Leader.
Charles Bray visits and enters into a heated argument on phrenology.
Writes to Charles Bray defending GHL's article on J. S. Buckingham in the Leader.
'The Morality of Wilhelm Meister' appears in the Leader. Reading Keightley's Life of Milton prior to reviewing it for the Leader.
GHL ill with toothache. GE reads to him from Scott.
'The Future of German Philosophy' appears in the Leader.
Review of Keightley's Life of Milton (largely concerned with Milton's view of divorce) appears in the Leader, three days after it was completed (on Aug 1).
Carlyle reads proof of GHL's Goethe.
Completes an article on Sain Marc Giardin for the Leader.
Completes article on Cumming for the Westminster Review.
'Love in the Drama' published in the Leader.
Completes article on Hein for the Leader.
'Heine's poems' appears in the Leader.

Sends Cara Bray an earnest and lengthy defence of her relationship with GHL: 'If there is any one action or relation of my life which is and always has been profoundly serious, it is my relation to Mr Lewes' (Letters 2: 213; Cross 1: 327). Correspondence between the pair subsequently resumed.
'Michelet on the Reformation' published in the Leader.
Leave for two weeks in Worthing, Sussex, with lodgings at 21 Steyne.
'German Mythology and Legend' appears in the Leader.
'Long walk on the beach; but not a mollusc to be seen' (Journals 57). Note: this is the first mention of sea-creatures, many months before the May 1856 Ilfracombe science trip.
Move to 8 Park Shot, Richmond, Surrey.
Finishes article on Margaret Fuller and Mary Wollstonecraft.
“Margaret Fuller and Mary Wollstonecraft” published in the Leader.
Finishes article on Carlyle for the Leader.
Working on the 'Belles Lettres' section of the Westminster, including Browning's Men and Women, Longfellow's Hiawatha and Thoreau's Walden. Receives two letters from Princess Wittgenstein.
Reading Gall's Anatomie et physiologie du cerveau, and Carpenter's Comparative Physiology.
'Translations and Translators' published in the Leader.
'Thomas Carlyle' appears in the Leader.
Publication of GHL's Life of Goethe.
GE's review of GHL's Life of Goethe appears in the Leader.
Affected by a severe cold.
Sufficiently recovered to leave the house for the first time in two weeks.
Completes 'German Wit: Heinrich Heine' for the Westminster (Journals 58).
Finishes and sends off article on Belles Lettres (Journals 58)
Forwards letter sent to her from Herbert Spencer to Sara Hennell.
Travels to Attleborough to spend Christmas with Chrissey. GHL spends Christmas at the home of Arthur Helps. (Cross 1: 224)
Returns to Richmond.
Finishes review of Meredith's Shaving of Shagpat for the Leader.
'German Wit: Heinrich Heine' appears in the Westminster, along with her 'Belles Lettres' section.
Sends New Year greetings to Charles Bray. Continues to work on reviews of books by Meredith and Julia Kavanagh and a translation of von Bohlen' s Introduction to the Book of Genesis.
Reviews of The Shaving of Shagpat (highly favourable) and of Julia Kavanagh's Rachel Gray appear in the Leader.
'Introduction to Genesis' appears in the Leader.
Barbara Smith sends GE a petition in favour of rights of women to their earnings (Journals 58). Records the sale of 1000 copies of GHL's Goethe.
Gives qualified praise to the proposed legal reforms for women as helping to raise their position and character.
'History of German Protestantism' appears in the Leader.

Completes her translation of Spinoza's Ethics - never published, owing to GHL's dispute with the publisher. Declares herself in happy ignorance of the Spectator's views on emancipation. Reading the third volume of Ruskin's Modern Painters and Thomas Rymer Jones's General Outline of the Animal Kingdom.
GHL's damning review of Alison's History of Europe appears in the Saturday Review.
Tells Sara Hennell of her sympathy for Harriet Martineau's heart condition.
Reminds Sara Hennell of the importance of being called 'Mrs Lewes' by visitors.
'The Poets and Poetry of America' appears in the Leader.
GHL asks Spencer to refer to GE as Mrs Lewes.
Finishes article on Torso for the Saturday Review
Tells Charles Bray that her 'pen is not of the true literary order which will run along without the help of brains' (Cross 1: 393).
'The Antigone and its Moral' appears in the Leader.
Tells Charles Bray of plans to take GHL' s sons to Germany for the summer. (Letters 2: 234). Congratulates Bessie Parkes on her children's story The History of our Cat Aspasia (Letters 2: 235).

Contributes 'Art' and 'Belles Lettres' sections to the Westminster: Modern Painters, Ruskin v. III review; ; also in this column, reviews Walt Whitman's Leaves of Grass, the first positive review of the work in Britain.
Asks Charles Bray if John Sibree would consider tutoring GHL's sons. 'A delicious day! We are going to have a holiday at the Zoological Gardens' (1, 395).
Chapman accepts GE's idea for an article on Young. 'Church History of the Nineteenth Century' appears in the Leader.

Resolve to send GHL's sons to school in Switzerland. 'Keeping Sabbath in Mr Bray's fashion - enjoying the sunshine and reading the newspapers' (Letters 2: 237). Cross remarks, 'The next few weeks are, perhaps, the most signally important and interesting of all in George Eliot's development. There are unmistakable signs of the rising of the sap of creative production' (Cross 1: 395-6).
'The Court of Austria' published in the Leader.
Visited for the day by Herbert Spencer.
'Who Wrote the Waverley Novels?' published in the Leader.
Commences 'Worldliness and Other-Worldliness: The Poet Young'.
'Heine' s Book of Songs' appears in the Saturday Review, and 'Story of a Blue-Bottle' in the Leader.
Begins reading Riehl's Land und Volk.
Set out for Ilfracombe, Devon, via Bristol, staying at Exeter overnight.

Visit Exeter Cathedral. Take lodgings at Runnymede Villa, Ilfracombe. For GE's recollections of this holiday, see Cross I: 396-406 and Journals, 359-273 . Idea of 'Barton' conceived on this trip: 'One morning as I was thinking what should be the subject of my first story, my thoughts merged themselves into a dreamy doze, and I imagined myself writing a story, of which the title was 'The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton' (Cross 1: 415). GE and GHL undertake many maritime zoology explorations, since GHL involved with preparation for his Sea-Side Studies.
'Pictures of Life in French Novels' appears in the Saturday Review, and 'Margaret Fuller's Letters from Italy' in the Leader.
'The Art and Artists of Greece' appears in the Saturday Review.
Finishes and sends off article on Riehl, 'The Natural History of German Life.'
Tells Charles Bray, 'between work and zoology and bodily ailments my time has been full to overflowing' (Letters 2, 252; Cross 1: 406).
“Transatlantic Latter-Day Poetry,”including a second notice of Walt Whitman’s Leaves of Grass, appears in the Leader.
Bohn expresses to GHL his doubts about publishing GE' s translation of Spinoza's Ethics.
Tells Barbara Smith that she considers Ruskin the finest writer living.
Take the steamer for Swansea in South Wales, continuing by rail to Tenby.
Writes to Sara Hennell with reminiscences of their visit to Tenby 12 years previously.
Sends Chapman her favourable comments on the latest issue of the Westminster.
Joined at Tenby for five days by Barbara Smith.
'A Tragic Story' appears in the Leader. Discusses an idea for an article on 'Silly Women's Novels' with GHL, intending it to be an article of wholesome truth as well as some humour.

Repeats the 'Silly Women's Novels' idea to Chapman (Letters 2: 258). Records in Journal, 'I have done no visible work. But I have absorbed many ideas and much bodily strength; indeed I do not remember ever feeling so strong in mind and body as I feel at this moment' (Cross 1: 411).
Joined at Tenby by Edward Pigott.
'The Lover's Seat' appears in the Leader.
Tells Charles Bray, 'I never think what I write is good for anything till other people tell me so' (Letters 2: 260; Cross 1: 412).
Leave Tenby, spending the night at Bath.
Return to Richmond after 3 months of traveling. 'Enjoyed the sense of being at home again' (Journals 63)
'Ferny Combes' published in the Leader.
'Recollections of Heine' appears in the Leader.
GHL leaves for Hofwyl, in Switzerland, with his sons Charles and Thornton.
'Felice Orsini' appears in the Leader. GE 'chloroformed twice, and at last ... the tooth was got out' (Letters 2: 261).
GHL returns from Hofwyl.
Remarks to Sara Hennell how revealing writing may be: 'We mortals have such a knack of shutting up our best selves quite away from each other' (Letters 2: 263).
'Sight-seeing in Germany and the Tyrol' appears in the Saturday Review.
Despatches [sic] 'Silly Novels by Lady Novelists' to Chapman.
Reading Sophocles's Ajax.
Commences writing 'Barton,' which she is already hoping 'to make one of a series called Scenes of Clerical Life' (Journals 63) .
Offers Sara Hennell her criticisms of the latter's Christianity and Infidelity.
Congratulates Sara Hennell on her revision of Christianity and Infidelity.
Offers GHL's criticisms of Christianity and Infidelity to Sara Hennell. Finishes writing 'Barton'.
GHL sends Blackwood the manuscript of 'Barton', proposing a series of clerical tales.
Discusses the meaning of 'Islam', and natural theology, in letter to Sara Hennell.

Blackwood tells GHL, 'I am happy to say that I think your friend's reminiscences of Clerical Life will do. . .. If the author is a new writer, I beg to congratulate him on being worthy of the honours of print and pay' (Letters 2: 272; Cross 1: 419-20).
GHL tells Blackwood that his 'clerical friend' is 'somewhat discouraged' by Blackwood's previous letter, but will continue the sketches when other work allows (Letters 2: 273-74; Cross 1: 421).

Blackwood assures GHL of his admiration for 'Barton' and offers to 'publish it without seeing more' (Letters 1: 422). Barbara Smith (with Bessie Rayner Parkes) visit, Smith about to leave for Algiers (Journals 64)
GHL tells Blackwood of the restored confidence of his unusually sensitive friend, who would like to see 'Barton' published in January 1857 as the first of the 'Scenes of Clerical Life.'
Writes to Sara Hennell of the difficulty of repenting past errors, and warmly recommending E. B. Browning's Aurora Leigh.
'Worldliness and Other-Worldliness: The Poet Young' sent to Chapman.
Sends Sara Hennell copies of letters by Varnhagen and Ary Scheffer.
GHL deflects a challenge from Thornton Leigh Hunt, father of four children by Agnes, GHL's wife (Haight's contention, per Thomas Carlyle's comments).
Sends an autograph of Arthur Helps to Sara Hennell and looks forward to having a week of quiet solitude.
GHL sends a paper on anemones to Blackwood and receives the proofs of 'Barton'.
GHL travels to Vernon Hill, Hampshire, to spend Christmas with Arthur Helps (a traditional visit).
GE alone for Christmas again. Commences 'Mr Gilfil' s Love Story'.

Blackwood sends GHL the January Blackwood's containing 'Barton': 'It is a long time since I have read anything so fresh, so humorous, and so touching' (Cross 1: 425). Also encloses a cheque for 50 guineas.
First instalment of 'Barton' appears in Blackwood's.
Sends Sara Hennell New Year's greetings and suggests Groombridge as a publisher for her work.
Writes to Blackwood as the author of 'Barton' expressing her appreciation of his efforts.
GHL returns to Richmond.
Chapman offers GE a more generous rate of pay for her articles.
Finishes ch. 2 of 'Gilfil'.
Herbert Spencer to dinner.
Writes to Sara Hennell offering to make an exception by reviewing her Christianity and Infidelity for the Leader, or offering GHL as an alternative reviewer.
Blackwood sends GE ('My dear Amos') a copy of the February Blackwood's, containing the conclusion of 'Barton'. Blackwood notes Thackeray' s approval.

Adopts the pseudonym George Eliot in a letter to Major William Blackwood. Cross remarks, 'I may mention here that my wife told me the reason she fixed on this name was that George was Mr Lewes's Christian name, and Eliot was a good mouth-filling, easily-pronounced word' (Cross 1: 431).
Blackwood tells GE of 'Barton's' public acclaim.
GHL sends Blackwood the first instalment of 'Gilfil'.
Blackwood tells GHL that he has read the first instalment of 'Gilfil' with delight.
Reading Oedipus Rex, part of a continuing course of study of Greek drama.
Blackwood sends GE proofs of the first instalment of 'Gilfil', suggesting modifications in Caterina's character.

Thanks Blackwood for his suggestions, but remarks, 'I am unable to alter anything in relation to the delineation or development of character, as my stories always grow out of my psychological conception of the dramatis personae' (Letters  2: 299; Cross 1: 431).
Blackwood confides to GHL his suspicion that 'Gilfil' will be even more popular than 'Barton'.
Sends Blackwood the second instalment of 'Gilfil', informing him that the story has grown longer than she expected.
Blackwood sends a cheque for £21 for the first instalment of 'Gilfil' together with the proofs of the second instalment.
Finishes third instalment of 'Gilfil' and receives check from Blackwood for Part I. GHL' s review of Sara Hennell's Christianity and Infidelity appears in the Leader.
First instalment of 'Gilfil' appears in Blackwood's. Sends Blackwood the proofs of second instalment and manuscript of third instalment.
Sends Sara Hennell her full appraisal of Christianity and Infidelity.
GHL writes to Blackwood to confirm the financial arrangements for second and third instalments of 'Gilfil'.
Blackwood expresses his delight with the proof of the third instalment of 'Gilfil', though querying the necessity of Caterina's dagger .
Writes to Blackwood refusing to let Caterina only dream of taking the dagger, and insisting on maintaining her pseudonym.

Set out for the Scilly Isles and Jersey (until late July) to continue research for GHL's Seaside Studies. Reading on this holiday includes most of Austen, and novels by Gaskell, Charlotte Brontë and Hawthorne. (For general recollections of the trip see Cross 1: 436-9 and 444-8 and Journals 274-82)
GHL tells Blackwood that the Scillys are enchanting, and should be conducive to good writing.
Tells Sara Hennell of the zoological pleasures of the Scillys, also lamenting the recent death of her niece Frances.
Finishes 'Gilfil'.
Begins reading Gaskell' s Life of Charlotte Brontë.
Tells Gaskell of her pleasure in reading this biography.
Informs Sara Hennell of her delight in reading Oedipus at Colonnus and Gaskell's Life of Charlotte Brontë. GHL despatches [sic] the last instalment of 'Gilfil' to Blackwood.
Begins writing 'Janet's Repentance'.
GHL sends Blackwood his article 'The Scilly Isles' for inclusion in Blackwood's.
Blackwood informs GHL of the rumour that Scenes of Clerical Life is the work of E. G. Bulwer Lytton.
Blackwood dispatches proofs of the conclusion of 'Gilfil'.
Tells Blackwood of her dissatisfaction with the ending of 'Barton'.
Relieved to get letters telling her that her sister Chrissy and daughter Katie are well, after a month of worrying about their health following the loss of Chrissy's other daughter, Fanny.
Returns final proofs of 'Gilfil' together with an epilogue.
Leave the Scillys for Jersey.
Take lodgings at Rosa Cottage, Gorey.
Writes Isaac, 'I have changed my name, and have someone to take care of me in the world' (Letters 2: 331).
Congratulates Chapman on his medical degree, also telling him that she is now Mrs Lewes to all her family.
Sends Blackwood first instalment of 'Janet's Repentance'.
Writes to Sara Hennell defending her relationship with GHL and emphasising the need for a truthful account of her situation.
Describes her life to Mary Cash (neé Sibree) as 'a preparation for some special work that I may do before I die' (Letters 2: 343; Cross 1: 456).
Blackwood sends - with qualified approval - proof of chs 1-4 of 'Janet's Repentance'.
Vincent Holbeche, family solicitor, sends an enquiry about GE's marriage on behalf of the offended Isaac.

Writes to Blackwood defending the drama of 'Janet's Repentance' as the clash 'between irreligion and religion' and refusing to make any alterations of substance: 'as an artist I should be utterly powerless if I departed from my own conceptions of life and character' (Letters 2: 347-48; Cross 1: 458-59).
Acknowledges to Holbeche that her marriage is not legal, precipitating ostracism by her family.
GHL writes to Blackwood expressing his amazement at the latter's criticisms of 'Janet's Repentance'.
Assures Blackwood that her characters will become clear as the story proceeds.
Finishes reading aloud to GHL Charlotte Brontë's The Professor.
Reads Samuel Smiles' s Life of George Stephenson aloud to GHL.
Blackwood congratulates GE on the appearance of 'Janet's Repentance' but again expresses reservations about the harshness of some of the characterisation.
First instalment of 'Janet's Repentance' appears in Blackwood's.
The reviewer of 'Janet's Repentance' in the Manx Sun attributes the work to 'Mr Liggins'.
Blackwood sends proofs of second instalment of 'Janet's Repentance' with slight reservations.
GE returns proofs. GHL requests Blackwood to refrain from criticising GE's work unless absolutely necessary.
Tells Sara Hennell that she expects to have forfeited the correspondence of her brother by her relationship with Lewes.
Sends Bessie Parkes good wishes on becoming editor of the Waverley Journal. GHL writes satirically to Blackwood concerning the attribution of Scenes to Liggins.
Leave Jersey for London.
See Donizetti's Lucrezia Borgia.
Visited by Sara Hennell.
Second instalment of 'Janet's Repentance' appears in Blackwood's.
GHL sends Blackwood the third instalment of 'Janet's Repentance.'
Entertain Barbara Bodichon (neé Smith) and her new husband to dinner.
Blackwood sends proofs of third instalment of 'Janet's Repentance' with unqualified praise. GE begins reading Aeschylus's Agamemnon, having completed Sophocles's Electra.
Blackwood forwards a letter from the Revd W. P. Jones, claiming that 'Janet's Repentance' refers to his brother, who died 23 years previously.
Assures Blackwood that 'Mr Tryan is not a portrait of any clergyman, living or dead' (Letters 2: 375; Cross 1: 462).
Tells Sara Hennell, 'writing is part of my religion, and I can write no word that is not prompted from within' (Letters 2: 377; Cross 1: 464).
GHL leaves to visit his sons at Hofwyl.
Expresses to Bessie Parkes her approval of the contents of the Waverley Journal.
GHL returns from Hofwyl.
GHL sends Blackwood the fourth instalment of  GE's 'Janet's Repentance'.
Sends Blackwood her preliminary ideas for Adam Bede: 'I am inclined to take a large canvas for it, and write a novel' (Letters 2: 381; Cross 1: 464).
Visits Bessie Parkes at the offices of the Waverley Journal, who introduces her friend as 'Miss Evans'.
Asks Bessie Parkes to refer to her as 'Mrs Lewes.'
Requests Chapman to send the books necessary for an article on F. W. Newman. Suggests W. M. W. Call to Chapman as a contributor.
Finishes 'Janet's Repentance.'
GHL despatches the fifth and last instalment of 'Janet's Repentance' to Blackwood.
Blackwood sends the final proof of 'Janet's Repentance' with a copy of each of the Scenes to revise for the book reprint.

Sends Blackwood a title page for the Scenes and proposals for Bede: 'My new story haunts me a good deal, and I shall set about it without delay. It will be a country story - full of the breath of cows and the scent of hay' (Cross 1: 465-6).
Recommends Monteil's Histoire des Franfais des divers etats to Sara Hennell as 'one of the most wonderful books in French or any other literature' (Cross 1: 465).
Begins writing Adam Bede.
Reading Sophocles's Philoctetes.
Blackwood finalises the publishing and copyright arrangements for Scenes of Clerical Life.
Final part of 'Janet's Repentance' appears in Blackwood's.
Confirms her acceptance of £120 for the first edition of Scenes.
Blackwood sends the first 16 pages of page proofs for the first edition of Scenes.
Thanks Blackwood for the proofs, also reporting that Bede 'is in progress - slow progress at present' (Cross 1: 470).
Visited by Chapman and his brother Thomas.
