Discusses in letter to Charles Bray the content of his Philosophy of Necessity and the desirability of its republication, remarking, 'My own experience and development deepen every day my conviction that our moral progress may be measured by the degree in which we sympathise with individual suffering and individual joy' (Letters 1: 472).
Thirty-eighth birthday. Tells Sara Hennell, 'Anniversaries are sad things - to one who has lived long and done little' (Cross 1: 474).
GHL tells Blackwood that 'GE has come to stay at Richmond and is writing his new story with a fresh influx of confidence' (Letters 2: 406).
Writes 'How I Came to Write Fiction' in her Journal, detailing the conception and writing of Scenes (see Journals, 283-96; Letters 2: 406-10). Finishes reading the Agamemnon.
Blackwood tells GHL that GE is too diffident.

Learns of Blackwood' s decision to extend the first edition of Scenes to 1000 copies, and to give her a further £60. Reads Christmas number of Household Words by Wilkie Collins and Dickens; also reading Riehl's Die Familie.
Receive a letter from Blackwood's brother, Major William Blackwood, announcing his intention of visiting.
Major William Blackwood calls. GE notes, 'It was evident to us ... that he knew I was George Eliot' (Cross  1: 476).
Thanks Blackwood for his confidence in Scenes and the extension of the first edition.
Tells Sara Hennell, 'I get more hungry for knowledge every day, and less able to satisfy my hunger' (Cross 1: 478). GHL proposes Physiology of Common Life to Blackwood.
Blackwood sends proof of the title page of Scenes.
Returns the amended proof with a list of the recipients of complimentary copies, including Jane Carlyle, whom GE has never met.

Looks back at the year, grateful for their successful year, culminating with: I have written the Scenes of Clerical Life--my first book--and though we are uncertain still whether it will be a success as a separate publication, I have had much sympathy from my readers in Blackwood, and feel a deep satisfaction in having done a bit of faithful work that will perhaps remain like a primrose root in the hedgerow and gladden and chasten human hearts in years to come (Journals 71).
Writes to Charles Bray discussing his views on the gold standard and sending good wishes for Christmas.
GHL and GE spend Christmas day together. 'We ate our turkey together in a happy solitude á deux' (Cross 1: 480).
GHL travels to Vernon Hill for his annual Christmas visit with the Helps family. GE remains home alone.
Delane, editor of The Times, asks Blackwood for a review copy of Scenes.

Notes in her Journal, 'Few women, I fear have had such reason as I have to think the long sad years of youth were worth living for the sake of middle age .... May I be able to look back on 1858 with an equal consciousness of advancement in worth and heart' (Journal 72; Cross 1: 481).
GHL returns from Vernon Hill with a copy of The Times containing Samuel Lucas's favourable review of Scenes.
Scenes subscribed in London.
First edition of Scenes published. Herbert Spencer to dinner.
First four chapters of Bede completed and read to GHL.
Blackwood sends details of the subscriptions to Scenes.
Subscriptions already total 580. GE notes that she ordered copies to be sent to Froude, Dickens, Thackeray, Tennyson, Ruskin, Faraday, Albert Smith and Jane Carlyle.
Writes to Chapman asking to be excused from contributing the article on F. W. Newman to Westminster.
Reading Aeschylus's Choephori. Agrees with Sara Hennell's disappointment with the January Westminster. J. A. Froude sends a letter of thanks for his copy of Scenes.
Dickens expresses his admiration for Scenes and his belief that the writer must be a woman. GE receives it on Jan 20.
Reads GHL part of ch. 6 of Bede.
Writes to Blackwood expressing her deep gratitude for Dickens's praise, and regretting that the 'iron mask of my incognito' prevents her writing to him (Letters 2: 424).
Dickens writes to Blackwood insisting that Scenes are the product of a female pen.
Faraday thanks GE for his copy of Scenes.
Writes to Bessie Parkes declaring her interest in the latter's new English Woman's Journal.
Finishes chs 7 and 8 of Bede.
GHL writes to Blackwood expressing his disappointment at the sales of Sea-Side Studies and outlining his financial difficulties.

GE receives a request from Bessie Parkes to contribute to the English Woman's Journal. GE responds, 'I have given up writing articles, having discovered that my vocation lies in other paths' (Letters 2: 431).
Blackwood sends £120 as the first instalment for Scenes. Ch. 9 of Bede completed.
GHL visits J. W. Parker, publisher and editor of Fraser's Magazine, and hears GE spoken of as a writer of great merit.
Visit W. M. W. Call and his wife Rufa (formerly Rufa Hennell), and have their photographs taken by Mayall.
Visited by Blackwood. GHL and GE decide the time has come to reveal her identity to Blackwood, who at last has his suspicion confirmed.
Blackwood tells his wife of the revelation of GE's identity.
Visited by Blackwood, who reports Thackeray' s high opinion of Scenes. Manuscript of chs 1-13 of Bede passed to Blackwood.
Signs her will, making GHL her executor. Records in diary, “I wrote my will, and signed it in the presence of Mr. Chapman and Mr. Birt.”
Works on ch. 14 of Bede.
Blackwood sends his approval of the Bede manuscript.
GHL informs Blackwood that his praise has restored GE' s confidence.
Authorises Blackwood to make his own decision as to whether Bede should appear in instalments, and requests an outstanding payment of £60 for Scenes. Sends Cara Bray her photo.
Asks Charles Bray not to spread 'false rumours' that she is commencing a novel (Letters 2: 443).
Blackwood sends a detailed appreciation of the first section of Bede, suggesting minor changes, but stressing its great promise.
Refuses to disclose the story of Bede to Blackwood in advance.
Leave for Munich, travelling via Lille, Cologne, Frankfurt and Nuremberg. For GE's account of this trip see Journals, 303-26, Cross 1: 18-34, 39-61, 63-4.
Take lodgings in Munich at 15 Luitpoldstrasse.
Commences vol. II of Bede manuscript.
Blackwood agrees to GE's scheme of publishing Bede as a complete work as soon as it is finished.
Call on Liebig in his laboratory. He explains his new method of mirror silvering, and gives GE a mirror as a souvenir.
Visit the anatomist von Siebold.
GHL visits the Museum of Comparative Anatomy to watch van Siebold at work.
GE sees Flemish pictures in the Pinakothek. Study of Flemish art in Munich galleries anticipates the concerns of ch. 17 of Bede.
Sees antique sculpture at the Glyptothek and visit the Pinakothek again, journaling extensively about painting and sculpture (Journals 310-3)
Reads ch. 20 of Bede to GHL.
Discusses sources of Scenes, both actual and imaginary, in letter to Blackwood . Writing ch. 21 of Bede.
The Saturday Review contains a laudatory notice of Scenes.
See Rossini's William Tell. Conceives the fight in the wood between Arthur and Adam during this performance.
Finishes ch. 21 of Bede.
Sends condolences to Sara Hennell following the death of her mother.
Spends the next eight days working on chs 23-4 of Bede.
GHL leaves Munich to visit his sons at Hofwyl.
GHL returns.
Visited by Strauss at her lodgings: 'I had a quarter of an hour's chat with him alone, and was very agreeably impressed' (Cross 2: 63). Bede now completed to ch. 26.
Leave Munich for Dresden, via Salzburg, the Tyrol, Vienna, and Prague, encountering scenes to be used in 'The Lifted Veil' and Daniel Deronda.

Take lodgings at 5B Waisenhausstrasse in Dresden, where she wrote the latter half of the  second volume of Adam Bede, in the long mornings that our early hours... secured us (Journals 325). At the Picture gallery, GE sees many famous paintings and and is especially impressed by Raphael's Sistine Madonna (Journals 325-6).
GHL sends Chapman news of his almost completed article 'Realism in Art: Recent German Fiction'.
GHL sends Blackwood publication details of Physiology of Common Life and confirms the good progress of Bede.
Visit Tauchnitz in Leipzig .
Shown around Carus's anatomical museum.
Return from their almost 5 months in Germany to Richmond.
GHL receives an offer from Major William Blackwood for the German publication of Scenes, and prepares to negotiate a fee.
Passes on Strauss' s greetings to Rufa Call. Sends Sara Hennell a Liebig autograph.
Discusses Spurgeon, and Ruskin's high opinion of him, in letter to Sara Hennell.
Sends Vol 2 of the Bede manuscript to Blackwood.
GHL confirms that GE requires £50 from Brockhaus for the German edition of Scenes.
J. A. Froude writes a second time requesting that he might know more of the author of Scenes.
Asks Blackwood to reply to Froude on her behalf stressing her admiration for him, but also the necessity of remaining incognito.
Blackwood writes of his admiration for the second manuscript volume of Bede.
Discusses October's Westminster in letter to Sara Hennell.
Blackwood tells GHL that he had not praised Volume 2 of Bede sufficiently.
Chapman visits, expressing dissatisfaction with certain aspects of the Westminster.
Invites Charles Bray to visit Richmond.
Vol. III of the Bede manuscript sent to Blackwood.
Visited by Bessie Parkes and Barbara Bodichon before Bodichon's departure for Algiers.
Reading Carlyle' s Life of Frederick the Great.
Blackwood praises vol. III of the Bede manuscript and offers £800 for the copyright for four years. GE accepts the offer on Nov.4.
Accepts Blackwood's offer. At dinner Herbert Spencer reveals that Chapman had referred casually to GE's authorship of Scenes. GE writes to Chapman insisting that he respect her incognito.
Sends Sara Hennell autographs, including Thierry, De Tocqueville and Comte.
Visited by Wilkie Collins: 'there is a sturdy uprightness about him that makes all opinion and all occupation respectable' (Journals, 75).
Blackwood agrees to pay the first instalment for Bede immediately upon publication.
'Wrote the last word of Adam Bede . .. Jubilate!' (Journals 75).
GHL accepts Blackwood's offer for the publication of the Physiology of Common Life.
Blackwood sends congratulations on the conclusion of Bede and forwards Williams and Norgate's offer of £30 for the continental reprint of Scenes, together with the first proof sheets of Bede.
Accepts Williams and Norgate's offer. Visited by Charles Bray.
Sends Cara Bray her advice for the Brays' projected stay abroad.

GE writes the 'History of Adam Bede' in her Journal, detailing the conception and progress of the novel (see Journals 296-298; Cross 2: 65-71. Formally concludes her friendship with Chapman following his indiscretion over her incognito.
Requests Blackwood not to delay the publication of Bede unduly lest her identity be discovered before the novel's appearance.
GHL stresses to Blackwood the necessity of concealing GE' s identity if Bede is to be received impartially.
Blackwood sends £30 for the German edition of Scenes and suggests a sum of £50 for the initial offer of American publication.
GE suggests not more than £30 for the American publication, and expresses her approval of the typeface for Bede.
Sends Blackwood a prefatory 'Demonstrance' to Bede, written at GHL' s insistence.

Blackwood advises omission of this preface. GE and GHL spend Christmas very happily alone together (Journals 75). This is their first Christmas together as a couple; GHL postpones his holiday trip to the Helps's.
GHL suggests a briefer advertisement to replace the Bede preface. GHL leaves to pay a short visit at Vernon Hill (Journals 75).

Writes to Blackwood agreeing that the Bede preface is unsuitable, and anticipating renewed writing in the new year: 'I have not yet made up my mind what my new story is to be, but I must not lie fallow any longer' (Letters 2: 75).
Records in Journal, 'Our double life is more and more blessed--more and more complete' (Journals 75; Cross 2: 75).
Tells Chapman that further letter-writing is unlikely to advance their mutual understanding.
Publication of part I of GHL's Physiology of Common Life.
First mention of research for The Mill on the Floss – searching Annual Register for examples of inundation. Reading Scott's Life and Michelet's De l'amour.
Last proofs of Bede read. GHL and GE walk to Holly Lodge, the house they have taken for 7 years (Journals 76). GHL reports previous two to three weeks almost entirely taken up by house-hunting.
GHL records in his Journal his debt to Spencer for introducing him to GE: 'to know her was to love her, - and since then my life has been a new birth' (Cross 2: 76).
Visit St Paul's Cathedral. Blackwood sends £400 as a first instalment for Bede.
Asks Blackwood to send presentation copies of Bede to John Brown, Jane Carlyle, Dickens, J. A. Froude, Kingsley, Owen and Thackeray.
Bede published.
Take possession of Holly Lodge, Southfields, near Wimbledon.
Move from Richmond to Holly Lodge.
Reads John Brown's 'Rab and his Friends' and Scott's Life. On GE's behalf, GHL writes to Chapman denying her authorship of Bede.

Tells Sara Hennell, 'We have met a pleasant-faced, bright glancing young man, whom we set down to be worthy of the name, Richard Congreve. I am curious to see if our Ahnung will be verified' (Cross 2: 84).
Jane Carlyle expresses her delight at her presentation copy.
Begin enquiries for a new servant.
Much upset by receiving letter from consumptive Chrissey, and tells Cara Bray: 'It has ploughed up my heart' (Cross 2: 85).
Finishes The Lifted Veil. Enthusiastic reviews of Bede appear in the Athenaeum and Leader, symptomatic of its generally favourable reception.
Pay their first call on their neighbours Richard and Maria Congreve.
Blackwood reports Bede 'coming in a winner at a slapping pace' (Letters 3: 29).
Elizabeth Gaskell admires GE's fiction in a letter to Blackwood.
Spend evening with the Congreves. GE and Maria Congreve become close.
Meet the Positivist J. H. Bridges.
Notes in her diary the letter from Chrissey about three weeks ago [Feb 24] and now a letter from Emily that Chrissy cannot live many days (Journals 77).
Death of Chrissey, before any reunion could take place. Nothing in the journal except an italicized (underlined) entry for March 15, Chrissy died this morning, at a quarter to 5 (Journals 77).

Blackwood announces second edition of Bede now a certainty -the edition appears this month. Journal remarks, 'I happened this morning to be reading the 30th Ode, B. III of Horace - Non omnis moriar' (Cross 2: 93).
Tells Sara Hennell: 'Chrissey's death has taken from me the possibility of many things towards which I looked with some hope and yearning in the future' (Cross 2: 95).
Visit from Spencer, with whom cordial relationships begin to decline. Spencer has let slip to a persistent John Chapman GE's authorship of Adam Bede.
Offers Blackwood 'The Lifted Veil', 'not a jeu d'esprit, but ajeu de melancolie' (Letters 3: 41).
Invited by Samuel Lucas to contribute to Once a Week.
Spend four days in the Isle of Wight in attempt to improve GHL's health.
The Times declares of Bede that 'its author takes rank at once among the masters of the art'.
Henry Smith Anders writes to The Times asserting that Joseph Liggins is the author of Scenes and Bede.
GHL writes to The Times denying Liggins's authorship. Barbara Bodichon sure that Bede is by GE.

Records success of Bede in her Journal, remarking, 'Shall I ever write another book as true as Adam Bede? The weight of the future presses on me, and makes itself felt even more than the deep satisfaction of the past and present' (Journals 300; Cross 2: 101).
Informs Sara Hennell of the pleasure derived from the company of the Congreves.
GHL tells Blackwood that the Liggins myth must be refuted.
Decides to rewrite first two chapters of Mill. Informs Blackwood of desire to add a sentence to third edition of Bede--the only alteration proposed.
E. G. Bulwer-Lytton praises Bede as 'one of the very ablest works of fiction I have read for years' (Cross 2: 102).
Barbara Bodichon reveals her intuition that GE is the author of Bede. GE finishes 'The Lifted Veil'.

Decides to rewrite first two chapters of Mill, tentatively called The Tullivers or St. Ogg's on the Floss. Blackwood proposes a third edition of Bede. GHL suffers unpleasant fall. Journal entry on May 2 elaborates: last week [GHL] fainted in his dressing room, but Dr. Simon, who visited, assured them he was free from organic disease (Journals 77).

Acknowledges the authorship of Bede to Barbara Bodichon but asks her to keep the secret. GHL tells Barbara Bodichon not to address GE as Marian Evans. Blackwood reports the 'third' edition of Bede (actually a new impression of the second edition) almost sold.
Tells Major William Blackwood it seems impossible to write anything so good and true as Bede again.
GE and GHL drive to Dulwich and look at paintings in the picture gallery and enjoy spring weather outside at the Commons (Journals 77).
Blackwood sends proof of 'The Lifted Veil', suggesting the deletion of the final blood transfusion (advice ignored), and offering to make an extra payment of £400 for Bede.
Tells Sara Hennell that she and GHL take it in turns to nurse each other - symptomatic of their variable health in these years. Returns corrected proof of 'The Lifted Veil'.
First concert outing since returning from abroad - Handel's Acis and Galatea, arranged by Mozart, at St James's Hall.
Entertain Blackwood to dinner.
Visited by George Meredith - one of several contacts with the novelist during this period.
The editor of The Times hears news of 'George Eliot's' identity.
Elizabeth Gaskell writes to say that being suspected as the author of Bede was the greatest compliment she had yet received.
Visited by Blackwood, who reports that GE 'gave me more the idea of the creator of her humorous characters than I have yet seen' (Letters 3: 75).
The Revd John Gwyther writes to Blackwood claiming that he is sure that he has been depicted as 'Amos Barton', and also identifying other 'originals'.
Attend Messiah at the Crystal Palace. Afterwards dine with the Brays, GE revealing her nom de plume. Blackwood delighted with the opening of Mill. Third edition of Bede published.
Blackwood visits Holly Lodge and discusses terms for Mill, subsequently telling his brother that it is impossible not to like GE excessively. GHL prepares a denunciation of Liggins for The Times.
Sara Hennell reports Isaac Evans' s remark that no one but his sister could have written Bede.
Tells the Brays and Sara Hennell that she does not enjoy discussing her books. Editor of The Times tells Blackwood that he feels GHL's denunciation is too severe.
GHL tells John and Major William Blackwood that the secret of authorship is to be revealed.
GHL requests Barbara Bodichon not to pass on any adverse criticism to GE. He tells Bray that the secrecy of the pseudonym is to be abandoned.
Athenaeum attacks 'George Eliot' for mystification over the authorship of her books. Visit from John and Major William Blackwood.
Leave for Lucerne, Switzerland, via Paris , Strasbourg, and Basel.(For details of journey, see Cross  2: 119.)
Stay at the Schweizerhof in Lucerne.
Dickens writes to GE that Bede has taken its place among the actual experiences and endurances of his life, and invites her to contribute to his periodical.
GHL visits his sons at Hofwyl for three days (July 13-16), and finally tells them of his relationship with GE, the author of  Adam Bede, a novel they recognize. They are delighted.
Leave Lucerne for Basel, where they spend another 2 days before heading home via Paris and Boulogne.
Return home.
Second edition of Scenes published.

Langford brings a pug as a present from Blackwood, and also the second edition of Scenes. GE tells Charles Lewes: 'I look forward to playing duets with you as one of my future pleasures' (Cross 2: 125).
Dickens regrets that he is unable to visit GE and GHL until he comes up to town.
Declines invitation to write story for the New York Century for fee of £1200.
Sends Blackwood progress report on Mill: 'my stories grow in me like plants, and this is only in the leaf-bud. I have faith that the flower will come' (Cross 2: 129).
First letter from Thornton Lewes to his new 'mother'.
Travel to North Wales.
Abandon North Wales for Weymouth, Dorset, meeting two nieces at Lichfield, Staffordshire, en route, and gathering detail for Mill in Dorset.
Study mills in Dorset. Read aloud A. H. Layard, Nineveh and its Remains.
GHL tells Blackwood, 'GE is in high spirits, having found a mill and mill-stream to his heart's content' (Letters 3: 145).
Suggests to Blackwood that Mill should not receive serial publication.
Return from Dorset to Holly Lodge.
'In much anxiety and doubt about my new novel' (Cross 2: 133).
Writes to Charles Bray about her extreme annoyance with Bracebridge. GHL writes directly and vehemently to Bracebridge.
Blackwood offers £3000 for Mill, and suggests retaining serial publication. Bracebridge renounces Liggins.
Depart for the Trent to gather more material for Mill.
Return to Holly Lodge.
Annoyed by Bracebridge's description of her father as a 'farmer'. GHL asks Charles Bray to move GE's photograph to a private position in his house. Gratified by Spencer's praise of Bede.

Records in Journal, 'Certain new ideas have occurred to me in relation to my novel, and I am in better hope of it' (Journals 80; Cross  2: 133). Sends Sara Hennell a detailed description of her aunt, Elizabeth Evans, who suggested characters and incidents in Bede.
Tolstoy reads Bede, a representative instance of its remarkable reputation and market.
Vol. 1 of Mill finished. Draws Blackwood's attention to printer's errors in the third edition of Bede.
Writes to D' Albert, announcing that she has at last found out her new vocation. Major William Blackwood perturbed to find GE's change of signature (from 'George Eliot' to 'Marian Evans Lewes').
Spencer dines at Holly Lodge, better relationships having been restored with him. GE resolves to allow no more talk in her house with visitors on the subject of her books.
GHL attempts to get Blackwood to instigate legal proceedings against the Bede sequel.
Finish reading Balzac's Père Goriot: 'a hateful book' (Cross 2: 139).
Blackwood sends the final £400 for Bede, and promises a bonus of £800 in the new year.
Acknowledges Blackwood's gesture, but in terms the firm considered cold and insensitive.
Reading Tom Brown at Oxford.

Entertains Dickens to dinner at Holly Lodge, afterwards visiting the Congreves to discuss Positivism. GE pronounces Dickens 'a man one can thoroughly enjoy talking to' (Cross 2: 140). Elizabeth Gaskell renounces Liggins.
GE acknowledges Gaskell's letter, offering her own generous assessment of Gaskell's work.
Invited by Dickens to write a new novel for All the Year Round. GHL tells Sara Hennell never to pass on to GE any comments made by others about her writings.
GHL is shopping for a better publishing deal for Mill. Bradbury and Evans offer to outbid Blackwood's.

Declines Dickens's invitation on the grounds that Time is an unsurmountable obstacle (Journals 81), which is GE's standard reason given for not accepting any invitations as a matter of course. Reading Thomas à Kempis. Blackwood tells Langford of his disappointment at the tone of GE's reply to his offer. GHL informs Blackwood that 'Maggie goes on gloriously' (Letters 3: 208).
Sign their wills, their solicitor, Henry Sheard, simultaneously offering advice on the legal background in Mill.
Fortieth birthday. Records in Journal her annoyance at Blackwood's failure to suppress Adam Bede, Junior.

Begin reading (on the day before its publication) Darwin's On the Origin of Species - 'though full of interesting matter, it is not impressive, from want of luminous and orderly presentation' (Journals, 82).
Tells the Brays Darwin's book 'makes an epoch' (n, 144). Rereads Bunyan with pleasure.
Writes desiring to know if Blackwoods' wish to remain her publishers.
Blackwood explains his conduct, and on the 30th GE sends a lengthy explanation of her own. Also writes to The Times emphatically dissociating herself from Adam Bede, Junior.

Bradbury and Evans offer £4500 for a serialized version and two subsequent edition of GE's new novel. Major William Blackwood tells his brother that he is chiefly perturbed by GE's determination to drop her incognito. GHL asks Emile Montégut to suggest a translator for Bede.
Book III of Mill finished.

Writes at length to Barbara Bodichon, discussing Darwin, and remarking that recent difficulties have taught 'how entirely the rewards of the artist lie apart from everything that is narrow and personal' (Cross 2: 147).
Writes at length to D' Albert, detailing the changes in her character since he knew her.
Long visit from Blackwood, discussing terms for Mill.
Visited by Tauchnitz.
Blackwood finds the first volume and a half of Mill wonderfully clever.
Blackwood offers £2000 for first edition of Mill.
Blackwood visits, and tells his brother his former good opinion of GE is restored.
Accepts Blackwood' s offer.
GE and GHL spend Christmas Day with the Congreves. Bridges also present.
GHL sends light-hearted New Year greetings to Blackwood.
GHL buys GE a set of Walter Scott's Waverley novels.
Blackwood pays additional royalty on Bede and returns copyright.
Acknowledges Blackwood's generosity, and asks his advice on possible titles for Mill.
GHL offers Blackwood five possible titles for Mill.
Blackwood makes his own title suggestion: The Mill on the Floss.
Records in Journal: 'Our New Year opens with happy omens' (Cross 2: 154).
The Mill on the Floss chosen as title.

Vol. II of Mill manuscript completed. GHL tells Blackwood that the Queen has commissioned two watercolours of scenes from Bede. Reading Humphry Clinker - 'much disappointed' (Cross 2: 156). Chapman asks permission to reprint GE's articles (refused).
Entertain Pigott, Redford, and Frederic Chapman to dinner. Maria Congreve and her sister arrive for musical entertainment.
Tells Blackwood, 'I have been invalided for the last week, and, of course, am a prisoner in the castle of Giant Despair, who growls in my ear that The Mill on the Floss is detestable' (Cross 2: 156).
GHL remarks to Blackwood, 'There never was so diffident and desponding an author, since the craft first began' (Letters 3: 258).
Blackwood receives manuscript of vol. II of Mill.
GHL goes to Lymington for two days--GE notes that she is alone in this house for the first time (Journals 84)
GHL requests proof to be sent to Sheard, to prevent legal solecisms.

E. G. Bulwer-Lytton calls. GE reports to Blackwood that Lytton 'thinks the two defects of Adam Bede are the dialect and Adam's marriage with Dinah; but of course, I would have my teeth drawn rather than give up either' (Cross 2: 157).
GHL secures £300 for Mill from Harpers and £100 from Tauchnitz for the German reprint.
Terms for American and German editions of Mill arranged.
Informed of death of niece Katie.
Samuel Laurence requests permission to paint GE's portrait - sittings given in August.
GHL tells Blackwood, 'Mrs Lewes is getting her eyes redder and swollener every morning as she lives through her tragic story' (Letters 3: 269).
GHL forbids the confirmation of his two eldest boys.
Completes Mill.

Tells Blackwood, 'I am grateful and yet rather sad to have finished' (Letters 2: 160), and sends three corrections. Also remarks, 'It is time that I should go and absorb some new life, and gather fresh ideas' (Cross 2: 160).
Receives, corrects, and returns, proof of Mill conclusion. GHL asks Bray to abstain from biographical statements about GE.
Depart for Italy, via Paris. For GE's detailed account of this European trip see Recollections of Italy. 1860, Journals 327-68, and Cross 2: 164-252.
Visit Notre Dame, Sainte Chapelle and the Louvre in Paris, and see Rossini's Otello.
Arrive in Rome. GE at first disappointed.

Visited cemetery containing grave of Keats and ashes of Shelley - 'a spot that touched me deeply' (Cross 2: 193). Seeing 'dear Shelley's tomb,' she says, 'was like a personal consolation to me to see that simple outward sign that he is at rest, where no hatred can ever reach him again'  (Letters 3: 288).]
Mill published.
Kneels to receive the Pope's blessing in St Peter's.
Third edition of Scenes published.
Leave Rome.
Arrive in Naples, 'declaring it to surpass all places we had seen before' (Cross 2: 199).
Visit Pompeii. 'I hope I shall never forget the solemnity of our entrance into that silent city' (Cross 2: 204).
GHL sends his sons details of the holiday so far.
Second visit to Pompeii.
Leave Naples.
Arrive in Florence.
The Times reviews Mill favourably.
Savonarola strikes GHL as a good subject for a novel. GE immediately enthusiastic.
Sara Hennell sends signed copy of her Thoughts in Aid of Faith. Buy Savonarola's Poems and visit his monastery of San Marco.
Writes to Major William Blackwood discussing deficiencies in the Times review of Mill.
Spend evening with Theodosia Trollope at Florence.
Leave Florence for Bologna.
Arrive in Venice: 'Venice was more beautiful than romances had feigned' (Cross 2: 237).
Asks D' Albert never to let her know the substance of French criticism of her work.
Leave Venice.
Tells Blackwood their journey has left them 'immensely enriched with new ideas and new veins of interest' and that she is keen to begin a new and secret 'great project' (Cross 2: 252).
Visit Hofwyl, taking away Charles Lewes, GHL's eldest son.
Introduces GHL to D' Albert at Geneva.

Return to Holly Lodge 'after three months of delightful travel' (Letters 2: 25), with Charles, 'the most entirely lovable human animal of seventeen and a half that I ever met with or heard of' (Cross 2: 266).
Thanks Sara Hennell for her Thoughts in Aid of Faith, though also expressing guarded reservations.
Sends Blackwood her comments on E. G. Bulwer-Lytton's criticism of Mill. GHL writes with blunt criticism of Sara Hennell's Thoughts.
Offers to lend Charles Bray £100.
Trollope announces that Charles Lewes has been nominated as a supplementary clerk in the Post Office.
GHL asks Blackwood to suggest a suitable Edinburgh establishment for his second son, Thornton, to board at.
Charles Lewes enters the Civil Service.
Regrets distressing Sara Hennell. Reading Emerson, 'Man the Reformer'.
Tells Blackwood of the Savonarola idea, but wishes to write another novel first. Eighth sitting for Laurence. Succeed in letting Holly Lodge.
Make offer for 10, Harewood Square, Marylebone.
Thornton Lewes leaves Hofwyl for Edinburgh.
Move to Harewood Square.
Blackwood sends £1000 as first instalment for Mill.
GHL delivers Thornton to a schoolmaster in Edinburgh. GE begins Silas Marner.
Begin to attend course of chemistry lectures by A. W. Hofmann.
Rereading Sara Hennell's Thoughts.
Trollope to dinner: 'made me like him very much by his straightforward wholesome Wesen' (Letters 2: 280). Hears from Arthur Helps of Queen Victoria's admiration for her work.
Second edition of Mill published.
GHL tells Blackwood that GE, recovered from illness, is now writing magnificently.

Reports herself suffering from depression: 'the loss of the country has seemed very bitter to me, and my want of health and strength has prevented me from working much' (Cross 2: 279- 80). Work proceeding slowly on Marner, 'the idea of which came to me after our arrival in this house' (Cross 2: 280-1).
Tells Maria Congreve of pleasure given by Monday Pops Concerts at St James's Hall, at which GE and GHL become regular attenders .
Move to 16 Blandford Square.
Records admiration for part II of Spencer's First Principles.

Tells Barbara Bodichon , 'Everything I do seems poor and trivial in the doing, and when it is quite gone from me, and seems no longer my own, then I rejoice in it and think it fine. That is the history of my life' (Cross 2: 284).
Blackwood sends £1000 for Mill, and £150 each for Bede and Scenes.

Records in Journal, 'this year has been marked by many blessings, and above all, by the comfort we have found in having Charles with us . Since we set out on our journey to Italy on 25th March, the time has not been fruitful in work: distractions about our change of residence have run away with many days; and since I have been in London my state of health has been depressing to all effort. 'May the next year be more fruitful!' (Letters 2: 284).
Tells Blackwood she is writing Marner, a 'sudden inspiration' (Cross 2: 285).
Invites Sara Hennell to call.
Warmly thanks Richard Owen for sending a copy of his Memoir on the Megatherium.
Gives D' Albert a comparative assessment of Bede and Mill.
'The first month of the New Year has been passed in much bodily discomfort' (Cross 2: 285).
Begin four-day trip to Surrey - 'I suppose we must keep soul and body together by occasional flights of this sort' (Cross 2: 286).
Thanks Maria Congreve for the gift of a basket of eggs.
First 13 chapters of Marner sent to Blackwood . Reading Carlyle's Memoirs.

Tells Maria Congreve, 'I have not been working much lately indeed this year has been a comparatively idle one. I think my malaise is chiefly owing to the depressing influence of town air and town scenes' (Letters 2: 288).
Blackwood congratulates GE on opening of Marner, whilst expressing reservations about a 'want of brighter lights' and more likeable characters (Letters 3: 380).
Remarks to Sara Hennell, 'I am unequal to the least exertion or irregularity. My only pleasure away from our own health is going to the Zoological Gardens' (Cross 2: 288).
Informs Blackwood of the inspiration for Marner, and of its intention of setting 'in a strong light the remedial influences of pure, natural human relations' (Cross 2: 290).
Blackwood offers £800 for the first edition of Marner.
Accepts this offer.
Sends Blackwood a motto from Wordsworth's 'Michael' for Marner.
GHL tells Blackwood that he is reassured by his approval of Marner.
Last pages of Marner sent to Blackwood.
Sends a lengthy letter of personal news to Barbara Bodichon.
Tells Blackwood that, against his advice, she has decided to retain the carol sung by Aaron Winthorp in ch. 10 of Marner and thanks him for his prompt printing of the novel.
Set off for a week in Hastings, reading there book v of Macaulay's History of England.
Sends duplicate corrections (from memory) for end of Marner, the corrected proofs having been lost in the post. Writes affectionately to Charles Bray.
GHL, having dissected a starfish, reports GE reading Macaulay. GE tells Blackwood that she and GHL are considering a second visit to Florence.
Receive first copy of Marner.
Asks Langford to send a presentation copy of Marner to GHL' s mother.

Blackwood buys portrait of GE by Laurence. GE tells Cara Bray of her gratitude to her: 'I suppose I must lose my memory altogether before I could forget all the tenderness, forbearance, and generous belief that made the unvarying character of your friendship towards me when we used to be a great deal together' (Letters 8: 276).
Blackwood sends cheque for £1350 for Mill.
Publication of Marner. Langford reports 5500 copies already bespoken .
Explains to Clementia Taylor her rule of never paying visits.
Death of Major William Blackwood. Declines permission for Laurence portrait to be exhibited.
Tells Barbara Bodichon of their projected Italian visit.

Hear Beethoven's Mass in D at the Exeter Hall, but GE comments the next day to Sara Hennell, 'The enjoyment of such things is much diminished by the gas and bad air. Indeed our long addiction to a quiet life, in which our daily walk among the still grass and trees was a fête to us, has unfitted us for the sacrifices that London demands' (Cross 2: 297).
Set out for Italy, GE intending to do further research on Savonarola.
Send Charles Lewes details of their brief stay in Paris.
Arrive in Florence, but soon plagued by illness. Learn from Blackwood that he expects to sell the complete print run of Marner (7500 copies).
GHL sends Charles Lewes further details of their travels.
Hear Bottesini, the legendary double-bass virtuoso.
Tell Charles Lewes about the Bottesini performance, and describe their working day.
Reports to Blackwood, 'We have been industriously foraging in old streets and old books. I feel very grave just now, and enjoy the thought of work' (Cross 2: 303).
GHL tells Blackwood of the pleasure he derives from GE' s affection for his children, shown in several affectionate letters of this period.
Set off in company of Tom Trollope to visit monasteries of Camaldoli and La Vernia. For details see Letters 3: 422-5.
Leave Florence for Berne.
See Bertie Lewes at Hofwyl.
Return to England.
Talks to Blackwood at lunch about progress with Romola.
Reports in Journal, 'This morning, for the first time, I feel myself quietly settled at home. I am in excellent health, and long to work steadily and effectively' (Cross 2: 306).
Entertained by Blackwood at Greenwich.

Finishes the first volume of her Journal: 'This is the last entry I mean to make in my old book in which I wrote for the first time at Geneva in 1849. What moments of despair I passed through after that - despair that life would ever be made precious to me by the consciousness that I lived to some good purpose. . . . The same demon tries to get hold of me again whenever an old work is dismissed and a new one is being meditated' (Cross 2: 306-7). Tells Sara Hennell, 'We have had a perfect journey except as regards health - a large, large exception' (n, 307).
GHL writes reprovingly to Edward Walford about inaccurate statements concerning GE' s biography in his Men of the Time.
Tells Sara Hennell of disappointment at failure to gain a glimpse of a conspicuous comet.
Anthony Trollope and W. G. Clark to dinner.
Having finished Tom Trollope's La Beata, (which may have suggested some details of Tessa in Romola), writes to Trollope to express her appreciation of it.
Tells Sara Hennell she has been reading Pierre Helyot, L'Histoire des ordres monastiques, Montalembert, Monks of the West, and Comte, Philosophie positive, vol. v.
See Fechter in Hamlet.
'My mind dwelling with much depression on probability or improbability of my achieving the work I wish to do. I struck out two or three thoughts towards an English novel' (Cross 2: 311).
'Struggling constantly with depression' (Cross 2: 313).
Reading Boccaccio.
Depressed by inability to construct story of Romola: 'I became desperate, and suddenly burst my bonds, saying, I will not think of writing' (Cross 2: 313).
Musical entertainment with Pigott and Redford- one of several such relaxations this month.
GHL reports progress with planning of Romola - it is 'slowly crystallising into what will be a magnificent programme' (Letters 3: 446).
Begin fortnight at Malvern to take waters. Reading Anna Jameson, Legends of the Monastic Orders, and Marchesi, Storia di San Marco.
Tells Blackwood, 'I can desire nothing more satisfactory to myself than that our relations should continue as long as my writing life' (Letters 8: 289).
Begins to correct her four books for Cheap edition.
Blackwood sends £1000 as second instalment for Marner.

Sends Blackwood corrections for Bede and Mill: 'It has moved me a good deal - reading the books again after a long interval, but it has done me good, for I can say a full Amen to everything I have written' (Letters 8: 291).
Buy new grand piano 'which tempts me to play more than I have done for years before' (Cross 2: 316).
Finishes correcting proofs for Cheap edition of novels - 'feel my mind free for other work' (Cross 2: 317).
'My mind still worried about my plot - and without any confidence in my ability to do what I want' (Cross 2: 317).
Begins ch. 1 of Romola.
Blackwood offers £3000 for copyright of novels. Reading Nardi's History of Florence.
In the evening we had our usual Saturday mixture of visitors, talk, and music' (Cross 2: 318).
'Utterly desponding' about Romola (Cross 2: 319).
Reading Cicero, De officiis and Petrarch's Letters. Records in Journal that she is 'dreadfully depressed' about Romola.
Tempted to abandon Romola.
See Fechter in Othello - 'lamentably bad' (Cross 2: 320).
Visits British Museum reading room for first time, to research costumes for Romola.
Tells Blackwood she declines to sell her copyrights, also mentioning that 'that journalistic whirlwind,' Dumas père, has pronounced Bede 'the greatest novel of the age' (Letters 8: 293).
Visited by Wilkie Collins, a frequent caller at this time.
Tells GHL her scheme for Romola.
Completes scheme for Romola, and determines to revise it.
GHL reports GE 'still deep in her researches . . . her distressing diffidence paralyses her' (Letters 3: 473-4).
Studying topography of Florence.
Speaks of beginning (i.e. re-beginning) Romola on New Year's Day.
Tells Blackwood, 'The year opens with good auguries. I have begun [i.e. re-begun] my novel [i.e. Romola] this morning' (Letters 4: 3).
Sends D'Albert her recent news.
Implores Maria Congreve to visit them.
Encourages Blackwood to contemplate issuing the Cheap edition of Marner and Scenes at Easter.

Tells Cara Bray: 'The year is opening happily for us, except - alas! the exception is a great one - in the way of health. Mr Lewes is constantly ailing, like a delicate headachy woman' (Letters 2: 330).

Reading Trollope's Orley Farm, commenting to Sara Hennell, 'Anthony Trollope is admirable in the presentation of even average life and character, and he is so thoroughly wholesome-minded that one delights in seeing his books lie about to be read' (Letters II, 331).
George Smith calls to ask if GE will be open to a magnificent offer for Romola.

Records in Journal, 'Detained from writing by the necessity of gaining particulars: 1st, about Lorenzo de Medici's death; 2d, about the possible retardation of Easter; 3d, about Corpus Christi day; 4th, about Savonarola’s preaching in the Quaresima of 1492. Finished La Mandragola - second time reading for the sake of Florentine expressions - and began La Calandra' (Cross 2: 332).

Reads Proem and opening scene of Romola to admiring GHL. Records in Journal, 'It is impossible to me to believe that I have ever been in so unpromising and despairing a state as I now feel' (Cross 2: 332).
Finishes rewriting ch. 1 of Romola.
Begin three-day stay at Dorking, Surrey.
Cheap edition of Bede published. Tells Barbara Bodichon, 'We have had no troubles but the public troubles – anxiety about the war with America, and sympathy with the poor Queen' (Cross 2: 335).
Reports completion of Proem and first two chapters of Romola. Records in Journal, 'I have an oppressive sense of the far-stretching task before me' (Cross 2: 336).

Visits British Museum for Romola research. Finishes reading E. B. Browning's Casa Guidi Windows, remarking, 'It contains amongst other admirable things a very noble expression of what I believe to be the true relation of the religious mind to the past' (Cross 2: 336).
Complains to Blackwood about poor publicity for Cheap edition of her works.
Pleased to note the affectionate respect of the obituary notices of A. H. Clough.

Considerably depressed by slow progress of Romola. Confides to Journal, 'I have a distrust in myself, in my work, in others' loving acceptance of it, which robs my otherwise happy life of all joy.... I have written now about sixty pages of my romance. Will it ever be finished? Ever be worth anything?' (Letters 2: 336).

Smith offers £10,000 for Romola, which GHL swiftly recognises as 'the most magnificent offer ever yet made for a novel' and urges her to accept it (Letters 4: 17-18). Send their servants to the theatre.
Finishes reading David Wingate's Poems and Songs.
Idea for swift Cornhill appearance of Romola - with correspondingly high fee - temporarily abandoned.
Begin week's stay at Englefield Green, Surrey.
Reports in Journal having begun ch. 4 of Romola.
Finishes Christopher Wordsworth's Greece.
Hear Joachim play at St James's Hall.
Records in Journal, 'Writing with enjoyment', but progress with Romola still slow (Cross 2: 338).
Begin three weeks at Dorking in attempt to revive GE's health and spirits.
Assures Sara Hennell that she is not the author of Chronicles of Carlingford (actually by Margaret Oliphant).
GHL accepts consultant editorship of the Cornhill.
Sends domestic news, and details of a recent concert visit, to Charles Lewes.
Reading Collins's No Name. Thanks Cara Bray for printing a correction of the rumour that GE is the author of Chronicles of Carlingford.
Reads Smith several chapters of Romola.
Trollope reports that Charles Lewes is not doing well at the Post Office.
See Verdi's Rigoletto.
Accepts £7000 for Romola in Cornhill. Smith hires GHL as consulting editor for the Cornhill. Leighton chosen as illustrator. Informs Blackwood of plans to publish Romola elsewhere.
Blackwood gracefully acknowledges GE's decision. View Leighton's pictures at the Academy.
GE signs agreement with Smith for Romola.
Smith and Leighton call to discuss the Romola illustrations.
Visited by Tom Trollope.
Entertain Anthony and Tom Trollope and others to dinner.
Still frustrated by slow progress with Romola.
GHL informs Charles Bolton that he is at liberty to dramatise Marner (never accomplished).
Visited by Blackwood.
Reads the third book of Romola to GHL.
Begins fourth book of Romola.
Visits recently opened International Exhibition at South Kensington with Bara Bodichon.
Receives congratulatory letter about Romola from Trollope.
Thanks George Smith for sending a copy of D. G. Rossetti's Early Italian Poets.
Thanks Sara Hennell for her congratulatory remarks about Romola.
Finishes book IV of Romola.
Thornton Lewes passes first examination for Indian Civil Service.
Begins three-week stay at Littlehampton, Sussex, writing Romola (chs 27-32) and reading Beaumont and Fletcher.
GHL writes severely to Sara Hennell asking her never to pass on any comments on GE’s work.
Blackwood sends details of sales of the Cheap edition of GE's works.
GE replies, and recommends Trollope's Orley Farm.
Finishes book VII of Romola.
Finishes reading Boccaccio for second time.
Much impressed by hearing Joachim play Bach at a Monday Pops concert.

Tells Barbara Bodichon, 'Pray don't ever ask me again not to rob a man of his religious belief, as if you thought my mind tended to such robbery.... I have very little sympathy with Freethinkers as a class, and have lost all interest in mere antagonism to religious doctrines' (Letters 2: 343).
Thanks D'Albert for sending two copies of his translation of Marner.
Book VIII of Romola finished.
Cheap edition of Mill published.
First visit from Browning.

Records in Journal, 'At p. 22 only. I am extremely spiritless, dead, and hopeless about my writings.... I am inwardly irritable, and unvisited by good thoughts.... After this record, I read aloud what I had written of book IX to George, and he, to my surprise, entirely approved of it' (Letters 2: 345).
Thornton Lewes knocks down his tutor, but is reinstated in the tutor's house.
Tells Clementia Taylor, 'We go nowhere except to concerts' (Cross 2: 345) and attends Messiah that evening.

Tells Sara Hennell of her enjoyment of Messiah, remarking, 'What pitiable people those who feel no poetry in Christianity. Surely the acme of poetry hitherto is the conception of the suffering Messiah, and the final triumph.... The Prometheus is a very imperfect foreshadowing of that symbol wrought out in the long history of the Jewish and Christian ages' (Cross 2: 347).
Reflects in her Journal on the many blessings experienced in the passing year, not least 'opportunities which have enabled us to acquire an abundant independence' (Cross 2: 348).
Thanks Sara Hennell for sending a book mark for her Bible.
Blackwood requests corrected copy for the Cheap edition of Scenes and Marner, and gives a disappointing report of recent sales of GE's novels.
Begins four-day visit to Dorking. Subsequently reports to Sara Hennell, 'the quiet and fresh air seemed to make a new creature of me' (Cross 2: 349).

Thanks Sara Hennell for her generous appreciation of Romola: 'I have had a great deal of pretty encouragement from immense big-wigs, some of them saying Romola is the finest book they ever read; but the opinion of big-wigs has one sort of value, and the fellow-feeling of a long-known friend has another. One can't do quite well without both' (Cross 2: 349).
Finishes book X of Romola.
Instructs Blackwood to reprint the existing text of Marner (i.e. the second edition).
Visits the Congreves at Wimbledon.
Declines Emily Faithfull's invitation to write a story for the Victoria Magazine.
Thanks Smith for a gift of Thackeray's Henry Esmond, and reports herself impressed by the progress of Gaskell's Sylvia's Lovers.
Records in Journal, 'making no progress in writing' (Letters 4: 79).
Leave for Dorking.
Return to Blandford Square.
Discusses Anthony and Tom Trollope, and the latter's views on spiritualism, in letter to Charles Bray.
Regrets that she will be in Dorking when Maria Congreve calls, though reporting, 'at present I am rather like a shell-less lobster, and inclined to creep out of sight' (Cross 2: 350).
Recommends Thackeray's Lectures on the English Humourists to Charles Lewes.

Thanks Bessie Rayner Parkes for gift of her Ballads and Songs. Looks forward to seeing Barbara Bodichon in June: 'You will come to me like the morning sunlight, and make me a little less of a flaccid cabbage-plant' (Letters 2: 354).
Finishes book XIII of Romola: 'Killed Tito in great excitement' (Letters 2: 353). Inspect The Priory with a view to purchase.
Begins book XIV of Romola.
Hear a sermon by Wiseman.
Reaches the end of ch. 70.
Small party to celebrate (prematurely) the completion of Romola.
Completes Romola. 'The writing of Romola ploughed into her more than any of her other books.... In her own words, I began it a young woman, - I finished it an old woman' (Cross 2: 352).
Sends Sara Hennell an autograph of Montalembert.
Begin fortnight's holiday on the Isle of Wight.
Tells Charles Lewes, 'I am very happy in my holiday, finding quite a fresh charm in the hedgerow grasses and flowers after my long banishment from them' (Cross 2: 355).
Romola published. Second edition appears later this month.

Trollope thanks GE for the gift of a copy of Romola: 'You will know what I mean when I say that Romola will live after you. It will be given to very few latter day novels to have any such life' (Letters 6 (2, 311).
Sends Sara Hennell details of her opera- and theatre-going, and of the decision to purchase The Priory (see 22 Aug).
Hear Gounod’s Faust for the second time.
Discusses Renan's Vie de Jésus in letter to D'Albert.
Reading Mommsen History of Rome - 'I count all minds graceless who read it without the deepest of stirrings' (Cross 2: 365).
Hear Faust for a third time. Receives from F. D. Maurice 'the greatest, most generous tribute ever given to me in my life' (Cross 2: 358).

Tells Clementia Taylor she does not intend to read all of Renan's Vie de Jésus: 'We can never have a satisfactory basis for the history of the man Jesus, but that negation does not affect the idea of the Christ either in its historical influence or its great symbolic meanings ' (Cross 2: 360).
Browning writes to congratulate GE on Romola, an opinion subsequently modified.

Sends R. H. Hutton a lengthy and important letter discussing Romola: 'certain chief elements of my intention have impressed themselves so strongly on your mind, notwithstanding the imperfect degree in which I have been able to give form to my ideas' (Letters 2: 360).
Begin week's visit to Worthing.
Records in Journal, 'Returned home, much invigorated by the week of change; but my spirits seem to droop as usual, now I am in London again' (Cross 2: 363).
Thanks Barbara Bodichon for writing to her, and sends domestic news.
Buy The Priory, 21 North Bank, Regent's Park. GHL records in Journal recent difficulties with his son Thornton, following his failure in the second examination for the Indian Civil Service.
Discusses Romola in letter to Sara Hennell, declaring also her impatience with the public outcry over the Colenso affair and Renan's Vie de Jésus.
Tells Cara Bray and Sara Hennell, 'We are still in a nightmare of uncertainty about our boys' - a reflection of an anxiety which had lasted through much of the summer (Cross 2: 364).
Begin 12 days in Richmond.
Thanks Mary Cash for sending a portrait of her mother.
Thornton Lewes embarks for South Africa. Tells Sara Hennell she is 'taking a deep bath of other people's thoughts' (Cross 2: 366).
Trollope sends a gift of his newly published novel, Rachel Ray.
Congratulates Trollope on Rachel Ray, and on his writing in general.
Move to The Priory.
Blackwood reports disappointing sales of the Cheap edition of the novels.
Complains to Journal, 'I long very much to have done thinking of upholstery, and to get again a consciousness that there are better things than that to reconcile one with life' (Letters 2: 367).
Invites Bessie Parkes to bring Isa Craig to call.
Housewarming at The Priory; also the occasion of Charles Lewes's twenty-first birthday.
Sends Maria Congreve an account of the move to The Priory and of the housewarming party, and brings D’Albert up to date with family news.

Acknowledges gift of Cara Bray’s Physiology for Schools: ' I thank you, dear Cara, not simply for giving me the book, but for having put so much faithful labour in a worthy direction' (Letters 2: 370).
Visited, and impressed, by Robert Buchanan.
Tells Sara Hennell that reading Renan's Vie de Jésus has lessened her opinion of his mind.
Tells Clementia Taylor, 'I am wonderfully well in body, but rather in a self-indulgent state mentally, saying Soul, take thine ease, after a dangerous example' (Cross 2: 373).
GHL retrospectively records in his Journal, 'In a domestic sense it has been a checquered (sic) year', mentioning problems with his children and with The Priory (Letters 4: 126).

Sends good wishes to Maria Congreve, who is visiting Italy in an effort to improve her husband's health: 'I please myself that you will all come back with stores of strength and delightful memories' (Letters 2: 374).

Tells Sara Hennell of her recent interest in the personality and writings of Robert Buchanan, and reports the high opinion of Cara Bray's British Empire entertained by Herbert Spencer 's father. Writes to Hedwig Sauppe, an old Weimar acquaintance, stating that permission to translate Romola should be obtained from the publisher.
Death of half-brother Robert Evans.
Thanks her nephew Robert Evans for news of the death of his father.
Entertain Theodore Martin and Anthony Trollope.
Sympathises with Bessie Parkes on the death of her friend Adelaide Proctor.
Watches Kate Bateman in Augustin Daly's Leah the Forsaken.
GHL suggests GE should write a play for Helen Faucit, and sketches a plot himself. This is perhaps Savello, for details of which see Letters 4: 132-3.
Writes a letter of sympathy to Robert Evans's widow, Jane.
F. W. Burton asks to take her portrait.
Pleased to hear of Clementia Taylor's interest in 'David Gray' by Robert Buchanan: 'It is good for us all that these true stories should be well told' (Cross 2: 378).
Asks Cara Bray to call when she visits Sydenham. Blackwood sends a cheque for £150, again reporting poor sales of the Cheap edition.
Thanked by widow of Robert Evans for her letter of sympathy, and told that Bede was the last book he read.
Sends Sara Hennell an autograph of Sir John Herschel.

Shares Clementia Taylor's delight at Northern successes in the American Civil War, also remarking, 'I wish an immortal drama could be got out of my sorrows, that people might be the better for them two thousand years hence. But fog, east wind, and headache are not great dramatic motives' (Cross 2: 380--1).
Spend a week in Glasgow, seeing Helen Faucit act.
Delighted to receive animated first letter from Thornton in South Africa, and reports selected details of it to Barbara Bodichon. Visit Leighton's studio.
Visited by Herbert Spencer, discussing his relation to Comte.
See Mulready 's pictures at the South Kensington Museum.
Thanks Mary Marshall for sending news of the death of her mother (also Mary Marshall), an aunt of Cara Bray and Sara Hennell.
Attend working-class deputation to Garibaldi at Crystal Palace, meeting F. D. Maurice.
First meeting, at a Covent Garden performance of Rossini's William Tell, with the Lehmanns, soon to become close friends.
Informs Sara Hennell of her impending departure for Italy. Tells Nina Lehmann that she hopes to be able to accept her invitation to dinner.
Thanked by Smith for 'Brother Jacob', which had been given to the Cornhill gratis as a result of the comparative failure of Romola.
Set out for Italy with Frederic Burton, the holiday lasting seven weeks. On their visit to Venice the idea for The Spanish Gypsy occurs to GE.
Asks Theodosia Trollope if it will be possible to visit her on their journey from Venice to the Alps.
GHL sends Charles Lewes details of the pleasures of the stay in Venice.
Return to London. Charles Lewes becomes engaged.
Writes to D’Albert with details of their Italian holiday, and of Charles Lewes's engagement.
First meeting with Richard Monckton Milnes.
First sitting for a portrait by Burton. Begins a Spanish drama - later to become The Spanish Gypsy.
Reading Newman's Apologia with 'absorbing interest' (Letters IV, 158). Also sends Sara Hennell her views on Holman Hunt's Afterglow in Egypt.
Writes in Journal, 'Horrible scepticism about all things paralysing my mind. Shall I ever be good for anything again? Ever do anything again?' (Cross 2: 386).
Reading Gibbon.
Envies Sara Hennell her opportunities of seeing and hearing J. H. Newman: 'I... should like to make an expedition to Birmingham for that sole end' (Cross 2: 387).
At work on Spanish drama.
Begin two-and-a-half-week stay at Scarborough and Harrogate, taking the waters to improve GHL's health. GE begins to study Spanish. Reading includes Tennyson's Idylls.
Sends Sara Hennell details of their early experiences in Yorkshire.
Return to The Priory, GE much gratified by the improvement in GHL's health, though this is not finally restored until November.
Invites Maria Congreve to stay the following weekend.
Finishes first draft of Act I of Spanish drama.
Tells Maria Congreve that her visit was 'pure delight' (Cross 2: 390).
Begins Act II of Spanish drama.
Sits for her portrait by Burton.
GHL begins a fortnight's water cure at Malvern.
Reads Act II of Spanish drama to GHL.
'Sticking in the mud continually in the construction of the 3d, 4th, and 5th Act' (Cross 2: 391).
Belatedly sends birthday greetings to Sara Hennell.
'Much malaise and feebleness' (Letters 4: 169). Sends Charles Bray a cheque for unemployed weavers.
GHL records his appointment as an adviser to the Pall Mall Gazette. GE finishes Act III of Spanish drama.

Records in Journal, 'The last year has been unmarked by any trouble except health. . . . The last quarter has made an epoch for me, by the fact that, for the first time in my serious authorship, I have written verse' (Letters 2: 394).
Begins 'My Vegetarian Friend', published as 'A Minor Prophet' in Jubal.
Visited for two nights by Maria Congreve. Thanks George Smith for the gift of an oyster dish.
GHL invites Nina Lehmann to call.
Sends D’Albert her family news.
GHL sends lengthy outline of his conception of the Fortnightly Review to Henry Seymour.

Begin 11 day holiday in Paris, spending six evenings at various theatres, and visiting Comte's house, subsequently telling Maria Congreve, 'Such places, that knew the great dead, always move me deeply; and I had an unexpected sight of interest in the photograph taken at the very last' (Letters 2: 395).
Finishes 'A Minor Prophet'.
Sends her recent news to Sarah Hennell.
Appearance of first number of Pall Mall Gazette.
Visited by Maria Congreve.
Host their first evening party since the previous winter. Sunday afternoon At Homes now begin to replace Saturday evening parties.

Sends Maria Congreve a report of the party: 'If the severest sense of fulfilling a duty could make one's parties pleasant, who so deserving as I? I tum my inward shudders into outward smiles, and talk fast with a sense of lead on my tongue' (Letters 2: 397).
Notes in Journal, 'George has taken my drama away from me,' an action caused by GE's prolonged depression (Cross 2: 397).

Sends Barbara Bodichon the date of Charles's wedding: 'We have loved Gertrude better and better as we have seen more of her, and we both feel that we could have desired no better lot for Charlie' (Letters 8: 333).
Writes 'A Word for the Germans' for the Pall Mall Gazette.
'A Word for the Germans' published.
Much impressed by Helen Faucit’s performance of Rosalind in As You Like It.
Visited by Sara Hennell. Writes to congratulate Helen Faucit on her performance.
Begins two-day stay with the Congreves.
'Servants' Logic' published in the Pall Mall Gazette.

Commiserates with Cara Bray on the death of the Brays' adopted daughter Nelly: 'I don't know whether you strongly share, as I do, the old belief that made men say the gods loved those who died young. It seems to me truer than ever, now life has become more complex, and more problems have to be worked out'  (Cross 2: 400).
Attend marriage of Charles Lewes to Gertrude Hill.
GHL persuaded at a meeting of the stockholders to become editor of the Fortnightly Review.
Notes in Journal, 'I am in deep depression, feeling powerless. I have written nothing but beginnings since I finished a little article for the Pall Mall' (Cross  2: 401).
Sends letter on 'Futile Falsehoods' to Pall Mall Gazette. Begins Felix Holt.
'Futile Falsehoods' published.
Sends article on Lecky's History of Rationalism to Fortnightly.
'Modern Housekeeping' appears in the Pall Mall Gazette.
Herbert Spencer to lunch.
Appearance of first number of Fortnightly, to which GE contributes two articles: 'The Influence of Rationalism' and 'The Grammar of Ornament'. Begin five-day stay in Eastbourne, Sussex.
Explains to Sara Hennell both her own involvement and that of GHL in the Fortnightly.
Finishes Bamford’s Passages from the Life of a Radical. Begins to reread J. S. Mill's Political Economy.
Finishes reading the Annual Register for 1832.
Spends two hours discussing Holt with GHL.
Records in Journal: 'Read again Aristotle's Poetics with fresh admiration' (Cross 2: 404).
Notes in Journal, 'Walked together on Wimbledon Common, in outer and inner sunshine, as of old; then dined with Mr and Mrs Congreve, and had much pleasant talk.'
Reads opening of Holt to GHL.
Reading Shakespeare's King John.
Again attends Faust at Covent Garden.
Writes to Clementia Taylor about J. S. Mill, whose work she has been reading in recent weeks.
Last sitting for Burton portrait.
Records in Journal that she is working 'doggedly' at Holt, 'seeing what determination can do in the face of despair' (Cross 2: 406). Reading Daniel Neal's History of the Puritans.
Maria Congreve to lunch.
Sends a lengthy letter of news to Cara Bray.
Declines to contribute to fund for Mazzini under the present terms.
Finishes reading Aeschylus's Agamemnon for the second time.
Leave for month in Normandy and Brittany, GE keeping a Journal of their travels.
Illustrated edition of Romola printed. Probably published later this month.

Return from a month's holiday in Normandy and Brittany. (For itinerary, see Cross 2: 409.) Subsequently reports to Sara Hennell: 'Our travelling in Brittany was a good deal marred and obstructed by the Emperor's fête. . . . But the Norman churches, the great cathedrals at Le Mans, Tours, and Chartres, with their marvellous painted glass, were worth much scrambling to see' (Cross 2: 412).

Sympathises with Sara Hennell following the death of her friend Joanna Bonham Carter, and reaffirms their friendship: 'the delight I had in you, and in the hours we spent together, is really part of my life, and can never die out of me' (Cross 2: 410).
Helps Sara Hennell with the title of Present Religion.
Reaches p. 74 in manuscript of Holt.
Shown several memorabilia of E. B. Browning by Robert Browning, a developing admirer.
Discusses David Masson’s Recent British Philosophy in letter to Sara Hennell.
Reading includes Henry Fawcett, The Economic Position of the English Labourer; J. S. Mill, On Liberty; Daniel Neal, History of the Puritans (vol. IV now reached); and Strauss's second Life of Jesus.
Writes Mr Lyon's story (ch. 6 of Holt). Reads the Bible.
Reaches end of ch. 7 of Holt.
Finishes Neal's History. Begins Hallam's View of the State of Europe during the Middle Ages.

Sends Maria Congreve Trollope's Orley Farm and The Small House at Allington, also telling her, 'I think more of you than you are likely to imagine, and I believe we talk of you all more than of any other mortals' (Cross 2: 414).
Hear Handel's Israel in Egypt at the Exeter Hall.
Finishes eh. 10 of Holt.
Sends a lengthy letter of personal news to D’Albert.

Clarifies her views of Dissent and Establishment in letter to Gertrude Lewes: 'as a system of thought . . . the Church of England is the least morally dignified of all forms of Christianity . . . but as a portion of my earliest associations and most poetic memories, it would be more likely to tempt me into partiality than any other form of dissent' (Letters 4: 214).
Records in Journal, 'For two days I have been sticking in the mud from doubt about my construction . . .' (Cross 2: 415).
Invites Harrison to visit, subsequently seeking his advice on legal problems in Holt, which give rise to a considerable correspondence during this month,
Entertain Huxley, Beesly, Burton, Spencer and Harrison.
Discusses Proudhon and Courbet in letter to Barbara Bodichon.
Begin fortnight in Tunbridge Wells.
Reports to Maria Congreve an improvement in GHL's health.

Sends Sarah Hennell an account of the stay at Tunbridge: 'Alas! we had chiefly bad weather... George was a little benefited, but only a little . . . After the notion I have given you of my health, you will not wonder if I say that I don't know when anything of mine will appear. I can never reckon on myself' (Letters 2: 424).
Reading Theocritus, Mill's Logic, and books on English history and law.
Anthony Trollope to lunch.
Hear Joachim, Piatti and Hallé in music by Beethoven at St James's Hall.
Reads the existing manuscript of Holt to GHL.
Records sickness hindering progress in previous fortnight. Now working on chs 30-1 of Holt.

Writes to Sara Hennell, 'I torment myself less with fruitless regrets that my particular life has not been more perfect. The young things are growing, and to me it is not melancholy but joyous that the world will be brighter after I am gone than it has been in the brief time of my existence' (Cross 2: 425).
Notes the poor progress of Gladstone's Reform Bill in the Commons. Again seeks Harrison's advice.
Manuscript of Holt vol. II completed.
Begins vol. III of Holt manuscript.
GHL tells Blackwood that Holt should be ready for publication by the end of May, and invites him to make an offer for the copyright.
Blackwood expresses his satisfaction that GE should be contemplating a return to his firm, but declines to make a definite offer until he has been able to see the manuscript.
Manuscript of vols I and II sent for Blackwood's opinion.
Blackwood describes his delight with the opening of Holt.
Blackwood offers £5000 for five-year copyright of Holt, and expresses himself 'lost in wonder and admiration of Mrs Lewes's powers' (Letters 4: 243).

GHL accepts Blackwood's offer: 'It is a great pleasure to me to be writing to you again, as in the old days. After your kind LettersI am chiefly anxious that the publication of Felix Holt may be a satisfaction to you from beginning to end' (Letters 2: 427).
Blackwood sends a lengthier encomium.

Describes to Blackwood some of the research for, and depression caused by, Holt, and thanks him for his enthusiasm: 'Your letter has made me feel, more strongly than any other testimony, that it would have been a pity if I had listened to the tempter Despondency' (Letters 2: 428).
Begin a week's stay near Dorking to improve GHL's health. GHL requests Blackwood to offer the right of translation of Holt into German to Frederick Lehmann.
Harrison answers queries on transportation, and noncombatants being made prisoners of war.
Tells William Blackwood of her satisfaction in returning to the firm, and that there is now no need to print epistolary sections of Holt in italic.
Harrison offers four legal comments on the trial scene. GE writes to Harrison agreeing to alter the scene so that Esther will become the last witness.
Finishes Holt, subsequently remarking to Maria Congreve, 'As soon as I had finished I felt well' (Cross  2: 430).
Harrison concludes his legal examination of the proofs, and congratulates GE on the accuracy of her researches.
Final proof of Holt handed over to Blackwood and his nephew, who call to express their delight in the novel's conclusion.
Visit GHL's mother.
Blackwood and his nephew to lunch. Writes to Cara Bray regretting the impossibility of a meeting before she and GHL begin their holiday. See Donizetti's L'Elisir d'amore.
Leave for Holland, Belgium and Germany.
See the Oberammergau passion play presented in Antwerp.
Holt published, and soon accorded excellent reviews.
E. G. Bulwer-Lytton sends Blackwood a two-sided response to Holt.
Thanks Blackwood for sending details of the favourable reception of Holt, and sends him news of their holiday.
Sends Maria Congreve an account of the progress of their holiday: 'Already we feel great benefit from our quiet journeying and repose' (Cross 2: 433).
Blackwood again enlarges on the reception of Holt, dismissing The Times's claim that the trial scene had been suggested by a recent novel of Charles Reade's.
Harrison writes of Holt’s excellent reception, and hopes that GE may be able to produce a Positivist work of art.
Blackwood tells GHL, 'I do not know that I ever saw a Novel received with a more universal acclaim than Felix' (Letters 4: 289).
Return home from continental tour. Invites the Congreves to dine in the course of the corning week.
Trollope thanks GE for Holt: 'To me the great glory of Felix Holt is the fulness of thought which has been bestowed on it. . . . I think its success is unrivalled' (Letters 8: 381).
Asks Harrison to visit soon. Expresses to Blackwood her approval of the physical appearance of the three volumes of Holt.
Thanks Trollope for his praise of Holt.

Sends Sara Hennell an account of their travels, including the Oberarnmergau passion play: 'All the rest was inferior, and might even have had a painful approach to the ludicrous; but both the person and the action of the Jesus were fine enough to overpower all meaner impressions. Mr Lewes . . . felt what I am saying quite as much as I did, and was much moved' (Cross 2: 438).
Regrets having to decline an invitation to visit her nephew Robert Evans and his wife because of the pressures of preparing for Bertie's departure for South Africa.

Replies to Harrison’s request with a lengthy letter on aesthetic and novelistic problems, promising to bear 'the great possibility (or impossibility)' of his suggestion in mind. Also reveals that she is going to rework Gypsy (Cross  2: 442).
Notes in Journal, 'I have taken up the idea of my drama, The Spanish Gypsy, again, and am reading on Spanish subjects - Bouterwek, Sismondi, Depping, Llorente, &c.' (Cross  2: 439).
Tells Blackwood that she is 'swimming in Spanish history and literature' (Cross 2: 444).
Give farewell dinner party for Bertie Lewes, who sets out the next day to join Thornton in South Africa.
Blackwood, slightly disappointed at the sale of Holt in three volumes, suggests reprinting the novel in two.
Agrees to Blackwood’s proposal.
Sends an unusually semi-confessional letter of sympathy to the American journalist Harriet Peirce.
Journal recalls, 'Finished Depping’s Juifs au Moyen Age. Reading Chaucer, to study English. Also reading on Acoustics, Musical Instruments, &c.' (Cross 2: 445).
Sends D’Albert her domestic news.
Gertrude Lewes's first child dies as a result of an accident during birth.
Thanks Sara Hennell for her sympathy over the loss of Gertrude's baby.
Decides on new form for Gypsy.
Encourages Blackwood's scheme for an illustrated edition of the novels.
GHL resigns editorship of the Fortnightly. Trollope writes regretting the resignation, and asking GHL's opinion of John Morley as a possible successor.

Reading Renan, Histoire des langues sémitiques, and Ticknor, Spanish Literature. Thanks Sara Hennell for her birthday greetings: 'I am very well now, and able to enjoy my happiness. One has happiness sometimes without being able to enjoy it' (Letters 2: 446).
Finish a week at Tunbridge Wells, where reading includes works on astronomy and history, and Spanish ballads on Bernardo del Carpio.

Tells Sara Hennell, 'No, I don't feel as if my faculties were failing me. On the contrary, I enjoy all subjects - all study - more than I ever did in my life before. But that very fact makes me more in need of resignation to the certain approach of age and death. Science, history, poetry - I don't know which draws me most, and there is little time left me for any of them' (Cross  2: 446-7).
Thornton writes to say he has bought a farm at Wakkerstroom in the Transvaal.
Publication of the (two-volume) edition of Holt. Thanks Jane Senior for the offer of the use of a house in Spain, but declines, chiefly on the grounds of GHL’s ill health.
Blackwood, though noting that sales have been disappointing, sends first instalment of £1666 for Holt.
Regrets having been out when Eliza Linton called, and hopes her visit will soon be repeated.
Blackwood formally suggests a stereotyped (and illustrated) edition of GE’s works and offers terms: £5000 for five novels for five years.
GE accepts Blackwood's offer.
Thanks George Smith for the gift of a travelling bag.
Set out for France and Spain, chiefly to improve GHL's health.
Meet Renan in Paris.
Sends Barbara Bodichon a description of their journey so far, including their encounter with Renan.
Again studying Spanish.
Reading Comte. GE tells Maria Congreve, 'My gratitude increases continually for the illumination Comte has contributed to my life' (Cross 3: 3-4), and also sends her an account of their travels.
See Nina Lehmann at Pau.
Reports to George Smith the usefulness of the travelling bag.
Gives Barbara Bodichon details of their travels, and mentions their proposed itinerary.
Harrison, in the Pall Mall Gazette, proves the folly of a legal criticism of Holt in the Edinburgh Review.

Thanks Harrison for his Pall Mall article, also telling him, 'Just now we read nothing but Spanish novels - and not much of those. We said good-bye to philosophy and science when we packed up our trunks at Biarritz' (Cross 3: 10).
Informs Blackwood of her literary purpose in visiting Spain, and of the success of the trip.
Tells Maria Congreve, 'Mr Lewes says he thinks he never enjoyed a journey so much' (Cross 3: 12).
Return to London from Spain. GE resumes work on Gypsy.
Blackwood sends £2166, but reports a scant sale for the second edition of Holt.
Tells Blackwood of her Spanish poem, written and then put by in 1864, of which GHL is now hopeful, and of 'private projects about an English novel' (Cross 3: 16).
Sends Cara Bray details of their holiday, likening Renan's manner to that of an amiable Dissenting minister.
Receives first number of Bede, which commences the Stereotyped edition of the novels.
Urges Cara Bray to call on her when in town.
Sends news of their holiday to D’Albert.
GHL's fiftieth birthday.
Attends the first of Congreve's Positivist lectures.
Writes to Barbara Bodichon, discussing the death of a neighbour, Joseph Neuberg, and a visit to the historical-portrait collection at South Kensington.
The Calls to dinner.
Attends Congreve's lecture again, noting decreased attendance
Writes to Sara Hennell about the Congreve lectures.
Discusses female enfranchisement in letter to Morley, telling him that her attitude is very nearly his own.
Attends Congreve.
Thanks Jane Senior for advice on millinery.
Attends Congreve.
See Academy exhibition.

Agrees with Clementia Taylor's desire 'to see women socially elevated - educated equally with men, and secured as far as possible along with every breathing creature from suffering the exercise of any unrighteous power' (Cross 3: 18). Tells Blackwood of her delight with the Stereotyped edition of Bede, and especially with the title-page vignette.
Reaches the point of Fedalma's appearance in the Plaça in Gypsy.
Blackwood to dinner. Reads him, to his pleasure, the first 56 pages of Gypsy manuscript.
Spend day at Eton with Oscar Browning.
Begin fortnight on the Isle of Wight.
Return from Isle of Wight.
Blackwood sends cheque for £2166, but reports the near-failure of the Stereotyped edition of the novels.
Replies to a letter from Cara Bray, mentioning Arthur Helps's unsuccessful china-day speculation, and giving details of the two portraits of her by Burton and Laurence.
Thanks Oscar Browning for sending her a chair. Tells Smith her new production (i.e. Gypsy) will not be suitable for the Cornhill.
Read Congreve’s 'Mr Broadhead and the Anonymous Press', a defence of the instigator of the Sheffield trade-union outrages.
Tells Maria Congreve of her cordial satisfaction with Congreve’s pamphlet.
Leave for Germany, meeting Edmund Benson and his wife on the Channel crossing. Much reading of Tennyson on this tour.
Reading Shakespeare's Pericles and Venus and Adonis (which GHL finds 'wretched stuff' - Letters 4: 386). Send news of their travels to Charles Lewes.
Advises Emanuel Deutsch to send the proof of his article on the Talmud to her at Dresden.
New Reform Bill receives the royal assent, greatly extending the franchise. GE draws on this event when writing Middlemarch.
GHL sends Charles Lewes details of their daily programme during their stay at Ilmenau.

Return to London. Records in Journal, 'We returned home after revisiting the scenes of cherished memories - Ilmenau, Dresden, and Berlin. Of new places we have seen Wetzlar, Cassel, Eisenach, and Hanover. At Ilmenau I wrote Fedelma’s soliloquy after her scene with Silva, and the following dialogue between her and Juan. At Dresden I re-wrote the whole scene between her and Zarca' (Cross 3: 21).
Thanks Blackwood for sending grouse while they were away - the grouse were forwarded to, and eaten by, GHL's mother.
Reading Percy's Reliques.
Begins Gypsy-camp scene of Gypsy. Finishes reading Los Judios en España. Also reading Iliad book III.
Begins reading Prescott's Ferdinand and Isabella.
Warmly recommends Deutsch's article 'The Talmud' in the current Quarterly Review to Sara Hennell.
GHL and Spencer begin brief walking tour in Surrey, Spencer introducing GHL to the Cross family.
Writes to Blackwood expressing admiration for Theodore Martin's Memoir of W. E. Aytoun.

Journal records, 'I have now inserted all that I think of for the first part of The Spanish Gypsy. On Monday I wrote three new Lyrics. I have also re-written the first three scenes in the Gypsy camp, to the end of the dialogue between Juan and Fedalma. But I have determined to make the commencement of the second part continue the picture of what goes forward in Bedmar' (Cross 3: 23).
Begins book II of Gypsy. Stereotyped edition of Mill published.

Congratulates Harrison on his article 'Culture: A Dialogue' in the current Fortnightly, also discussing her qualified veneration of Browning. Blackwood, singing Disraeli's praises, suggests GE write an address to working men for his magazine, and sign it Felix Holt.

Asks Blackwood to put the beginning of Gypsy in type, but to keep the poem's existence a secret. Tells him of her disappointment at the lack of success of the Stereotyped edition, especially among young men, 'who are just the class I care most to influence' (Cross 3: 25).
