Writes to Cara Bray to express delight at the promise of a visit from her.
Blackwood urges the case for the proposed 'Address to Working Men', reminding GE of the topicality of the Reform issue.
Invites Emily Davies to discuss her plans for a college for women (eventually Girton College, Cambridge).
Discussion with Emily Davies.
Emily Davies tells Barbara Bodichon that GE 'said she thought the higher education of women was the thing about which there could be no doubt' (Letters 8: 409).
Begins 'Address to Working Men, by Felix Holt' for Blackwood’s. Urges Emily Davies to raise funds on a major scale, also telling Sara Hennell of her enthusiasm for the Women's College scheme.
Blackwood expresses his enthusiasm for Gypsy and satisfaction on hearing of progress with the 'Address'.
Sends manuscript of Address to Working Men to Blackwood.
Hears part of debate on Abyssinia in House of Commons.
Returns proof of 'Address' to Blackwood.

Thanks Blackwood for the revised proofs of the 'Address', but remarks, 'I feel the danger of not being understood. Perhaps, by a good deal longer consideration and gradual shaping, I might have put the ideas into a more concrete easy form' (Cross 3: 27).
Consoles Emanuel Deutsch after the attacks made on his article.
Reading Herbert Spencer's First Principles.

'George and I dined happily alone: he better for weeks than he has been all the summer before, - I more ailing than usual, but with much mental consolation, part of it being the delight he expresses in my poem' (Cross 3: 28).
Reports herself depressed by the troubled state of European affairs and threat of war.
GHL leaves for Germany for research on his Problems of Life and Mind.
Blackwood sends payment of £25 for 'Address'.
GHL returns to London, having 'had a brilliant time, gained great instruction, and seen some admirable men who received him warmly' (Cross 3: 33).
Thanks Maria Congreve for gift of mittens.
Tells Arthur Helps of her enjoyment in reading Queen Victoria's Leaves from the Journal of our Life in the Highlands.
Begin three-day visit to Tunbridge Wells to improve their health. Some proofs of Gypsy corrected there.
Writes to D’Albert with family news and distress at national and international affairs.
Finishes book III of Gypsy.
Helps Charles Lewes with his translation of Lessing’s Emilia Galotti.
Begin two-day visit to Cambridge.
Writes affectionately to Jane Senior, promising to communicate again on their return from Torquay.
Begin month at Torquay, Devon, where GE finishes Gypsy book IV, and GHL works at articles on Darwin.
Deplores spoilt nature of Torquay in letter to Sara Hennell: 'Our selfishness does not adapt itself well to these oncomings of the millennium' (Cross 3: 35).
Discusses technical details of Gypsy edition, including the poem's length, in letter to Blackwood.
Blackwood sends favourable comments on books II and III of Gypsy.
Requests Blackwood to change spelling of Fidalma to Fedelma in proof passim.
Return to London from Torquay.

Thanks Maria Congreve for the gift of her husband's pamphlet on Ireland on which she gives an opinion, and offering to contribute towards the expenses of publishing his translation of Comte's Positive Polity.
Goes to see Holman Hunt's Isabella and the Pot of Basil.

Sends Blackwood the manuscript of book IV of Gypsy, and reports that she has been persuaded by GHL to return to the original ending. Gives permission for Carl Buchheim to include extracts from her works in his Materials for German Prose Composition.
Blackwood expresses his enthusiasm for what he has seen of Gypsy.
Gypsy completed.
Blackwood offers £300 for first edition of Gypsy.
Queries the terms for Gypsy. Thanks Mary Cash for the gift of her Credentials of Conscience.
Tells Cara Bray that she is apprehensive of what the public will think of her turning to poetry.
Attends lecture by Deutsch on the Talmud.
Blackwood refuses to revise his offer for Gypsy.
Accepts Blackwood’s offer.

Gypsy published. Harrison sends thanks in advance for his presentation copy, and reminds GE of his Positivist suggestion of 19 July 1866. GE gracefully sidesteps Harrison's request: 'It would be better for you to encourage the growth towards a realisation in your own mind, rather than trust in transplantation' (Cross 3: 51).
Leave for two months in Germany and Switzerland (for itinerary see Letters 2: 52). Reading whilst there includes Morris's Earthly Paradise.
The Times praises Gypsy.
The Spectator follows suit.
GHL declines permission for dramatisation of Gypsy.
Sends Charles Lewes an account of their stay in Petersthal.
Visit peasant's cottage at St Margen (partly the inspiration for 'Agatha').
Return to London.
Reports to Blackwood on their holiday: 'I think we were hardly ever, except in Spain, so long ignorant of home sayings and doings' (Cross 3: 54).
Blackwood reports reasonable sale of Gypsy, but generally poor reviews: 'The reviewers have looked perseveringly for faults and shut their eyes to the beauties' (Letters 4: 460-1).
GE replies, 'I am serene, because I only expected the unfavourable' (Letters 3: 55). Darwin suggests that he and GHL exchange photographs.
Thanks the Revd William MacIlwaine for pointing out errata in Gypsy.
Darwin writes to tell GHL that his recent articles on Darwin’s work have been excellent.
Writes to Emily Davies on the physical and spiritual differences between the sexes.
Thanks F. D. Maurice for the gift of his The Conscience: Lectures on Casuistry.
Begin three-day visit to Allbutt at Leeds, visiting a large art exhibition held in aid of the Leeds Infirmary. For details see Cross 3: 75-8.
Warmly invites the Congreves to attend a meal of their choice.
Corrects Gypsy for third edition. Reading A. W. Kinglake, The Invasion of the Crimea. Visited by the Congreves, with whom they go to the Zoo.
Reads article on Ostrovsky by W.R. Shedden-Ralston in the July issue of Edinburgh Review.
Requests piano arrangements of Verdi's best operas.
Blackwood reports second [sic] edition of Gypsy nearly sold out.
Tells Blackwood that she is brooding on many subjects and hopes that the coming months will not be barren.
Spends the night with the Congreves, Richard Congreve commenting on Positivist strains in Gypsy.
Begin week at Sheffield and Matlock, touring an iron works at the former, and at the latter revisiting places previously seen in the company of her father.
Harrison congratulates GE on Gypsy, and gives his developing views on its meaning.
Invites Maria Congreve to stay. Returns proofs for third edition of Gypsy. GHL asks Darwin if he may be allowed to call on him.

Writes to Barbara Bodichon about the visit to Matlock, reflecting that 'I am one of those perhaps exceptional people whose early childish dreams were much less happy than the real outcome of life' (Cross 3: 65).
Darwin proposes GHL for the Linnean Society.
Tells Sara Hennell about her Northern holiday, and sends news of Herbert Spencer.

Records in Journal, 'The return of this St Cecilia’s Day finds me in better health than has been usual with me in these last six months. But I am not yet engaged in any work that makes a higher life for me - a life that is young and grows, though in my other life I am meditating the subject of Timoleon' (Cross 3: 67).
Suggests Blackwood advertises third edition of Gypsy more prominently.
Blackwood apologises and reports over 700 copies of the edition sold.
Tells Maria Congreve with pleasure of the speed with which that 'mass of Positivism', Gypsy, has sold (Cross 3: 68).

Congratulates Charles Bray on his arguments against the ballot: 'It has been a source of amazement to me that men acquainted with practical life can believe in the suppression of bribery by the ballot, as if bribery in all its protean forms could ever disappear by means of a single external arrangement' (Letters 3: 68-9).
Blackwood sends cheque for £333 for first two editions of The Spanish Gypsy.

Records in Journal considerable satisfaction with the passing year, desiring that in the next year 'I may do some good lasting work, and make both my outward and inward habits less imperfect - that is, more directly leading to the best uses of life' (Cross 3: 70).
Tells Blackwood that she deeply regrets that Browning has spent his powers on a subject unworthy of his talent, and hopes that she may finish some new work in the coming year.
First mention of Middlemarch, though thought of since completion of Holt. Again considers Timoleon as subject for a poem.
Reminds Barbara Bodichon of loan of a shilling from one of GE's servants.
GHL learns of Thornton's illness, believed at this point to be a kidney stone.
GHL tells Blackwood of his instruction to Thornton to return to England: 'The vision of him haunts me incessantly' (Letters 5: 4).
Probable first visit to The Priory of Emilia Pattison, a disputed model for certain features of Dorothea.
GHL writes to invite Charles Eliot Norton and wife to lunch. (For a full account of their visit, see Norton's letter to G. W. Curtis, Letters 5: 7-9).
GE, in thanking Oscar Browning for greetings on his birthday, refers to 'the growth of a maternal feeling towards both men and women who are much younger than myself' (Letters 5: 5).
Thanks Susan Norton for gift of James Russell Lowell's Under the Willows and Other Poems.
Poem 'Agatha' completed. Complains in Journal of ill-health since the New Year, and records characteristically wide reading, including Byron, Clough, Jonson and Spenser.
Begins 'How Lisa Loved the King'. Reading Bright's speeches, Manzoni's I Promessi sposi, and Mommsen's Rome.
Company at the by now much-frequented Sunday afternoon At Homes includes Emilia Pattison, Eliza Lynn Linton, Burton, Palgrave, and Holland.
Writes the song of Minuccio in 'How Lisa Loved the King'.

Hear Clara Schumann play at a Pops Concert. GE reading inter alia Arnold's poetry, and a speech by Bright on the Irish question. Reads a 'deservedly high' appreciation of Lowell's poems in the Spectator (Cross 3: 77).
Visited by D. G. Rossetti.
Susan Norton and her daughters lunch at The Priory.
Entertain Spencer and Sara Hennell to dinner, the latter also staying the night.
Poem 'How Lisa Loved the King' finished. Invites J.B. Payne to discuss Gypsy. Sunday afternoon guests include Browning, Harrison, the Pattisons and Barbara Bodichon.
'How Lisa Loved the King’ sent off to Blackwood. Writes to Sara Hennell elucidating the mention of Elisha in Browning's The Ring and the Book.
Blackwood expresses his admiration for 'How Lisa Loved the King' and offers £50 for it.

Tells Blackwood of her intention of commencing Middlemarch immediately, the various elements of the story having been 'soliciting my mind for years', and the plan being sketched already: 'But between the beginning and the middle of a book I am like the lazy Scheidt; between the middle and the end I am like the arrowy Rhône' (Letters 5: 16).
Emanuel Deutsch and Emilia Pattison to lunch.
Apologises to Blackwood over difficulties caused by corrections in 'How Lisa Loved the King'.
Goes to see Michelangelo’s Entombment with Barbara Bodichon. Blackwood explains reasons for declining permission for 'How Lisa Loved the King' to appear in the Atlantic Monthly.
Set out for Italy, staying in Florence (20-5 Mar, 23-7 Apr), Naples (26 Mar--4 Apr), and Rome (4--21 Apr), travelling out via Paris, Lyon and Marseille, and returning via Munich.
Arrive for a six-day stay in Florence with the Tom Trollopes.
Visit Pompeii.
Notifies Blackwood of errors in revise of 'How Lisa Loved the King'.
GHL's fifty-second birthday - forgotten by both him and GE. Visited at Rome by Anna Cross and her son John Walter - their first encounter.
Tells Maria Congreve, 'Our long journey... has been a history of ailments' (Cross 3: 79).
Return to London. 'How Lisa Loved the King' published in Blackwood's.

GE sends a lengthy and personal letter to Harriet Beecher Stowe, acknowledging gratefully the warrant to call her friend; and thanks Robert Lytton for drawing attention to linguistic errors in Gypsy: 'For in authorship I hold carelessness to be a mortal sin' (Letters 5: 33).

Thornton returns from South Africa suffering from tuberculosis of the spine, the preface to five months of suffering; GE writes a long, affectionate letter to HBS the same day (but later seems to forget that she wrote it, probably due to the stress of the day).

Visited for the first time by Henry James. He comments, 'Yes, behold me literally in love with this great horse-faced bluestocking' (Haight, p. 417). Thornton, as James soon discovers, in very considerable pain.
Acknowledges Blackwood’s payment of £50 for 'How Lisa Loved the King', and expresses anxiety over Thornton's condition.
Asks Barbara Bodichon to visit Thornton.
Visited by American publisher James T. Fields, who proposes uniform American edition of GE's works.
Thornton visited in GE's absence by his mother, Agnes Lewes, Paget having pronounced the illness very serious.
Authorises Fields Osgood's uniform American edition of the novels.
'Agatha’ sold to Fields Osgood for the Atlantic Monthly for £300. Writes to invite Emanuel Deutsch to lunch.
Writes to Maria Congreve, giving her details of Thornton's illness.
Tells Browning of Frances Julia Wedgwood's admiration for his work.
Congratulates Frederic Harrison on his engagement and hopes that he will call.
Tells Cara Bray of Thornton's illness, and asks her to send her own news.
Writes to Barbara Bodichon to correct any impression of irreverence or flippancy in a discussion of Mark Pattison.
Sends Barbara Bodichon an account of Thornton's condition.

Journal records the completion of five 'Brother and Sister’ sonnets, partly the result of the contemplation of childhood involved in preparing for Middlemarch. Reading includes Lucretius; Hugo, L'Homme qui rit; and von Hillern, Ein Arzt der Seele.
Visited by Cara Bray.

Apologises to Cara Bray for behaviour at their recent meeting, and to Harriet Beecher Stowe for the break in their correspondence necessitated by Thornton's illness: 'We have both been absorbed in our new duties to this poor child, and have felt our own health and nervous energy insufficient for our needful activity of body and mind' (Cross 3: 91). Has enjoyed Stowe's Oldtown Folks.
Return from a two-day stay in Hatfield, Hertfordshire.
Begins Nisard's History of French Literature.
Journal records discussion of women's suffrage at Sunday afternoon At Home.
Writing introduction to Middlemarch. Three further 'Brother and Sister’ sonnets completed.
Tells Cara Bray of an improvement in Thornton's condition. Reading Reybaud, Les Réformateurs modernes.
'I read aloud Fourier and Owen, and thought of writing something about Utopists' (Cross 3: 96).
Reading Plato's Republic selectively.
Reads Shakespeare's sonnets. 'Brother and Sister’ sonnets finished.
Begins writing Viney-Featherstone part of Middlemarch.
First chapter of Middlemarch completed. Reading Renouard's History of Medicine.
Thornton becomes paraplegic.
Apologises to Emilia Pattison for outburst of motherly affection.
GHL forced to engage new nurse for Thornton, Charlotte Lee's health having broken down.
Tells Cara Bray of fluctuations in Thornton's condition. Discusses Mill with Emily Davies.
Comments to Cara Bray on new revelations in Byron's biography, admitting that his poetry has fallen greatly from her favour.
Reaches p. 40 of Middlemarch manuscript.
Thanks Barbara Bodichon for sending flowers to Thornton, but reports, 'He is strangely indifferent about everything now' (Letters 8: 467).
Lunch with the Crosses at Weybridge, Surrey. Cross, detailing the visit, records, 'Our visitors had come to the house as acquaintances, they left it as lifelong friends' (Cross 3: 98).
More planning of Middlemarch, now written up to the beginning of ch. 3.
Spend the morning at Hatfield Park.
Thanks Jane Senior for enquiry as to Thornton's (improving) health.

Journal records, 'I have achieved little during the last week, except reading on medieval subjects - Encyclopaedia about the Medical Colleges, Cullen's Life, Russell's Heroes of Medicine, &c, I have also read Aristophanes' Ecclesiazusae and Macbeth' Letters 3: 99).
Despondent about the prospects for Middlemarch.

Records further difficulties in work on Middlemarch. Visited by Maria Congreve, and asks her to supply information about provincial hospitals. Counsels Sara Hennell to take regular holidays, and discusses Byron, who 'seems to me the most vulgar-minded genius that ever produced a great effect in literature' (Letters 3: 100).
Begin three-day visit to Watford, Hertfordshire.
Records 'great depression' (Cross 3: 100).

Tells Jane Senior, 'There is no subject on which I am more inclined to hold my peace and learn, than on the Women Question', at the same time expressing her steadfast belief in the necessity of equal educational opportunities for women (Letters 5: 58).

'Ever since the 28th I have been good for little, ailing in body and disabled in mind.... I have begun a long-meditated poem, The Legend of Jubal, but have not written more than twenty or thirty verses' (Cross 3: 101).

Reading Lecky's History of Morals, having recently finished Müller's History of Sanskrit Literature, and Spencer's Psychology. Approximately 100 verses of 'Jubal' completed. Thornton increasingly weak.
Sends greetings to Oscar Browning on his return from Russia.
Thornton dies with GE at his side. Confides to Journal, 'This death seems to me the beginning of our own' (Letters 5: 19).
Writes to Cara Bray about Thornton's death.
Thanks Barbara Bodichon for her letter of sympathy. 'Just now all else seems trivial compared with the powers of delighting and soothing a heart that is in need' (Letters 5: 60-1).
Travel to Limpsfield, Surrey, for three-week stay, GHL giving orders that no letters should be forwarded from London.
Thanks Oscar Browning belatedly for the gift of a pair of Russian slippers, and apologises to Emilia Pattison for delay in writing to her.
Return to The Priory from Limpsfield.
GHL describes the previous months of suffering to Blackwood, and reports GE now reflecting more calmly on their loss.
Tells Sara Hennell, 'We both of us felt, more than ever before, the blessedness of being in the country, and we are come back much restored' (Cross 3: 102).
Give copies of their books to Girton College.
Fiftieth birthday.
Tells Barbara Bodichon: 'I have a deep sense of change within, and of a permanently closer relationship with death' (Letters 5: 70).
Last mention of Middlemarch until 7 March 1870.
Informs Harriet Beecher Stowe of Thornton's death in a lengthy letter.
Attend Rosslyn Unitarian Chapel, and visit Thornton's grave. Dine with Charles and Gertrude Lewes.
Enquires after Emilia Pattison.
Maria Congreve dines and stays the night.
Entertains D. G. Rossetti to lunch.
'Jubal', growing partly out of the experience of Thornton's sufferings, completed.
Sends Harrison qualified praise of his article 'The Positivist Problem'.
Thanks Oscar Browning in fulsome terms for his recent letter.
GHL spends three days alone at Hastings in poor spirits as a result of Thornton's death.
Listen to Neruda at St James's Hall.
Called on by Neruda.
Writes to invite Barbara Bodichon to Sunday lunch.
Thanks William Morris for an autographed copy of The Earthly Paradise.
Writes to Emilia Pattison.
Dickens, entertained to lunch, looks exhausted, but tells anecdotes dramatically.
Tells Blackwood that her novel proceeds very slowly (the first mention of Middlemarch since 28 November 1869) and that GHL's health alarms her.
Leave for Germany and Austria in hope of improving GHL's health, badly affected by Thornton's death,
GHL tells his mother of his enthusiastic reception in Berlin.
GHL informs Charles Lewes, 'The Mutter and I have come to the conclusion that the Music of the future is not for us' (Letters 5: 85).
Sends Maria Congreve a report on their holiday so far.
Leave Vienna, where GE had suffered a badly ulcerated throat, for Salzburg.
Return to The Priory.

Commends Emerson’s Society and Solitude in a letter to Oscar Browning; and thanks D. G. Rossetti for an inscribed copy of his Poems: 'I have a gret deal to be acquainted with and to like better and better' (Letters 5: 93).
Barbara Bodichon to dinner.
Accepts invitation to visit the Pattisons. Herbert Spencer to lunch.
Cara Bray to dinner.

Tells Sara Hennell how much she approves of plans to republish Charles Hennell’s Inquiry: 'When I remember my ' own obligation to the book, I must believe that among the many new readers a cheap edition will reach, there must be minds to whom it will bring welcome light in studying the New Testament, - sober, serious help towards a conception of the past instead of stage-lights and make-ups' (III, 105). Dine with distinguished company at Lord Houghton's.
Gratefully accepts portrait of Charles Hennell, and thanks Sara Hennell for her appreciation of 'Jubal'.
Recalls in her Journal her chief activities since Thornton's death, concluding, 'I am not hopeful about future work. I am languid, and my novel languishes too' (Cross  3: 110).
John Blackwood, after an hour's talk with GE, tells his nephew William that GE's new novel 'promises to be something wonderful' (Letters 5: 99).
Begin four-day stay with the Pattisons, GE's first visit to Oxford, meeting Mary Augusta Arnold (later Mrs Humphry Ward), Jowett and Pater. For GE's recollections, see Cross  3: 110.
Gives C. V. Stanford permission to publish musical settings of songs in Gypsy. Reading Dickens's Edwin Drood.
Death of Dickens - 'a great shock to us' (Cross 3: 113).
Acknowledges the gift of a copy of the new edition of Frederick Locker's London Lyrics.
Invites Georgiana Burne-Jones and her children to join GE and GHL on a stay in Whitby.

Set out for East Coast holiday, again aimed at improving GHL's health, staying at Cromer, Harrogate and Whitby. Reading includes Trollope, Vicar of Bullhampton; Balzac, Illusions perdues; Mendelssohn's Letters; Rossetti's Poems; and the latest volume of The Earthly Paradise.
Writes to commiserate with Edith Bulwer-Lytton on the death of her uncle, the Earl of Clarendon: 'for nearly a year death seems to me my most intimate daily companion' (Letters 5: 107; Cross 3: 115).
Urges Georgiana Burne-Jones to join them, delighting in the effect of Harrogate on GHL's health. Reading at Harrogate includes Edwin Drood, and poems by Milton and Rossetti.

GHL sends E. R. Bulwer-Lytton details of their routine at Harrogate, remarking that to be with GE 'is a perpetual Banquet to which that of Plato would present but a flat rival' (Letters 8: 482). Start of Franco-Prussian War, in which GE much interested, and by which much distressed.
Sympathises with Charles and Gertrude Lewes on the death of the latter's aunt, Mary Gillies: 'I think too much, too continually of death' (Letters 5: 110).
Return from East Coast to London.
Records in Journal that the results of the previous two months have not been rich. Begins to write 'Armgart'.

Leave for three weeks at Limpsfield, where most of 'Armgart' is written. Reading includes Lockhart's Life of Walter Scott, J. A. Froude's History of England, and Lettres d'Auguste Comte a M. Valat. The weather was perfect, and the place seemed more lovely to us than before' (Cross 3: 120).
Writes at length to Sara Hennell, with details of East Coast holiday, reading, and family matters.
Declines to write short stories for Scribners.
Comments to Barbara Bodichon on the French defeats.
Return from Limpsfield.
Tells Cara Bray; 'We think of hardly anything but the War, and spend a great portion of our day reading about it' (Letters 5: 114).
Commiserates with Emanuel Deutsch on the onset of illness.
Hear Spurgeon preach for the first time: 'my impressions fell below the lowest judgement I ever heard passed upon him' (Letters 5: 121).
Fifty-first birthday. GHL presents GE with a lockable book for her autobiography.

Records in Journal, 'I am experimenting in a story (Miss Brooke) which I began without any very serious intention of carrying it out lengthily. It is a subject which has been recorded among my possible themes ever since I began to write fiction, but will probably take new shapes in the development. I am today at p. 44' (Cross  3: 126). Reading Wolf's Prolegomena to Homer, and rereading Goethe's Wilhelm Meister. Indicates willingness to increase financial support for Octavia Hill's Walmer Street Industrial Experiment.
Blackwood lunches with GE and GHL, and reports decision to combine 'Miss Brooke' with Middlemarch.
Death of GHL's mother, aged 83.
Begin nine-day visit to Barbara Bodichon at Swanmore, Isle of Wight.
GHL plays practical joke with scourge from the Tractarian Swanmore Parsonage.
Attends Tractarian service at Swanmore with Barbara Bodichon.

'Here is the last day of 1870. I have written only 100 pages - good printed pages - of a story which I began about the opening of November, and at present mean to call Miss Brooke. Poetry halts just now' (ross3: 127). 'In my private lot I am unspeakably happy, loving, and beloved. But I am doing little for others' (Cross 3: 127).
GHL resumes work on Problems of Life and Mind.
GE tentatively (and unsuccessfully) recommends Nassau Senior for Educational Board. Sends New Year greetings to Sara Hennell.
First of several visits to The Priory by Turgenev.
Acknowledges gift of photographs from Julia Margaret Cameron.
Congratulates E. B. Hamley on letter to The Times criticising the ruthlessness of the Prussians in the Franco-Prussian War.
GE sympathises with the French in the war, and tells D’Albert, 'physically I feel old, and Death seems to me very near' (Letters 9: 10).
Turgenev present at one of their parties: 'To see him is to like him,' GHL remarks (Letters 9: 21).
Offers money for Gertrude Lewes to be taken out in a pony carriage.
Thanks Cara Bray for sending review of Edward Noel's Letters.
Inspect cottage at Weybridge.
Confesses in Journal her fear that she has 'too much matter - too many moments 'in Middlemarch. Records having completed about 236 printed pages of the novel (Cross 3: 129).
GHL inspects Brookbank, a cottage at Shottermill, near Petersfield, Hampshire.
Tells Cara Bray of the enthusiasm of Anna Maria Bridges for Cara Bray's Duty to Animals.
Congratulates George Howard on arrival of baby.
GHL offers Osgood Ticknor the early sheets of 'Armgart' and invites them to make an offer for Middlemarch.
GHL and GE inspect Shottermill and engage servant there.
Thanks Anne Gilchrist for her help in accommodating them at Shottermill.
Fourth edition of GHL's History of Philosophy published.
Enquiries after Mark Pattison’s health, and reproaches his wife for failing to inform her of it.
Writes to D’Albert.
Take up residence at Shottermill. GHL remarks, 'There I shall dig, and dig, and dig at the foundations of philosophy, and she will create' (Letters 9: 14).
Herbert Lewes sends news of opposition to his engagement from his fiancée's parents.
GHL invites Blackwood to visit Shottermill and proposes that Middlemarch be in four volumes.
Marriage of Herbert Lewes to Eliza Harrison.
Blackwood visits, and takes away book I of Middlemarch.
Blackwood expresses intense delight with the opening of Middlemarch.
GHL takes GE to London in attempt to ease the neuralgic pain of the previous months. Quinine prescribed.
Writes to Barbara Bodicon, expressing delight with their stay at Shottermill.
GHL inspects alterations at the Priory.
Cancel acceptance of invitation to attend Scott Festival at Edinburgh in August, on grounds of ill health.
Finishes book II of Middlemarch.
Writes to Charles Lewes regretting the necessity of vacating Shottermill, where health had improved and work proceeded satisfactorily.

Book II of Middlemarch sent to Blackwood. First meeting with Tennyson: 'Tennyson, who is one of the hill-folk about here, has found us out, so that we have lost the utmost perfection of our solitude - the impossibility of a caller' (Letters 5: 169).
GHL accepts Osgood Ticknor’s offer for the American publication of Middlemarch.
Read Keller's 'Romeo und Julia auf dem Dorfe'.
Blackwood expresses delight with book II of Middlemarch.

Agrees with Blackwood that Middlemarch will be long, but remarks, 'I don't see how I can leave anything out, because I hope there is nothing that will be seen to be irrelevant to my design, which is to show the gradual action of ordinary causes rather than exceptional, and to show this in some directions which have not been from time immemorial the beaten path' (Cross 3: 137).
Commiserates with Edith Bulwer-Lytton on the death of her son Rowland.
Congratulates Mary Finlay Cross on her story 'Marie of Villefranche'.
Thanks Cara Bray for sending news of herself. Confirms Alexander Main in his accentuation Romola, and regrets general misunderstanding of meaning as well as pronunciation.
Forcibly expresses her enthusiasm for Scott in a letter to Main.
Describes routine of days at Shottermill in letter to Maria Congreve.
GHL suggests £6000 for the four-year English copyright of Middlemarch, or a two-shilling royalty.
Two-day visit from Barbara Bodichon begins.
Tennyson calls, and reads Maud and 'Northern Farmer' aloud.
Again visited by Tennyson, who reads 'Boadicea', 'Tears, Idle Tears', 'Northern Farmer New Style' and 'Guinevere', GE weeping at the latter.
Return to The Priory. GE's health soon deteriorates.
GHL attempts to reassure Blackwood about recently negotiated arrangements for the American publication of Middlemarch.

GHL again reassures Blackwood over the American publication of Middlemarch, and reports, 'Mrs Lewes is not at all well - depressed in spirits and in liver... but perhaps gestation is more favourable when so much emotion accompanies it' (Letters 5: 184).
Learn of Herbert Lewes's marriage. GE expresses herself moved by quality of Main’s criticism of Gypsy.
Sends greetings to D’Albert.
Seriously ill for five days with gastric fever.
Blackwood sends a specimen page for Middlemarch.
GHL encourages Alexander Main’s proposal for a commonplace- style selection from GE’s work.
GHL expresses disappointment at Blackwood's cautious response to the Main proposal.
GHL reports an improvement in GE’s health to William Blackwood, and requests last-minute alterations to the title page and binding of Middlemarch.
GE reports improvement in her condition to Cara Bray.
Blackwood records his delight in reading the proof of Middlemarch: 'she who can administer to the world such tonics as Middlemarch must speedily cure herself of all ailments' (Letters 5: 199).
Blackwood decides to accept the Main proposal.
GHL advises Main on further dealings with Blackwood.
Servants Grace and Amelia resign after 10 years’ service.
Sends letter of sympathy to the Blackwoods on the death of John Blackwood's only surviving brother, James. Reads GHL book m of Middlemarch.
Begin four-day visit to Anna Cross at Weybridge.
Expresses support for Elizabeth Garret Anderson's Hospital for Women.
Printing of book I of Middlemarch completed.
Expresses approval of Main’s draft.
Osgood Ticknor announce that they have transferred Middlemarch to Harpers.
Promises Sara Hennell an author's copy of Middlemarch.
Barbara Bodichon to dinner.
Blackwood and son to lunch.
Book I of Middlemarch published.
GHL proposes transpositions in Middlemarch books II and III.
See Irving in Chatrian’s The Bells.
Sends Sara Hennell a two-sided appreciation of Forster’s Life of Dickens, the first volume of which has recently appeared.
First US instalment of Middlemarch, in Harper's Weekly. GE, now writing more steadily, tells GHL of future developments in the novel.

Records in Journal, 'My health has become very troublesome during the last three weeks, and I can get on but tardily. Even now I am only at p. 227 of my fourth part. But I have been also retarded by construction, which, once done, serves as good wheels for progress' (Cross 3: 145).
Thanks Main enthusiastically, both for his Sayings, and for his friendship.
Blackwood, sending New Year greetings, reports good sales for Middlemarch and a good reception for the Sayings.
Four-day stay with Anna Cross begins. Sends Blackwood an account of their 'rather doleful Christmas' (Cross 3: 146).
Sends New Year greetings to Sarah Hennell.
GHL tells Blackwood of the difficulty of obtaining copies of Middlemarch at two London railway termini.
Attends the Tichborne trial. Blackwood sends belated congratulations on the third book of Middlemarch.
Tells Blackwood that 'there remains the terror about the unwritten,' but that GHL is much satisfied with book IV.
Reading Johnson's Lives of the Poets 'with a delicious revival of girlish impressions' (Cross 3: 150).
Writes to congratulate Main notwithstanding some lukewarmness in the critical reception of his work. Blackwood sends good news of Middlemarch sales.
Large dinner-party and musical entertainment at The Priory, with Spencer and Harrison present, the first of such a size for four years.
Describes Middlemarch to D’Albert, and the Tichborne trial to Sara Hennell.
Blackwood confident of the commercial success of Middlemarch, and again praises its artistic merits.
Recommends Emilia Pattison to visit the Burne-Jones studio.
Trollope writes of his dislike for vol. I of Forster’s Life of Dickens.
Expresses distrust of spiritualists in letter to Harriet Beecher Stowe.
GHL solicits approval of Middlemarch book IV from Blackwood.
Commiserates with Clementia Taylor on the death of Mazzini.
Writes affectionately to E. R. and Edith Bulwer-Lytton.
GHL thanks E. R. Bulwer-Lytton for remarks on his Dickens article.
Gives her own estimation of Middlemarch in replying to that of Alexander Main.
Book III of Middlemarch published.
Blackwood sends his first cheque (of £500) for Middlemarch.
Encourages Ethel Harrison to call more frequently.
Writes to Cara Bray, asking her to forward news to Rufa Call.
GHL sends Main a photograph of Charles Lewes.
Journal records Middlemarch book V complete.
Begin three-month stay at Elversley, Park Road, Redhill, Surrey. Severe tooth trouble at this time.
Writes to Sara Hennell, though keeping Redhill address secret.
GHL, regretting the social pressures of London life, tells Main that he and GE propose to continue a hermit-like existence at Redhill, where Middlemarch will, he hopes, be finished.
Sends Barbara Bodichon an account of their Redhill life. Receives from an affable barrister a legal cavil regarding Middlemarch.
GHL pays an unsatisfactory visit to the Crystal Palace.
Daily Telegraph praises Middlemarch, declaring it 'almost profane to speak of ordinary novels in the same breath with George Eliot’s'. Other reviews share this enthusiasm.
Writes at length to Harriet Beecher Stowe, again discussing spiritualism.
GHL delightedly reports to Anna Cross an improvement in GE’s health, and suggests to Main that he might attempt an anthology of Augustus de Morgan's mathematical writings.
Sends good wishes to Emily Southwood Hill for her forthcoming marriage.
Commiserates with Jane Senior on the death of her elder brother.
Book VI of Middlemarch despatched to Blackwood.
Thanks Charles Ritter for sending a volume of Strauss's Select Essays.
Tells Maria Congreve 'Our days go by in delicious peace, unbroken except by my little anxieties about all unfinished work' (Cross 3: 164).
Birth of Blanche Southwood Lewes, daughter to Charles.
Blackwood sends an admiring appraisal of Book VI of Middlemarch.
Sends Blackwood a report on progress with Middlemarch.
Blackwood sends a cheque and a statement of the Middlemarch account.
Book VII of Middlemarch completed and sent off.
GHL thanks Edward Dowden for the generosity of his article on GE in the Contemporary Review.
Congratulates George Robertson on his engagement to Caroline Crompton.
GHL suggests Main write up his recent Scottish walking-tour as a magazine article.
First 90 pages of Middlemarch book VIII despatched to Blackwood.
Blackwood sends his approval of Middlemarch book VII.
Blackwood expresses his delight with Middlemarch book VIII: 'Dorothea is better than any sermon that ever was preached by man' (Letters 5: 307).
GHL thanks Blackwood for his praise: '[Dorothea] is more like her creator than any one else and more so than any other of her creations ' (Letters 5: 308).
Arrive to stay with Henry Bullock-Hall, J. W. Cross's brother-in-law, at Six Mile Bottom, Cambridgeshire.
Leave Six Mile Bottom.
Corrects proofs of Middlemarch book VIII.
Set out for Homburg.
Sends Anna Cross an account of their foreign experiences so far.
Gambling scene at the Kursaal provides germ for Daniel Deronda.
'Finale' of Middlemarch sent to Blackwood.
Sends Blackwood details of Homburg life.
Proof of Middlemarch 'Finale' returned to Blackwood.
Leave Homburg for Stuttgart and Karlsruhe.
Writes to Anna Cross, regretting that Bullock-Hall was unable to join them in Paris.
Return to England. GE writes to D’Albert.
Book VII of Middlemarch published. Writes to Lucy Smith, having read an obituary of her husband in Blackwood's.
Birth of Herbert Lewes's daughter Marian Evans Lewes.
Sends 'an egotistic note' to Main, describing her reaction to the completion of Middlemarch (Letters 5: 325).
Defends two 'errors' in Middlemarch pointed out by Courtney Kenny.
Visit Hertford Gallery of Pictures in Bethnal Green Museum, East London.
GHL, on GE's behalf, advises a young correspondent against throwing himself on literature as a living.
Spencer writes to GHL in praise of the most recent part of Middlemarch: 'I cannot conceive anything more perfectly done' (Letters 9: 63).
Tells Main of the intense comfort which his response to her work has afforded her.
Writes to Sara Hennell in advance of her birthday.
Tells Sara Hennell to expect to be disappointed in the 'Finale' of Middlemarch but to look back to the 'Prelude'.
Publication of eighth and final book of Middlemarch. GE expresses approval of the sensitivity of the review of Middlemarch in Blackwood's.
Sends Bessie Belloc good wishes on moving to a new home, and regrets that her (i.e. GE's) rules prevent her calling to see it.
GHL describes to Main the variety of kinds of admirer of Middlemarch.
Requests advice of Paget on correction of medical error in Middlemarch.

F. W. H. Myers sends warm appreciation of Middlemarch: 'You know the worst, and one thanks you in that you have not despaired' (Letters 9: 68). GHL discourages an article on a possible model for Dinah by 'Guy Roslyn'. GE defends the accuracy of bright dilated eyes in the description of the opiated Lydgate.
Thanks Cross for his interest in a plan for buying a site near Shere, Surrey.
Sends news to Maria Congreve.
First meeting, at The Priory, with Edith Simcox.
Tells Emilia Pattison of her present happiness: 'it is a holiday to sit with one's feet at the fire reading one's husband's writing' (Letters 5: 344).
Asks Simpson for further news of Middlemarch sales. Also writes to Lucy Smith.
Sends subscription to the Working Women's College.
Attend christening of Blanche Lewes. Blackwood sends a statement of the Gypsy and Middlemarch accounts.
Begin five-day visit to Anna Cross.

1 Records in Journal, regarding Middlemarch, 'No former book of mine has been received with more enthusiasm', also noting that 'Hardly anything could have happened to me which I could regard as a greater blessing, than the growth of my spiritual existence when my bodily existence is decaying' (Letters 5: 357). Thanks Main for 'a whole year's sympathy' (Letters 5: 358).
GHL also writes to Main.
Thanks Anna Cross for her interest in her illness, which is described at some length.
Blackwood proposes a Guinea edition of Middlemarch, and presents a further payment.
Thanks Main for noting minor error in Middlemarch, and asks him to keep a note of others.
Begins reading Sterne's Tristram Shandy aloud.
Expresses her gratification at Alice Wellington's appreciation of her work. GHL decides not to allow James Mackaye to dramatise Silas Marner.
Blackwood agrees to publish GHL’s Problems of Life and Mind.
Death of E. G. Bulwer-Lytton.
Sir James Paget advises removal of troublesome tooth.
Congratulates Jane Senior, the first woman to be appointed an inspector of workhouses and pauper schools.
Regrets that 'there has not…been one really able review' of  Middlemarch in letter to Ritter. (Letters 5: 374).
George Robertson and his bride Caroline, du Maurier and Barbara Bodichon to lunch.
Invites Oscar Browning to bring his photographs of Greece to lunch.
Expresses approval of the Guinea edition of Middlemarch (published around this date) to Blackwood.
Blackwood asks permission to include 'The Lifted Veil' in a Blackwood anthology, but on the 28th GE declines.

Asks Lucy Smith for a copy of her Memoir of her husband: 'it is an unforgettable picture of that union which is the ideal of marriage, and which I desire young people to have in their minds as a goal' (Letters 5: 381; Cross 3: 197).
Thanks Mary Simpson for sending a photograph and explains why a weekday call from her provoked GHL's ire.
Supports John Hollingshead in an attempt to change the law of copyright regarding dramatisation of novels.
GHL sends vol. 1 of Problems to Blackwood.
Visit Burne-Jones's pictures. Blackwood reports the Guinea edition of Middlemarch beginning to go out of print.
Tells Blackwood, 'I wish there were some solid philosophical Conservative to take the reins' after the resignation of Gladstone (Letters 5: 387; Cross 3: 199).
The Hon. Mrs Frederick Ponsonby introduced to GE, an indication of GE's social acceptance.
Acknowledges receipt of Curtius's Griechische Geschichte.
Writes guardedly to Elizabeth Stuart Phelps about plans for another novel.
Sends two guineas for concert in aid of Elizabeth Garret Anderson's Hospital for Women.
Sends Cara Bray £50 in hope that she will produce a further work discouraging children's cruelty to animals. Writes to Burne-Jones in appreciation of his work.
Sends a letter of strongly emotional recollections to D’Albert.
Approves Cara Bray's outline, and urges her to accept the cheque.
Browning, Darwin and Joachim amongst 23 afternoon callers.
GHL tells Main that he has arranged with Chapman and Hall for Main to undertake a synthesis of biographies of Johnson, to be called Life and Conversations of Dr Johnson.
Sends suggested reading to Barbara Bodichon.
GHL warns Main of Chapman’s laxity in business matters.
Spend all day house-hunting at Tonbridge, Kent, and Reigate, Surrey, one of several such expeditions at this time.
Blackwood tells GHL that the Guinea edition of Middlemarch has been reprinted, and queries some anti-religious remarks in Problems of Life and Mind.
GHL reports GE 'deep in the Greek poets' (Letters 9: 88).
Lunch with Emerson. GE sends the ailing Blackwood a letter of miscellaneous news.
Dissuades Main from including quotations of her work in his new Johnson publication : 'I hate a style speckled with quotations' (Letters 5: 404).
Encourages Lucy Smith in her plan of going to live with a young female undergraduate at Cambridge.
Blackwood sends news of sales, and suggests a cheaper edition of GE’s works.
Death in Alexandria of Emanuel Deutsch, whose achievements and sufferings influenced Deronda. Recommends Pigott as Secretary of the Royal Academy.
Visit the Castellani collection at the British Museum.
Guests at a representatively crowded Sunday At Home include Thomas Woolner, Lord Houghton, Frederic Harrison and George du Maurier.

Three-day visit to Myers at Cambridge, having a memorable conversation with him. Tells Maria Congreve, 'We were invited ostensibly to see the boat-race, but the real pleasure of the visit consisted in talking with a hopeful group of Trinity young men' (Letters 3: 205). (The group included Gurney, Jebb and Sidgwick.)
Finishes rereading Aristotle's Poetics.
Blackwood reveals he would be happier if GHL could find another publisher for Problems.
GHL defends his views to Blackwood, but is happy to seek another publisher.
Problems passed to Trübner. Visited by Blackwood and his nephew William.
C. V. Stanford requests permission to publish settings of poems from Gypsy.

Much taken with a house called Blackbrook, near Bickley, Kent. Thanks Cara Bray for sending news of the death of Rebecca Franklin, 'a friend whom one once looked up to with reverence' (Letters5, 419). 'She was always particularly good and affectionate to me, and I had much happiness in her as my teacher' (Letters 3: 206).
Two-day visit to Jowett, GHL recording 'one continuous excitement of talk' (Letters 9: 100). Blackwood writes to defend the terms for the Guinea edition of Middlemarch.
Stay the night with the Crosses.
Writes to congratulate Frederic Harrison on his criticism of James Stephen's Liberty, Equality, Fraternity.
Leave for two months in France and Germany. For a brief account of this trip, see Cross 3: 211.
Death of Thornton Hunt.
Discusses new plans for novel and play Deronda with GHL at Fontainebleau.
GHL buys Jewish books to help with GE's new novel.
Apologises for being unable to visit D’Albert.
Return to The Priory. GE invites Emily Faithfull, proprietor of the Victoria Printing Press, to call.
Grants permission for an expanded edition of Main's Sayings to include extracts from Middlemarch.
Asks Cara Bray to let her see the manuscript of Paul Bradley.
Considerably disappointed on arrival to take over Blackbrook, and agree to curtail lease, though staying there for September and October.
Recommends Paul Bradley to Macmillan.
Sends Anna Cross an account of their holiday, and of their disappointment with Blackbrook. Blackwood proposes a onevolume edition of Middlemarch.
Sends manuscript of Cara Bray's Paul Bradley to Macmillan with letter of recommendation.
Agrees to a one-volume Middlemarch, expressing wish to make corrections.
First meeting with Elma Stuart, GE's 'spiritual daughter'.
Sends Elma Stuart a lock of hair. GHL tells Main that both GHL and GE have read the sheets of his Life and Conversations of Dr Samuel Johnson and approve of it.
Passes to Cara Bray Macmillan's advice that she should approach the Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge with the Paul Bradley manuscript.
Sends Cross a clarification of her attitude to religions: 'I have no antagonism towards any religious belief, but a strong outflow of sympathy' (Cross 3: 216).
Considering a new drama.
Lunch with Darwin.
Writes warmly to T. C. Allbutt.
Tells Blackwood she is 'slowly simmering towards another big book' (Cross 3: 218).
Blackwood sends details of the sale of the Guinea edition of Middlemarch. GE tells Barbara Bodichon of her disappointment with Blackbrook, and comments on J. S. Mill's Autobiography.
Agrees with Blackwood's doubts about Main's new Preface, wishing to avoid any suggestion of a preaching tendency in her work.

Letter to Emilia Pattison reveals that reading currently includes Max Müller's Lectures on the Science of Religion and Herbert Spencer's Study of Sociology, as well as the study of works of Jewish history.
Visit Emily Clarke in Brighton.
Vol. 1 of GHL's Problems published.
GE returns proof of opening of one-volume edition of Middlemarch.
Visited by John Fiske. (For his account see Letters 5: 463-5.)
Regrets missing Harriet Stephen and invites her to call again.
Accepts invitation to join the Crosses for Christmas.
Finally obtain their own carriage.
Congratulates Cara Bray on the SPCK’s interest in Paul Bradley, also giving some suggestions for the improvement of the tale.
Begin four-day visit to the Crosses.
Thanks Clementia Taylor for her greetings.

Confides to Journal, 'The happy old year in which we have had constant enjoyment of life, notwithstanding much bodily malaise, is gone from us for ever. More than in any former year of my life, love has been poured forth to me from distant hearts.... Nothing is wanting to my blessings but the uninterrupted power of work. For as to all my unchangeable imperfections I have resigned myself' (Cross 3: 221-2).
Helps C. E. Appleton find a Parisian correspondent for the Academy.
Congratulates Appleton on the first number of the Academy.
GHL told by Trübner that a further edition of Problems will be required.
Congratulates Main on the penetrating choice of quotations from Middlemarch added to the new edition of Sayings.
Attend a séance at the house of Erasmus Darwin, also attended by Charles Darwin. Unimpressed.

Blackwood sends further settlement of Middlemarch and Gypsy accounts. GHL asks Blackwood to send a letter of encouragement to GE: 'I am hard at work and wish she were; but she simmers and simmers, despairs and despairs, believes she can never do anything again worth doing, etc, etc' (Letters 6: 11).
Entertain F. W. H. Myers, Sir Henry Maine, and Cross and his sister Emily to lunch.
Sunday-afternoon callers include Edith Simcox, Mark and Emilia Pattison, Cross, and Robert Browning.
Requests Page's Advanced Text Book of Geology from Blackwood.
Serious kidney pain, the first of a series of attacks which continue until GE’s death.
Recurrence of kidney pain.
Only recorded visit to The Priory by Ruskin.
Tells Barbara Bodichon that she does not mind about the Conservative majority in Parliament (the first since 1841).
Discusses recent attacks on Herbert Spencer in letter to Sara Hennell.
Deeply congratulates Lucy Smith on the private publication of her husband's Knowing and Feeling, and hopes it will be made public.
Comforts Cara Bray on the rejection of Paul Bradley by the SPCK.
GHL sends Main a frank appraisal of Life and Conversations.

Writes to Blackwood about the election result, criticising Gladstone's literary output, and remarking, 'I, who am no believer in salvation by ballot, am rather tickled that the first experiment with it has turned against its adherents' (Letters 3: 224). Also suggests cheap edition of her novels.
Attend performance of Sheridan's School for Scandal.
Writes to congratulate Helena Faucit, the Lady Teazle of this production.
Manuscript of The Legend of Jubal and Other Poems, gathered together this month, despatched to Blackwood.
Barbara Bodichon to lunch.
Hear Joachim and Piatti at a party given by Sir James and Lady Frances Colville.
Invites Anna Cross to lunch.
Enquires of E. A. Bond the progress made with a fund to support Octavia Hill, to which GE and GHL had contributed £200.
Asks Alice Helps to order her a new cloak.
Commiserates with Lady Lytton on death of her second son.
Further commiserates with Cara Bray on her failure to find a publisher for Paul Bradley.
Congratulates William Allingham on his Laurence Bloomfield, considering it superior to Crabbe.
Asks Alice Helps to call to discuss clothing.
Thanks Elma Stuart for the gift of a table made by her.
Birth of GHL’s second grandchild, Maud Southwood Lewes.
Blackwood sends remainder of revise for Jubal, and expresses his (slightly lukewarm) appreciation of the volume.
GE suggests price of six shillings for this volume, and requests royalty terms.
Visited by niece Edith Griffiths (the eldest daughter of Isaac Evans) and her husband.
Look at two houses at Earlswood Common, Redhill.
Sends letter of miscellaneous news to Sara Hennell.
Visit the Crosses at Weybridge and inspect a house, one of several such inspections in the Home Counties this summer.
Disappointed with choice of paper for Jubal.
Blackwood apologises for the Jubal paper.
Thanks her niece Edith for sending photographs of Griff.
Writes affectionately to Mary Cross, thanking her for the gift of a specially painted vase.
Invites the over-admiring Main to visit them in the country.
Asks Anna Cross and her son to Sunday lunch.
Thanks James Thomson for the gift of his 'City of Dreadful Night', which she finds admirable.
F. T. Palgrave calls at The Priory.
Start a four-month stay at Earlswood Common, Redhill, where GE makes considerable progress with Deronda, and GHL continues work on Problems.
Thanks Annie Fields for a letter of appreciation.
GHL reads beginning of Deronda.
Tells Anna Cross of their happiness in their new house, and hopes that J. W. Cross will find them a permanent dwelling of this kind.
Expresses satisfaction with swift sale of Jubal, and disappointment at the impending threat of the restoration of the Empire in France.
James Thomson writes of his considerable admiration for GE's writings.
GHL reports GE hard at work on Deronda and asks Blackwood to advertise Jubal more prominently.

In a letter of continued sympathy to Lucy Smith, reports herself 'revelling in the sweet peace of the country' (Cross 3: 237). Approves Clementia Taylor's interest in the condition of workhouse girls: 'You see my only social work is to rejoice in the labours of others, while I live in luxurious remoteness from all turmoil' (Cross 3: 235).
Explains her reluctance to being made a biographical subject in a lengthy letter to George Bancroft.
Asks Barbara Bodichon's advice on Holmwood Common as a place of residence.
Thanks Roland Stuart, whom she calls an adopted grandson, for sending a photograph of his mother.
Blackwood reports excellent sales of Gypsy, Jubal, and, most of all, Middlemarch.
Tells Blackwood of her delight at this good news, but depression when reading her own past work.
GHL reports over 5000 of the one-volume edition of Middlemarch sold in the previous two months, and the demand not slackening.
Finish reading Edward Burnett Taylor's Researches into the Early History of Mankind.
Entertain Lord Lytton (formerly E. R. Bulwer-Lytton) for two days.
GHL invites Elma Stuart to visit them at Redhill.
GHL gives Main a confident prediction of the high quality of Deronda.
Visit Emily Clarke at Brighton. William Blackwood reports continued high sales of Middlemarch.
Thanks Elma Stuart for gifts of clothing.
Sends news to Barbara Bodichon.
Return to The Priory.
Declines her nephew Robert's suggestion that communication be reopened with his aunt, Fanny Houghton.
Begin four-day visit to W. H. Bullock-Hall at Six Mile Bottom.
Begin fortnight's holiday in Paris and Brussels.
Return to London.
Visit Wiltshire (Salisbury and environs) on brief walking-tour in search of locations for Deronda.
Asks Barbara Bodichon to recommend a housemaid. Urges Elma Stuart to take better care of herself.
Again visit Wiltshire (Devizes and Marlborough) for four-day study of possible Deronda locations.
GHL recommends Matthew Arnold's 'Review of Objections to Literature and Dogma' to Elma Stuart. 'Much that he says on Religions we both think very good' (Letters 6: 87).
Cross takes GE to Lord Mayor's Show, one of several outings arranged by him at this time.
Thanks Alexander Macmillan for sending a complimentary copy of David Masson's Life of Milton, and compliments him on the quality of his publishing list.

Belatedly answers a letter from Harriet Beecher Stowe: 'Will you not agree with me that there is one comprehensive Church whose fellowship consists in the desire to purify and ennoble human life, and where the best members of all narrower Churches may call themselves brother and sister in spite of differences?' (Cross 3: 243).
Shown round the Bank of England by Cross.
Blackwood, with tactful indirectness, encourages progress on Deronda.
First of two visits to Russian church. Sends 'the gossip of our lives' to Sara Hennell, in anticipation of their adjacent birthdays (Letters 6: 93).
Second visit to Russian church.
Asks Cara Bray to send a proof of Paul Bradley.
GHL obtains from Spencer J. S. Mill's Three Essays on Religion for GE to read.
David Masson acknowledges GE's letter of appreciation of his Life of Milton.

In reply to Mary Ponsonby’s lengthy expressions of her religious difficulties, GE sends an unusually full statement of her own views: 'the fellowship between man and man which has been the principle of development, social and moral, is not dependent on conceptions of what is not man' (Cross 3: 245).
Sends a legal query to Harrison, perhaps with Deronda in mind. Blackwood sends New Year greetings.
Two-thirds of vol. 1 of the Deronda manuscript completed.
Thanks Albert and Anna Druce for the gift of some flowers. Sends further legal query to Harrison.
Thanks Main for his New Year greeting, and George Smith for a box of bonbons.
Writes to Emilia Pattison arguing against changes in the final chapter of her husband's Isaac Casaubon.
Asks Harrison for advice on resettlement of estates in tail (such as that of Sir Francis Mallinger in Deronda).
Invites Harrison to call for further discussions.
Writes at length to Elma Stuart, urging her to take better care of herself.
Blackwood sends a cheque and a statement of the year's account - sales of Middlemarch have been especially pleasing.

Confides to Journal, 'The last year has been crowded with proofs of affection for me, and of value for what work I have been able to do. This makes the best motive or encouragement to do more; but, as usual, I am suffering much from doubt as to the worth of what I am doing, and fear lest I May not be able to complete it so as to make it a contribution to literature, and not a mere addition to the heap of books. I am just now beginning the part about Deronda, at p. 234 [i.e. end of ch. 15]' (Cross 3: 250-1). Congratulates Emily Cross and Francis Otter on their engagement.
Encourages Clementia Taylor in her philanthropic work.
Sympathises with Elma Stuart on the death of her mother.

Urges Mary Ponsonby 'to consider your early religious experience as a portion of valid knowledge, and to cherish its emotional results in relation to objects and ideas which are either substitutes or metamorphoses of the earlier' (Cross 3: 253).
Visit Kew and Richmond to choose a scene for Deronda. GHL reassures Elma Stuart that she will always be a welcome visitor.
Invites Frederick Locker to call with his new wife, but only on a Sunday afternoon.

Thanks Blackwood for the gift of A. W. Kinglake’s The Battle of Inkerman, of which she sends a critique. Expresses disappointment with Margaret Majendie's Gianetto, though explaining that she is 'obliged to fast from fiction' (Cross  3: 255).
Encourages Mary Ponsonby to send papers detailing her religious struggle.
Begins reading J. H. Bridges's translation of Comte's System of Positive Polity.
Seeks further legal advice from Harrison.
Vol. II of GHL’s Problems published.
Further violent kidney attacks. Deronda written whilst suffering these continuing pains. Counsels Oscar Browning in his difficulties at Eton.
Thanks Elma Stuart for a further parcel of clothes.
Further sharp kidney attack.
Manning created Cardinal.
Visited by Lord and Lady Lytton.
Sends news to D’Albert.
Apologises to Lucy Crompton for an unfortunate remark made unknowingly by Cross concerning her father, Lord Romilly. Humorous letter about clothing sent to Elma Stuart.
See Salvini in Othello.
Dine at Lord Lytton's.
Again see Salvini in Othello.
William Blackwood relates to his uncle the details of a recent visit to GHL and GE, informing him that one volume of the Deronda manuscript is now ready for inspection.
Begin three-day visit to Jowett at Oxford.
Fresh kidney attack, which quickly passes, but the attacks recur until 9 May.
Leslie Stephen sends information on the resignation of Cambridge scholarships for Deronda.
Encourages Lucy Smith to publish her privately circulated memoir of her husband.
Drives with Cara Bray.
Birth of George Herbert Lewes, son to Bertie.
Gives Blackwood the manuscript of Deronda chs 1-8.
Blackwood expresses his delight with the manuscript, which he stayed up late to read.
Blackwood, encouraged by GHL, sends a further, unusually fulsome, appreciation of Deronda.
See Salvini's Hamlet.
Requests Harrison's further legal assistance.
Sends details of her requirements to Harrison.
Alice Helps to dinner.
Thanks Harrison for his advice.
Writes to Emily Clarke.
Again see Salvini's Hamlet.
Move for three-and-a-half months to The Elms, at Rickmansworth, Hertfordshire, where work takes place on vols II and III of Deronda.
Further legal query despatched to Harrison.
Give limited assistance to Octavia Hill's campaign to prevent fields near Swiss Cottage being built on.
Death of Herbert “Bertie” Lewes at Durban, the news not reaching England until the end of July.
Publication of GHL's On Actors and the Art of Acting.
GHL meets Queen of Holland, GE declining the invitation.
Asks Emilia Pattison to send news of her health.
Has tooth pulled.
GHL tells G. J. Holyoake, 'The uninterrupted peace is very favourable both to health and work. We see no one - absolutely no one' (Letters 6: 160).
GE enthuses over her Hertfordshire environs in letter to Clementia Taylor.

Tells Barbara Bodichon of Bertie Lewes's death, though circulation of news of this bereavement generally limited in order to avoid letters of condolence. Sends brief details of her biography to Elizabeth Stuart Phelps.

Discusses death of Bertie in letter to Cross: 'He was a sweetnatured creature - not clever, but diligent and well-judging about the things of daily life' (Letters 5: 165). Despairs of finishing Deronda satisfactorily.
Professes herself happy to continue discussing metaphysics with Mary Ponsonby.
Visited for the weekend by Charles Lewes and family
Encourages Elma Stuart to write a detailed story of her self-initiation as a wood-carver.
GHL asks Blackwood to send Andrew Wilson's The Abode of Snow for GE to read aloud.
Asks Anna Cross to send details of a skin ointment.
Undertake to help find governess position for Phoebe Marks.
Return to The Priory from Rickmansworth.
Set off for holiday in Wales, where reading includes Austen, Emma; Dickens, Uncommercial Traveller; Sterne, Sentimental Journey; Turgenev, Nouvelles moscovites.
Return from Wales.

Records in Journal, 'Our stay at Rickmansworth, though otherwise peaceful, was not marked by any great improvement in health... rather the contrary' (Cross 3: 263). Tells Blackwood she had a 'bad time' at Rickmansworth, 'and did less of everything than I desired' (Cross 3: 263). Suggests February publication for the first part of Deronda.
Sends D’Albert her news, including her feelings on Bertie's death.
Commiserates with Emilia Pattison on being advised to winter out of England because of arthritis. Blackwood agrees to begin publishing Deronda in February. Newnham College, Cambridge, opens.
First two volumes of Deronda sent to Blackwood. Decide to publish the novel in eight monthly parts.
Blackwood reports the opening of Deronda ready in proof, and offers the same terms as for Middlemarch.
GHL accepts this offer.
Asks Blackwood whether to rearrange the first four parts of Deronda. Blackwood sends the first 256 pages of proof and an encomium of the book's quality.
Blackwood sends a further 180 pages of proof, and gives his opinion on the splitting of the parts.
GHL sends Blackwood his thoughts on part-division and publication date.
Thanks Mrs Ernst Benzon for the gift of a scarf, and reminds Elma Stuart to send news of herself.
Sends pre-birthday greetings to Sara Hennell, revealing that she has re-established contact with Maria Lewis.
GHL suggests a form of advertisement for Deronda to Blackwood.

Asks Alice Helps to call. Blackwood remarks, 'You may rest assured that you are writing one of the most remarkable Books that ever was produced by man or woman. I know nothing like it' (Letters 6: 195).

Records in Journal, 'I have finished the fifth book, but am not so far on in the sixth, as I hoped to have been, - the oppression under which I have been labouring having positively suspended my power of writing anything that I could feel satisfaction in' (rn, 201).
Read approvingly Mark Pattison's article 'Philosophy at Oxford'.
Blackwood sends settlement of the Middlemarch, Jubal and Gypsy accounts.
GHL sends New Year reflections to Main, and comments on the progress of Deronda.
Blackwood is requested by GHL to ensure that advertisements for Deronda appear in the Contemporary and Fortnightly reviews.

GHL asks Blackwood to check that advance proofs of Deronda have been sent to Harpers, and on the 14th insists that publication of Deronda may have to be delayed if Harpers wish it. Blackwood tells GHL he is troubling too much about the matter.

Writes lengthily to J. F. Payne following the death of his mother, also discussing her purposes in writing fiction: 'my writing is simply a set of experiments in life - an endeavour to see what our thought and emotion may be capable of' (Letters 6: 216).
GHL tells Blackwood that he hopes to send vol. III of the Deronda manuscript, though progress is slow.
GHL writes to warn William Blackwood not to mention any reviews of Deronda.
William Blackwood to lunch.
First of eight parts of Deronda published. Others follow at monthly intervals, ending in September. GHL sends Blackwood manuscript of part VI.
Offers to lend Cara Bray £40 in expectation of a publisher's advance on her Elements of Morality, and discusses vivisection.
Ill again.
Attending as usual the Saturday-afternoon Pops Concert at St James's Hall, is moved by the music to kiss the violinist Neruda.
Suffers for five days from lumbago.
Attend performance of Liszt's The Legend of St Elizabeth. Blackwood sends an enthusiastic appreciation of Deronda, though retaining doubts about Mordecai.
Dine with Lord and Lady Lytton before the Lyttons depart for India.
GHL tells Blackwood that his comments on Mordecai have made GE despondent.
Blackwood reports that sales of Deronda are exceeding those for Middlemarch.
GHL tells Main that ill health has restricted the writing of both GE and himself.
Blackwood expresses unbounded congratulations on part VI of Deronda.
GHL reports that these congratulations have greatly raised GE’s spirits. GE writes to Emilia Pattison, praising the pictures of Burne-Jones and Frederick Walker.
Blackwood reports continued good sales of Deronda.
Begin 12-day stay in the Bullock-Halls' house at Weybridge, though returning to The Priory at the weekend.
Writes humorously to Blackwood about corrections to Deronda suggested by various correspondents.
Acknowledges George Grove's admiration of Deronda.
Mary Dickens, as requested by GE, sends details of the opening night of Tennyson's Queen Mary.
Writes to Barbara Bodichon, discussing vivisection inter alia.
GHL asked to become a member of the council of the Physiological Society.
Part VII of Deronda sent to Blackwood.
Confesses to Journal that Jewish part of Deronda is 'likely to satisfy nobody', though gratified by the novel's good sales, and by her own better health (Cross 3: 277).
Blackwood sends admiring comments on part vn of Deronda.
Sees Irving in Tennyson's Queen Mary. Tells Blackwood that she regrets including a motto from Whitman at the head of part IV, ch. 29.
Thanks Main for his continued affectionate sympathy.
Thanks Harriet Beecher Stowe for her letter - 'one of the best cordials I could have' (Cross 3: 280).
Asks Elma Stuart's advice on underclothing.
Blackwood agrees to let Harpers have proof of Deronda more than a month in advance, and sends further good news of sales.
Dine with Anton Rubinstein (a model for Klesmer?) at the Lehmanns.
John Blackwood to lunch. Dine with Lady Portsmouth. Manuscript of first half of part VIII of Deronda sent to William Blackwood.
Spend weekend with Jowett in Oxford.
GHL tells Blackwood that there is no objection to Edward Dowden making a book-length study of GE.
Declines invitation to meet Leopold, King of the Belgians, but GHL presented in her place.

Records in Journal, regarding Deronda, 'Growing interest in the public, and growing sale, which has from the beginning exceeded that of Middlemarch. The Jewish part apparently creating strong interest' (Cross  3: 283).
Writes to Elma Stuart regretting inability to give more time to her on her recent visit.
Reads GHL penultimate chapter of Deronda and sends manuscript to William Blackwood.
Deronda finished.

Set off for two-and-a-half months in France and Switzerland - for detailed itinerary, see III, 285. Blackwood sends his verdict on the conclusion of Deronda: 'criticism and eulogism are out of place' (Letters 6: 262).
Proof-reading final pages of Deronda in Paris.
GE sends Blackwood, and GHL sends Charles Lewes, news of their travels so far.

Thanks Jane Senior for the suggestion of a house: 'We do desire, above all earthly possessions of a material sort, a house in the country to which we could go, not simply in summer, but from time to time throughout the year' (Letters 6: 269). Also gives an account of their daily timetable in Ragatz. Blackwood sends a still-favourable account of Deronda sales.
GHL reports GE's health considerably improved.
Return to The Priory from France and Switzerland. Final part of Deronda published.
Writes to D’Albert telling him of their holiday and of the completion of Deronda. Tells Blackwood of her delight at the Chief Rabbi's approval of the Jewish characterisation in Deronda.
Apologises to Catherine Spence for her infelicitous reception at The Priory. Begin four-day visit to the Bullock-Halls at Six Mile Bottom.
Asks Cara Bray to send news.
Sends details of the continental holiday to Elma Stuart.
Visited by Emily Davies, their talk turning to the necessity of telling the truth, and the education of women. Manuscript of third volume of GHL’s Problems sent to the printer.

Take GE's niece, Emily Clarke, visiting them briefly, to W. S. Gilbert's Dan'l Druce, Blacksmith, based on Marner. Thanks Haim Guedalla, a Jewish community worker, for his praise of the Jewish elements in Deronda.

Explains to Haim Guedalla her reasons for refusing permission for him to publish her letter of 26 September; and regrets in letter to Barbara Bodichon the critical tendency to divide Deronda into separate portions: 'I meant everything in the book to be related to everything else there' (Cross 3: 291).
Visiting Bullock-Hall, they pay a visit to stables at Newmarket, Suffolk, GE noticing a defect in the Derby winner.
Return from four-day visit to Bullock-Hall.

Cross their only Sunday guest. Writes Blackwood an affectionate appreciation of his services. Blackwood subsequently remarks to his nephew, 'It is the greatest compliment a man in my position could possibly receive, and... brought warm tears to my eyes' (Cross 3: 293).
Sends Elma Stuart autographs of Shelley and the French executioner Sanson. Blackwood thanks GE for her generous letter.
Asks Lucy Smith to send more news of herself.
Blackwood offers £4000 for 10-year control of copyright.
Gratified, in looking over accounts in consideration of Blackwood's offer, to find 24,577 copies of Middlemarch had been distributed before Christmas 1875.
GHL, in amiable tone, seeks clarification of Blackwood's past and future terms.
Blackwood explains a blunder in the previous terms of the lease of the copyright.

In discussing Deronda in a letter to Harriet Beecher Stowe, deplores English misunderstanding of the Jews: 'The best that can be said of it is, that it is a sign of the intellectual narrowness - in plain English, the stupidity - which is still the average mark of our culture' (Cross 3: 295). GHL tells Blackwood that a royalty arrangement would be preferable to a down sum for the renewed copyright lease.
GE explains to Blackwood the reasons for preferring a royalty arrangement, discussing also her disappointment with reviews of Deronda.
Has tooth extracted.
Blackwood apologises for being unable to make a more generous offer.

Sympathises with Cara Bray's illness, sends items of personal news, and comments, 'It is remarkable to me that I have entirely lost my personal melancholy. I often, of course, have melancholy thoughts about the destinies of my fellow creatures; but I am never in that mood of sadness which used to be my frequent visitant even in the midst of external happiness. And this, notwithstanding a very vivid sense that life is declining and death close at hand' (Cross 3: 296-7). GHL agrees royalty terms for copyright lease, reminding Blackwood not to reveal to GE public disappointment with the Jewish sections of Deronda.
Taken by Cross to see The Heights at Witley, Surrey.
Records in Journal her disappointment at the critical reception of Deronda, but her gratification with its sales and approval by the Jewish community.
Buy The Heights at Witley. For GE's description of the house, see Cross 2: 298-9.
Notes in Journal pleasure at Jewish reception of Deronda and a second request to translate Romola into Italian.
Four volume Guinea edition of Deronda published by Blackwood. Assures Elizabeth Stuart Phelps that her attitude to Christianity has been consistent throughout her novels.
Sympathises with Cara Bray's illness, and indulges in several recollections of their past life.
GHL sends Christmas greetings to Elma Stuart, passing on GE's request for a letter from her.
Spend five days with Anna Cross.
Matthew Arnold present at their Boxing Day dinner.
Journal records anxiety over public affairs but concludes, 'As to our private life, all is happiness, perfect love, and undiminished intellectual interest' (Cross 3: 301).
Call on W. B. Scott.
Blackwood sends a cheque for £2215 to settle the previous year's account.
Edward Dowden tells Blackwood that he has had to abandon his plans to write a book on GE.
In response to a query from James Sully, GE replies that she believes the term 'meliorist' was her own coinage.
Edith Simcox inscribes copy of her newly published Natural Law for GE.

Suggests to Blackwood that Romola be included in his stereotyped edition of her works. Recommends Helen Allingham as an illustrator, and remarks that 'there is no book of mine about which I more thoroughly feel that I could swear by every sentence as having been written with my best blood' (Letters 3: 302).
Requests Andrew Clark to give an opinion on GHL's rheumatic gout.
Points out to Elma Stuart shortcomings in W. H. Mallock's 'Modern Atheism' in the January issue of the Contemporary Review.

Blackwood agrees to publish a stereotyped edition of Romola, and suggests GE or GHL approach Helen Allingham regarding illustrations, also including an assessment of GE's work by his retired chief proof-reader.
Invites Helen Allingham to illustrate stereotyped edition of Romola (declined).
Has severe renal attack.
Further kidney trouble.

GHL suggests a uniform edition of the novels to Blackwood - eventually the 'Cabinet' edition. Also agrees to an illustrated edition of Romola, and hints that Dowden should be urged to reconsider the possibility of a study of GE.
Go to see pictures by Millais.
Gives hints on writing in Midlands dialect to William Allingham.
Dinner with Elizabeth Benzon, where Joachim plays for them.
Attend music party given by Leighton, hearing Joachim, Petri and Piatti.
Blackwood makes further suggestions for the Cabinet edition.
Suggests the Cabinet edition comprise eight volumes. Sends strictures on Harriet Martineau’s Autobiography to Cara Bray.
Hear performance of Beethoven's posthumous string quartets.
Again asks Elma Stuart to send more detailed news of herself.
Morning encounter with Tennyson, one of many meetings at this time. Attend the last Saturday Pops Concert of the season.
Further suggestions from Blackwood about the Cabinet edition, to which GHL replies on the 29th with an idea of his own - that the edition be set from existing type but on finer paper.
Tennyson reads Maud and the two 'Northern Farmer' poems to a group of their friends at The Priory.
Commiserates with Mary Cash on the death of her father, John Sibree.
Vol. III of GHL's Problems published.
Thanks Mrs Burne-Jones for the offer of tickets to a showing of her husband's pictures, and mentions her problems in contemplating a new morning dress.
Blackwood announces that he has finally decided that the Cabinet edition should be in 19 or 20 volumes.
Liszt writes to introduce the Wagners.
Attend private view at the Royal Academy.
First meeting with Cosima Wagner, daughter of Liszt. Considerable contact with the Wagners in the ensuing weeks.
GE asks Burne-Jones if she may introduce Cosima Wagner to him.
Returns to Clementia Taylor her husband's Some Account of the Taylor Family and Auld Lang Syne.
Attend a rehearsal of Die Walküre and Tannhäuser.
Attend rehearsal of Siegfried and Lohengrin, afterwards taking Cosima Wagner to Burne-Jones's studio.

Princess Louise asks to be introduced to GE at a dinner with the Goschens. GE offers £10 towards the education of Joan Grüner, a Girton student. Tells Sara Hennell of her dislike of Harriet Martineau's Autobiography: 'the more I think of the book and all connected with it, the more it deepens my repugnance... to autobiography' (Letters 3: 306-7).
Sends Barbara Bodichon a list of the current Italian names for the water-wagtail.
Hear Wagner read Parzival. GE sends Catherine Paget a copy of her works as a wedding present.
Attend rehearsal of Tristan und Isolde.
Begin three-day visit to Jowett.
Thanks William Allingham for a copy of his Hunterian Oration.
Returns to Trübner the Jewish books consulted for Deronda. Expresses her gratitude to Elma Stuart for a gift of embroidery.
Warmly thanks David Kaufman for his favourable review of Deronda. Servants move in to The Heights, Witley, whilst GE and GHL go to Cambridge for five days, staying with the Sidgwicks.

Arrive at Witley, where reading includes Scott, Heart of Midlothian, and Legend of Montrose; Richardson, Sir Charles Grandison; Dumas, Les Trois mousquetaires; Trollope, The American Senator; Reade, A Woman Hater; Turgenev, Virgin Soil; Zola, L'Assommoir; Tennyson, Idylls of the King, and plays. Much contact with Sir Henry and Lady Holland at this period.
Thanks Charles Ritter for sending translations of extracts from Deronda.
GHL writes to Cross expressing delight with The Heights.
Harrison asks if GE might state the extent of her commitment to Positivism, eventually giving rise to publication of' A College Breakfast Party'.
Promises to bear in mind Harrison's request for some Positivist substitutes for Christian family prayers.
GHL tells Tennyson that he and GE have just read Harold for the first time, and Mary for the fourth. Hope to see him over the summer.
GHL invites Blackwood to call at Witley at his convenience.
Reading Life, Letters and Literary Remains of John Keats, ed. R. M. Milnes.
Birth of Elinor, third daughter of Charles Lewes.
GHL sends Blackwood a copy of Kaufman's pamphlet on GE and Judaism, advising him to choose a translator carefully.
GHL sends to Elma Stuart an anecdotal letter, reporting great delight with the Heights.
Thanks Charles Ritter for the gift of his translated anthology of her works, Fragments et pensées.
Harrison spends the day at Witley.
Asks William Allingham not to forget to send his news.
Cross introduces GE to tennis, subsequently a much-enjoyed recreation.
Visit Tennyson.
Begin five-day visit to the Bullock-Halls.
Return to London.
Visited at Witley by Jowett.
Introduced by Cross to badminton.
GHL tells Lady Holland how GE started to write fiction (Letters 9: 169).
Informs David Kaufman that his article on Deronda has now been translated.
Condemns W. H. Mallock's New Republic in letter to Mary Ponsonby: 'I think direct personal portraiture - or caricature - is a bastard kind of satire' (Cross 3: 317).
Leave Witley, GE much strengthened in health, for five-day visit to the Bullock-Halls at Six Mile Bottom. Blackwood apologises for being unable to offer greater remuneration for the Cabinet edition.
Return to The Priory.
Attends christening of grand-daughter Elinor at Rosslyn Hill.

Thanks Cross for the gift of a badminton set, and admits to finding 'some smaller wholes among the lyrics' rather than In Memoriam or the Idylls, 'the works most decisive of Tennyson's high place among the immortals' (Cross  3: 318).
Edith Simcox disappointed at GE's failure to comment on her Natural Law.

Declines to contribute a volume on Shakespeare to the 'English Men of Letters’ series. Records in Journal, 'We are at last in love with our Surrey house, and mean to keep it.
