The air and abundant exercise have quite renovated my health, and I am in more bodily comfort than I have known for several years' (Cross 3: 319).
GE at last refers, somewhat lukewarmly, to Edith Simcox's Natural Law.

Thanks Elizabeth Stuart Phelps for the gift of her The Story of Avis, which she is reading slowly; also repeating her misgivings about the benefits of reading contemporary fiction, and the quality of modem criticism.

Outlines her attitude to human misery in response to a cri de coeur from Myers: 'I only long, if it were possible to me, to help in satisfying the need of those who want a reason for living in the absence of what has been called consolatory belief' (Letters 9: 201). Sends Sara Hennell the customary letter of accumulated news in anticipation of her birthday.
Blackwood sends proof of 'A College Breakfast Party', and good news of sales of the one-volume edition of Deronda. Also seeks GE’s permission for Main’s new project, The George Eliot Birthday Book.
Main compiling his GE Birthday Book. Thanks Sara Hennell for her letter, attempting to explain off-handedness in Herbert Spencer's conduct, and attacking Mallock's New Republic.
Writes affectionately to D’Albert.
Writes to withdraw from spending Christmas with the Burne-Jones family.
Sends Main suggestions for the Birthday Book.
Visited by Edith Simcox, a visit recorded in some detail in Simcox's autobiography (see Letters 9: 206-7).
Sends Main criticisms of the draft Birthday Book.
GHL sends Christmas greetings to Elma Stuart and Anna Cross.
Christmas spent quietly at home, Anna Cross being ill.
Visited by Charles Lewes and family. Writes to Charlotte Carmichael, regretting her inability to do anything to increase appreciation of the Celts.

Ends her Journal with conflicting views about the prospect of further literary achievements, and acknowledging the usefulness of the Journal in the past: 'I have often been helped, in looking back in it, to compare former with actual states of despondency.... In this way a past despondency has turned to present hopefulness' (Cross 3: 324).
Leslie Stephen among the Sunday-afternoon callers.
Thanks Elma Stuart for the gift of a writing board.
Trollope calls, following his return from South Africa.
Asks Edith Simcox to obtain for the [sic] The Child's Own Book, and pays her for a copy of Cobbett's Rural Rides, also discussing the moral responsibilities and influence of the writer.

Reading includes J. R. Green, History of the English People, and W. E. H. Lecky, A History of England in the Eighteenth Century. Mentions the phonograph in a letter to Barbara Bodichon, and rejoices at London University opening its degrees to women.
Blackwood sends a cheque for £1006 and an account of sales in the past year.
Discusses liking for Pascal and La Bruyére in letter to Blackwood.
GHL tells Barbara Bodichon of his interest in a patient fitted successfully with a false larynx.
GE indulges in much philosophical conversation during a call on Edith Simcox.
Thanks Louise Houlton for the gift of her Swallow Flights.
GHL presented to Princess Christian.
Attend marriage of Elinor Locker to Lionel Tennyson.
Edith Simcox discusses 'The Lifted Veil' with GE and GHL.
Asks Barbara Bodichon to write with news of herself.
Attend concert at the Royal Academy of Music , performers including Henschel, Joachim, Piatti and Strauss, all of whom GE and GHL hear several times this season.
See the telephone demonstrated.
Discusses Wagner's setting of Heine's 'The Two Grenadiers' (heard at concert on the 20th) in letter to Georgiana BurneJones.
Thanks Elma Stuart for sending her violets, discussing - inter alia - her recent musical experiences.
Attend musical party given by Charlotte Moscheles.
Entertain Tennyson to dinner.
Explains to Lord Houghton that she is unable to receive the American poet and journalist Louise Moulton, having a horror of being interviewed or written about.
Dine with Tennyson.
Lord Acton sends a personal eulogy of her work.
Tells Cross, 'Non omnis moriar is a keen hope with me' (Cross 2: 226).
Take Emily Clarke to see Irving in Boucicault's Louis XI.
Attend private view at the Royal Academy.
Jowett writes, 'The more I think of it the more I agree in what you said that the really great and abiding interest of philosophy is human motive' (Letters 9: 227).
Asks Barbara Bodichon to recommend a housekeeper, and also a governess for the Bullock-Halls. William Blackwood sends a highly satisfactory statement of sales of the Cabinet edition.
Order furniture for Witley.
Edith Simcox finds Shakespeare's generic superiority to other dramatists a topic of Sunday afternoon conversation.
Attend a dinner given by the Goschens for the Crown Prince and Princess Royal. Many 'swells' present.
Sends Cara Bray her favourable impression of the Crown Prince and Princess Royal.
Begin three-day visit to Jowett. For details see Letters 7: 30- 1.
Hopes that Blackwood has enjoyed his travels, and that he continues to appreciate a holiday from business.
'A College Breakfast Party' published in Macmillan's Magazine.
Start reading P. G. Hamilton's Modern Frenchmen.
Advises Cara Bray on a publication problem with her Elements of Morality.
William Blackwood sends a half-year statement of sales.

Reaffirms, in a letter to Clementia Taylor, her refusal to speak on public topics: 'My function is that of the aesthetic, not the doctrinal teacher - the rousing of the nobler emotions, which make mankind desire the social right, not the prescribing of special measures , concerning which the artistic mind, however strongly moved by social sympathy, is often not the best judge' (Cross 3: 330).
Decide that GHL’s health will prevent their visiting Blackwood in Scotland.
Tells D’Albert: 'You remember me as much less of a conservative than I have now become ' (Letters 7: 47).
Sends William Blackwood corrections for Cabinet edition of Jubal and Deronda.
Visited by Edith Simcox, who notices GHL's deteriorating health.
Sends advice to Charles Ritter on his French translation of 'O May I Join the Choir Invisible'.
GHL is read part of Tennyson's unfinished Becket, about which GHL records serious reservations.
Agrees typeface for Cabinet edition of Jubal.

Take the Tom Trollopes to visit Tennyson. GE records, 'I saw an expression in his face that always reminds me of a large dog laying down its ears and wagging its tail on being stroked and patted ' (Letters 9: 237).

Asks Georgiana Burne-Jones to send news of herself: 'We have been so ailing in the midst of our country joys, that I need to hear of my friends being well, as a ground for cheerfulness' (Cross 3: 332). GHL congratulates Alexander Macmillan on the first three volumes of the 'English Men of Letters’ series, which GE has read aloud.
Hopes Blackwood may be able to send better news of his own health.
Visiting the Bullock-Halls for four days, spends some time with Turgenev, who admires GE's work as she does his.
Henry James, calling at Witley, much upset to find their lack of interest in his Europeans. Turgenev sends GHL capsules for pain.
Tells Elma Stuart, 'The larger world is so sad, with its wars and rumours of wars, that one is more than ever in need of the small world of specially beloved ones' (Letters 7: 75).
Leave The Heights for the Gloucester Hotel, Brighton.
Return to London.
Reads proof for Cabinet edition of Deronda.
GHL told by Sir James Paget of thickening of his mucous membrane.
Sends Blackwood first section of manuscript of Impressions of Theophrastus Such.
Blackwood declares himself delighted with the new work.
Tells Barbara Bodichon , 'I have a deep sense of change within, and of a permanently closer companionship with death' (Letters 7: 84).
Death of GHL following eight days of intense illness. Diagnosed with enteritis.
Funeral of GHL. GE not present. Reads In Memoriam, Shakespeare and Donne, but is unable to answer any of the many letters of sympathy received.
Death of Anna Cross.
Receives proofs of Such.
Records in diary, 'Here I and sorrow sit' (Letters 3: 345). Unable to see the Burne-Jones family.
Completes second reading of GHL's unfinished Problems.
GE records in her diary that she is feeling, “Weary and heavy laden.” Edith Simcox meets Cross at The Priory.

Writes to Barbara Bodichon, her first letter since GHL’s death: 'I bless you for all your goodness to me, but I am a bruised creature, and shrink even from the tenderest touch' (Cross 3: 346). Other letters follow.
GE records in her diary, “Head miserable and heart bruised.”
Agrees to correct proofs of Such, but only because this would have been GHL's wish, and out of consideration for Blackwood.
Ruminating on some kind of educational memorial to GHL.
Reads through GHL's journals. Tells Cross, 'Some time, if I live, I shall be able to see you - perhaps sooner than anyone else - but not yet' (Cross 3: 347).
GE records in her diary, “Wrote memories, and lived with him all day. Read in his diary 1874—‘Wrote verses to Polly—Wrote verses on Polly’.”
Acknowledges cheque from Blackwood for £m.
Again declines to see even Cross: 'When I said some time I meant still a distant time' (Cross 3: 347). Attack of renal pain.
Formally changes name to Mary Ann Evans Lewes with a legal Deed of Declaration, two months and a day after Lewes’s death. Visited by Sir James Paget.
Reports improved health to Georgiana Burne-Jones, but the onset of a mental winter.
Tells Barbara Bodichon she does not feel able to go away with her.
Orders carriage for first time.
Tells Cross, 'In a week or two I think I shall want to see you' (Cross 3: 348).
Depressed by inability to complete vol. III of Problems.
Asks Allbutt to write an article on the effect of GHL's work, also mentioning idea of endowing an academic post in his memory.
Sees Cross, but refuses Spencer. Declines Cross's invitation to move for a time to Weybridge. Returns proof of Such.
Tells Blackwood that, though she will continue to correct proofs, publication of Such must be postponed.
Death of W. K. Clifford (GE subsequently contributed to fund for his widow).
Requests revise proof of Such. Tells Barbara Bodichon that she is now driving out on most days.
Gertrude Lewes brings the grand-children to tea.
Henry Sidgwick discusses plans for the establishment of the GHL Studentship. GE authorises D’Albert's translation of Scenes.
Michael Foster suggests trustees for the Studentship.
Trübner discusses the printing of Problems.
Reads Problem II in volume V of Problems.
Signs her will. Visited by Cross, whose services become increasingly necessary and accepted.
Sees Maria Congreve - an indication of the gradual return towards light social engagements.
Moves back into the bedroom once shared with GHL. Call from Spencer, seeking advice on his Autobiography. Invites Georgiana Burne-Jones to visit her.
Blackwood sends revise proof of Such.
Asks Blackwood to supervise arrangements for foreign editions of Such.
Sends volume IV of Problems to printer.
So dissatisfied with Such that she writes to tell Blackwood of her decision to suppress it.
Tells Cara Bray that she will receive an annuity in her will.
Agrees to Blackwood's suggestion of publishing Such in May. Visits Charles Lewes’s house for the first time.
Diary records, 'A mental crisis. Occupied with his writings' (Letters 7: 130).

Invites the Harrisons to call. Visited by Elma Stuart. Explains the idea of the GHL Studentship in a letter to Barbara Bodichon: 'That there should always, in consequence of his having lived, be a young man working in the way he would have liked to work, is a memorial of him that comes nearest my feeling' (Letters 3: 355).
Tells Blackwood she is now taking a drive every day.

Letter to Harriet Beecher Stowe tells of struggle in coming to terms with bereavement: 'Formerly everything was easy because the supreme human blessing of perfect love was always with me. Now everything seems difficult. And yet I feel as if I were blaspheming to write that - for the Past is not dead, and in all I do, it is a living influence' (Letters 7: 132).
Letter to David Kaufman is one of several of this period regretting 'our having been betrayed into an unjustifiable war in South Africa' (Cross 3: 358).
Requests Cross's immediate advice on whether to lend Bessie Belloc £500: loan refused. Blackwood specifies 3000 copies for first edition of Such.
Queries the royalties for Such.
Visited by the Bullock-Halls.

Eliza Lewes and her children return to London from South Africa, and on the 29th are entertained at The Priory. But GE tells Eliza that the family may not live there, and informs Edith Simcox that the 'morbid time of repulsion' is over 'for ever' (Letters 9: 267).
Advises William Blackwood on terms for foreign editions and translations of Such. Correspondence on this subject continues over the first two-thirds of this month.
Visited by the Calls, and Eleanor and Florence Cross.
Burne-Jones calls.
Andrew Clark makes recommendations for the GHL Studentship.

GE's diary records a 'Crisis' - cause unknown; Harris and Johnston suggest it’s connected to her developing relationship with John Cross, writing “it is tempting to read [these entries] as anticipations of their marriage” (152). .
Receives Such, and volume IV of Problems.
Sees Trollope.
Leaves for Witley, where Cross visits her once or twice a week, and they continue to study Dante.
Badly afflicted by further renal pain.
Plays piano for first time since GHL's death.
Hears that Such is going into second impression. Advises James Sully on GHL's contributions to periodicals.
Visited by Barbara Bodichon, who reports to her sister an enormous improvement in GE's spirits: 'In fact, I think she will do more for us than ever' (Cross 3: 367).
Thanks William Blackwood for sending details of foreign sales, and tells anecdotes about the reception of her books.
Confined to bed for three days, the complaint not finally lifting until the beginning of August.
Tells Blackwood, 'Yesterday I was in more acute pain than I have ever known in my life before' (Letters 3: 367). Much gratified by the public reception of Impressions of Theophrastus Such.

Tells Georgiana Burne-Jones that 'there is a devoted friend who is backwards and forwards continually to see that I lack nothing' (Cross 3: 369). Thanks Blackwood for sending The Ethics of George Eliot by J.C. Brown.
Blackwood reports the continued success of Such.
Reports, 'The weather is a greater calamity even than the Zulu war' (Letters 7: 183) - the exceptionally poor summer does little to aid her recovery.
Reports to Charles Lewes taking her first drive 'for a long while' (Letters 7: 188).
Thanks James Sully for his continued help with GHL's Problems.
Invites Georgiana Burne-Jones to visit her at Witley. Thanks G. J. Holyoake for The History of Co-operation in England, which she has been reading.
Reports to Clementia Taylor that she hopes she is now fully recovered from her eight-week illness.
Records in diary, “Decisive conversation,” suggested to be her refusal of a proposal from Cross.
GHL Studentship at Cambridge inaugurated.

Tells William Blackwood of her continued delight at the quick sales of Such, asks for news of the translation of Kaufman's pamphlet on Deronda, and recommends a schoolfriend, Bradley Jenkins, if ever Blackwood should require French translations. Invites Barbara Bodichon to stay.
Suggests alterations in James Sully's article on GHL, especially recommending omission of GHL's criticism of Browning's obscurity.
Barbara Bodichon begins four-day visit to The Heights. Sends off the last proofs of Problems.
William Blackwood, revealing that his uncle has had to retire on medical grounds, reports over 6000 copies of Such sold, and offers an extra lump sum.
Appreciates gift from Anna Merritt of her Henry Merritt: Art Criticism and Romance.
GE sends letter to Cross, signing herself Beatrice, and admitting her feelings for him.
Delighted at the success of Charles Smart Roy's application for the GHL Studentship.

Hears of Blackwood’s severe illness, telling Charles Lewes, 'He has been bound up with what I most cared for in my life for more than twenty years; and his good qualities have made many things easy to me that, without him, would often have been difficult' (Letters 3: 383).
Death of Blackwood. Rejects W. L. Bicknell's request to dramatise Romola.
Visits the Crosses.
Returns to The Priory; reading there with Cross includes Dante, Chaucer, Shakespeare, Wordsworth, and Sainte-Beuve’s Causeries.
Suggests new format for Sayings to William Blackwood.
Reading Jowett's Thucydides.
Sixtieth birthday.
'Another turning-point' (Letters 7: 91).
Visits GHL's grave.
Reads GHL's Letters packing them together to be buried with her.
Answers query on the word 'adust' for James Murray's New English Dictionary.
Vol. V of Problems published.
Acknowledges receipt of the bound manuscript of Theophrastus Such, and counsels William Blackwood against the inclusion of too much easily written criticism in his magazine.
Tells Elma Stuart she would rather not have a portrait or bust of GHL: 'I am afraid of outward images lest they should corrupt the inward' (Letters 7: 235). Eliza Lewes and children to lunch.

Requests Edith Simcox to stop calling her 'Mother', confiding that 'her associations otherwise with the name were as of a task and it was a fact that her feeling for me was not at all a mother's.' (Letters 9: 283)
Jowett sends her New Year wishes and literary encouragement: 'you must not throw this precious trust away' (Letters 9: 286).
Congratulates Edward Clodd on his Jesus of Nazareth, whilst also expressing differences. Bret Harte introduced.

Thanks Clementia Taylor for her New Year greetings, mentioning that public calamities, such as the war in Afghanistan, have helped place her personal sorrow in perspective, and that she is now seeing several friends.
Reading the Odyssey, and C. P. Tiele's Outlines of the History of Religion.
Congratulates Frederick Myers on his engagement.
Reading Chaucer's General Prologue to the Canterbury Tales.
Pays second visit of the month to the Grosvenor Gallery.
Consults Croom Robertson about disposition of library.
Declines permission for Sydney M. Samuel to dramatise Deronda.
George Smith discusses de luxe edition of Romola, to whose publication GE assents.
Expresses satisfaction with new edition of Sayings.
Admits in an interview with Edith Simcox that she has never connected with women as easily as she has with men.
Sunday callers include Barbara Bodichon, Spencer, and the Harrisons.
Begins two-day visit to Weybridge.
Presides at sixth birthday party of GHL's grand-daughter Maud.

Tells Paget of Cross's third proposal. Accepts Paget's advice, and consents in the evening. Cross reports, 'It was finally decided that our marriage should take place as soon, and as privately, as might be found practicable' (Letters 3: 387).
GE and Cross inspect 4 Cheyne Walk, soon to become their residence.
Tells Eleanor Cross, 'I quail a little in facing what has to be gone through-the hurting of many whom I care for.... The springs of affection are reopened in me' (Cross 3: 388).
Discusses Wordsworth in letter to Harrison, recommending Moxon's one-volume edition, and regretting some omissions in Arnold's selection from the poet.
Tells Georgiana Burne-Jones that she is 'tired of being set on a pedestal and expected to vent wisdom' (Haight, p. 537; Letters 7: 263).
Begins three-day visit to Weybridge. Thanks Lady Lytton for sending her photograph, speculating on the events which have contrived to make her look sadder, and assuring her of continual friendship.
Thanks James Sully for his sympathetic review of vol. V of GHL’s Problems in the Academy.
Much gratified by the sensitive feelings displayed by Charles Lewes in a long interview. He undertakes to break the news of the marriage to Edith Simcox and others.

Writes to Georgiana Burne-Jones: 'A great momentous change is taking place in my life - a sort of miracle in which I could never have believed' (Letters 7: 269). Letters also sent to William Blackwood, Barbara Bodichon, Cara Bray and Maria Congreve.

Journal records, 'Married this day at 10.15 to John Walter Cross at St George's Hanover Square. Present, Charles, who gave me away, Mr and Mrs Druce, Mr Hall, William, Eleanor, and Florence Cross. We went back to The Priory, where we signed our wills. Then we started for Dover, and arrived there a little after five o'clock' (Cross 3: 393). Subsequent honeymoon takes them to France, Italy and Germany. Congratulations sent by William Blackwood and Frederic Harrison.
Sends Eleanor Cross an account of their honeymoon travels, a 'chronicle of our happy married life, three days long' (Cross  3: 394).
Henry James sends wedding congratulations.
Isaac Evans sends wedding congratulations, breaking a silence of 23 years.

Writes to Charles Lewes from Grenoble, 'I had but one regret in seeing the sublime beauty of the Grande Chartreuse. It was that the Pater had not seen it. I would still give up my own life willingly if he could have the happiness instead of me. But marriage has seemed to restore me to my old self' (Letters 3: 396).
Tells Florence Cross, 'I have been uninterruptedly well, and feel quite strong with all sorts of strength except strongmindedness' (Cross  3: 397).
Replies to her brother's letter, 'Our long silence has never broken the affection for you which began when we were little ones' (Cross  3: 398).
See Rossi in Hamlet. GE even less impressed than in London.
Gives Charles Lewes details of the rest of their proposed itinerary.

Explains to Barbara Bodichon the odd circumstances of her wedding: 'I really did not finally, absolutely decide- I was in a state of doubt and struggle - until only a fortnight before the event took place, so that at last everything was done in the utmost haste' (Letters 3: 401).
Begin three weeks in Venice.
Tells Charles Lewes they are reading Ruskin, 'using his knowledge gratefully, and shutting our ears to his wrathful innuendoes against the whole modem world' (Cross  3: 405).
Again writes to Maria Congreve about her marriage: 'The whole history is something like a miracle-legend' (Cross  3: 406).
Cross suffers mental derangement in Venice, jumping into the Grand Canal. GE horrified. See Cross 3: 407-8, Haight, p. 544 and Maddox, pp. 204-09.
Telegraphs for William Cross.
GE and Cross travel to Verona.
GE and Cross travel to Wildbad, 'which, we hope, will put the finishing-touch to J.'s recovery of his usual health', GE tells Charles Lewes (Cross 3: 408).
Return to Witley. Reading on their journey home included novels by Daudet and Sand.
Sends Barbara Bodichon an account of Cross's illness.
Apologises to Clementia Taylor for failing to send advance warning of her marriage.
Asks Alice Helps to send news of herself.
Tells Charles Lewes, 'Our life has had no more important events than calls from neighbours and our calls in return' (Cross  3: 413).
William Blackwood sends a report of sales, and congratulations on Charles Lewes's debut in Blackwood's Magazine.
Re-establishes contact with Elma Stuart.
Writes to Anna Druce with details of the weight of the human brain.
Acknowledges gift of Elizabeth Phelps's Sealed Orders.
New burial law, permitting Dissenters to have their own services in churchyards, receives royal assent.

Tells Barbara Bodichon, 'Our only bugbear - it is a very little one - is the having to make preliminary arrangements towards settling ourselves in the new house.... I am become so lazy that I shrink from all such practical work' (Letters 3: 416).
Tells Charles Lewes, 'We supply the want of regular lawn tennis by in-door battledore and shuttlecock, at which I am becoming an expert... ' (Letters 7: 325).
Calls doctor, 'my ailments being no better' (Letters 7: 326).
George Smith sends six copies of a (limited) de luxe edition of Romola, and an honorarium of £100.
Cross takes GE to Brighton for 10 days in attempt to clear renal trouble: 'The first effects of the sea breezes were encouraging, but the improvement was not maintained' (Cross  3: 416-17).
Smith publishes de luxe edition of Romola.

Taken seriously ill, and confined to bed. Asks Cross to read Bridges’s translation of Comte’s Discours preliminaire to her: 'This volume was one of her especial favourites, and she delighted in making me acquainted with it' (Cross  3: 419).
Andrew Clark comes to Witley to examine GE.
Recovered sufficiently to play the piano.
Sends condolences to D’Albert on the death of his wife.
GE's sixty-first birthday.
Reads Comte and begins Goethe's Hermann und Dorothea.
Sends news of herself to Cara Bray, though conceding 'It is difficult to give you materials for imagining my world' (Cross 3: 434-5).
Leave Witley for temporary stay in a London hotel, where reading includes Comte, and Tennyson's Ballads and Other Poems (1880), in which 'The First Quarrel' is particularly admired.
Move to 4 Cheyne Walk.
Attend their first Pops Concert together, hearing Neruda and Piatti.
Invites Maria Congreve to visit them at Cheyne Walk.
Attend a performance of Aeschylus's Agamemnon by Oxford undergraduates.
Attend Pops Concert at St James's Hall.
Visited by Spencer and Edith Simcox. Suddenly taken ill.
Dies at 4 Cheyne Walk.
Cross tells Elma Stuart, 'I am left alone in this new House we meant to be so happy in' (Letters 7: 351).
Cross sends GE's last, unfinished, letter to Lady Jane Strachey.

Funeral at Highgate Cemetery. Cross remarks, Her spirit joined that choir invisible 'whose music is the gladness of this world' (Cross 3: 439). Engraves Mary Ann Cross and Of those immortal dead who live again in minds made better by their presence on her cemetery stone.
